covid19scenario-110-0.sentence: No evidence flu vaccines make children more vulnerable to coronavirus infections

covid19scenario-110-3.sentence: Social media posts claim children vaccinated against the flu are at a significantly higher risk of contracting other respiratory infections, including coronaviruses.

covid19scenario-110-4.sentence: This is false; large studies in British Columbia and the US found no evidence that the influenza vaccine increases the risk of contracting a coronavirus, and health officials throughout North America recommend the flu vaccine for children during the COVID-19 pandemic.

covid19scenario-110-5.sentence: “Bombshell as flu shots found to cause huge increases in coronavirus infections,” says the headline of an article shared as a screenshot on July 31, 2020 on Facebook.

covid19scenario-110-6.sentence: “Children who are vaccinated with flu shots have a 440 percent increase in risk of contradicting other respiratory infections such as coronavirus, researchers found in a published paper,” claims the post, which also circulated on Instagram.

covid19scenario-110-7.sentence: Screenshot of a Facebook post taken on August 3, 2020

covid19scenario-110-8.sentence: Several posts claim the evidence came from “The British Medical Journal,” sharing this link.

covid19scenario-110-9.sentence: However, that is not a scientific study, but rather a response to an article about the COVID-19 pandemic from a retired pediatrician.

covid19scenario-110-10.sentence: BMJ executive editor Theodora Bloom explained in an email that “Rapid responses” are comments to the editors that appear on the journal’s website but “are not indexed in PubMed and they are not journal articles.”

covid19scenario-110-11.sentence: “Although we moderate Rapid Responses to ensure they are not libellous, for example, they are certainly not endorsed by the publication,” she said.

covid19scenario-110-12.sentence: Another version of the post reveals that the source of the claim is an article on the website NaturalNews, one of a network of internet domains found to host health disinformation which AFP has fact-checked in the past.

covid19scenario-110-13.sentence: NaturalNews was removed from Facebook in May 2020 “for spammy and abusive behavior, not the content they posted,” according to a Facebook spokeswoman.

covid19scenario-110-14.sentence: “They misled people about the popularity of their posts and relied on content farms in Macedonia and the Philippines.”

covid19scenario-110-15.sentence: Screenshot of a Facebook post taken on August 3, 2020

covid19scenario-110-16.sentence: Brian Ward, professor in the McGill University Department of Medicine, said in an email that the claim has been “cherry-picked from a very weak study.”

covid19scenario-110-17.sentence: It is based on a 2012 study titled: “Increased Risk of Noninfluenza Respiratory Virus Infections Associated With Receipt of Inactivated Influenza Vaccine.”

covid19scenario-110-18.sentence: The study was conducted from 2008-2009, a decade before the novel coronavirus pandemic, and only included 115 children during one flu season.

covid19scenario-110-19.sentence: It found that over nine months, the children in the group that received trivalent inactivated influenza vaccine “had an increased risk of virologically-confirmed non-influenza infections.”

covid19scenario-110-20.sentence: Ward explained that the study, though published in Clinical Infectious Diseases, has methodological flaws, including having 1.5 times more children in the flu vaccine group, compared to the placebo group.

covid19scenario-110-21.sentence: Sarah Gilbert, professor of vaccinology at the University of Oxford’s Nuffield Department of Medicine, also said in an email that it is important not to overstate the findings of a small study.

covid19scenario-110-22.sentence: Gilbert further explained: “It isn’t that the flu shot directly made children more susceptible to other viruses.”

covid19scenario-110-23.sentence: She said the children in the placebo group who were not vaccinated were more likely to get the flu and there seemed to be short-term protection from other viruses right after recovering from the flu.

covid19scenario-110-24.sentence: Based on this study, “no-one should make decisions to avoid flu vaccinations,” Gilbert said.

covid19scenario-110-26.sentence: Danuta Skowronski, the principal investigator at the British Columbia Center for Disease Control (BCCDC), published a study in May 2020 that included thousands of people over multiple flu seasons in Canada.

covid19scenario-110-27.sentence: It found the “influenza vaccine did not affect seasonal coronavirus risk.”

covid19scenario-110-28.sentence: Skowronski, who plays a critical role in Canada’s national influenza program, helped develop test negative design, a methodology used worldwide to monitor how well the influenza vaccine protects.

covid19scenario-110-29.sentence: Asked if there was any particular coronavirus risk to children who receive the flu shot, Skowronski said: “We saw no association in children nor in adults between the receipt of influenza vaccine and coronavirus risk.”

covid19scenario-110-30.sentence: Similarly, a 2013 study conducted in the US state of Wisconsin covering six flu seasons and including more than 3,000 patients found: “Influenza vaccination was not associated with detection of noninfluenza respiratory viruses.”

covid19scenario-110-31.sentence: Claims that a 2017 study also found the flu shot left people vulnerable to infections were also shown to be misleading by AFP Fact Check here.

covid19scenario-110-33.sentence: The US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices has not yet voted on the flu vaccine recommendations for 2020-2021, but Lisa Black, a spokeswoman for the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), said in an email that AAP has not changed its guidance because of the pandemic and “recommends that everyone over 6 months is vaccinated for influenza.”

covid19scenario-110-34.sentence: The same is true of the Canadian Paediatric Society.

covid19scenario-110-35.sentence: Spokeswoman Genevieve Brouillette said in an email: “Our general guidance (that everyone over 6 months of age be immunized against the seasonal flu) won’t be changing.”

covid19scenario-110-36.sentence: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said that how and where people get a flu vaccine may need to change due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

covid19scenario-110-37.sentence: This was echoed by Oxford’s Gilbert: “People leaving their homes to receive flu shots should take care to protect themselves against exposure to coronavirus by following all the public health guidelines on social distancing, handwashing and wearing face coverings.”

covid19scenario-110-38.sentence: The flu shot is a regular target of disinformation.

covid19scenario-15-0.sentence: Note: The objective of this report is to provide a snapshot overview of the current trends and insights into disinformation activities related to COVID-19/Coronavirus.

covid19scenario-15-1.sentence: It does not provide a comprehensive or complete overview and focusses primarily on the external dimension, in line with the European External Action Service (eeas) mandate.

covid19scenario-15-2.sentence: The report was authored by the EEAS Strategic Communications and Information Analysis Division, which contributes to the EU’s efforts to counter disinformation, including through detection, analysis and exposure of disinformation campaigns.

covid19scenario-15-3.sentence: In addressing disinformation and identifying and analysing disinformation surrounding the COVID-19 outbreak, the EEAS is working closely with the European Commission, European Parliament services and EU Member States.

covid19scenario-15-4.sentence: The EEAS also cooperates on this issue with international partners (G7, NATO and non-state actors).

covid19scenario-15-5.sentence: The results are regularly published on EUvsDisinfo.eu and social media channels.

covid19scenario-15-6.sentence: Insights are shared with EU institutions and EU Member States in real time, including through the Rapid Alert System on Disinformation.

covid19scenario-15-8.sentence: In line with the previous EEAS Special Reports and based on publicly available information, this edition gives an overview of recent developments around COVID-19 related disinformation.

covid19scenario-15-9.sentence: The report focusses on foreign state and non-state actors trying to exploit the uncertainty in societies as well as people’s fears and insecurities to advance their own agenda.

covid19scenario-15-10.sentence: While misinformation and disinformation[1] relating to issues surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic have continued to spread across the globe, the volume has – according to our findings – shown at least a temporary decrease during the period observed, alongside a general downward trend on COVID-19 related web searches[2].

covid19scenario-15-11.sentence: There is a crystallizing and clustering around specific topics and narratives: alleged links between COVID-19 and 5G networks; COVID-19 restrictions as pretext establishing global domination of secretive elites; and attacks on individuals engaged in the development of vaccines, especially Bill Gates.

covid19scenario-15-12.sentence: External actors, notably pro-Kremlin sources, are still involved in spreading disinformation, including by amplifying existing conspiracy theories, which link the COVID-19 pandemic to biological warfare, 5G technology and fuel anti-vaccination sentiment.

covid19scenario-15-13.sentence: The efforts of state actors like China to deflect blame, to use the pandemic to promote their own governmental system and enhance their image abroad continue.

covid19scenario-15-14.sentence: The claim that there are clandestine US biological laboratories on the territory of “former Soviet republics”[3] has been spread both by pro-Kremlin outlets as well as Chinese officials and state media.

covid19scenario-15-15.sentence: Disinformation around COVID-19 has real world consequences.

covid19scenario-15-16.sentence: It has become clear that disinformation is not just a potential health risk when false cures are propagated.

covid19scenario-15-17.sentence: The spread of false information pertaining to the 5G network has also led to multiple arson attacks on telecommunication infrastructure across Europe.

covid19scenario-15-19.sentence: In some regions and countries, the COVID-19 pandemic is used to restrict freedom of speech and freedom of the media.

covid19scenario-15-20.sentence: The EEAS has observed numerous cases in which governments or state officials have used the crisis to curtail media freedoms.

covid19scenario-15-21.sentence: The work of independent media and fact-checkers is crucial to deliver reliable and authoritative information about the pandemic.

covid19scenario-15-22.sentence: Continued threats and harassment against fact-checkers and fact-checking organisations are being observed.

covid19scenario-15-23.sentence: Social media companies continue to invest into detecting and countering misinformation and disinformation on their platforms.

covid19scenario-15-24.sentence: While the efforts are commendable, it is clear that much more needs to be done.

covid19scenario-15-25.sentence: In detail: COVID-19 related disinformation, propaganda and other activities (April 23 – 18 May)

covid19scenario-15-27.sentence: As the previous reports, this one focusses specifically on recent activities related to foreign state and non-state actors.

covid19scenario-15-28.sentence: Foreign actors have been trying to exploit citizens’ fears, insecurities and concerns for their own agenda, which must be distinguished from the legitimate democratic debate where citizens voice concerns and criticism in connection with the pandemic and measures taken by governments

covid19scenario-15-29.sentence: The information environment relating to COVID-19 continues to be crowded with disinformation and while many of the targets (the West as such, the EU and NATO, the United States) and themes remain the same, new targets have emerged, notably Bill and Melinda Gates and the Gates Foundation.

covid19scenario-15-30.sentence: Pro-Kremlin media outlets continue to disinform about COVID-19, however the intensity of the disinformation campaign seems to have decreased[5].

covid19scenario-15-31.sentence: Overall, the EUvsDisinfo database now contains nearly 500 examples of COVID-19-related pro-Kremlin disinformation.

covid19scenario-15-32.sentence: Although pro-Kremlin disinformation messages about EU actions in response to COVID-19 and EU solidarity continue to circulate, at least three English-language pro-Kremlin outlets reduced the number of COVID-19 related articles since the second half of April, compared to late March and the beginning of April.

covid19scenario-15-33.sentence: One of those outlets, “South Front”[6], has even removed a dedicated section on COVID-19 from its website.

covid19scenario-15-34.sentence: According to recent reports in Dutch media[7], the General Intelligence and Security service of the Netherlands has determined that Russian narratives about COVID-19 were shared in a number of Dutch-speaking social media groups.

covid19scenario-15-35.sentence: The narratives emphasized alleged lack of European solidarity in the field of COVID-19.

covid19scenario-15-36.sentence: Such findings are largely consistent with prominent pro-Kremlin disinformation narratives about COVID-19, reported by EUvsDisinfo.eu.

covid19scenario-15-37.sentence: Inside Russia, state-controlled channels continue to report on the domestic situation, acknowledging that COVID-19 is a complex challenge, including for Russia.

covid19scenario-15-38.sentence: At the same time, some state-controlled media outlets continue to spread false information about Bill Gates and vaccines; however in at least one case another state-run media outlet has called this out as “conspiracy theories” and challenged it[8].

covid19scenario-15-39.sentence: Russia’s state-controlled TV channels also used the broader COVID-19 situation to advance earlier-established disinformation narratives about the collapse of “perverse” Western values[9] (i.e.

covid19scenario-15-40.sentence: no one in Europe demands gay parades anymore) and abandonment of Ukraine (“the West have disposed of Ukraine like trash”)[10].

covid19scenario-15-41.sentence: In line with our previous analysis, China’s general aim of controlling the narrative on COVID-19 and deflecting any criticism of the country is still present.

covid19scenario-15-42.sentence: China – “having made sacrifices to buy time for the rest of the world”[11] – is portrayed as a responsible and transparent actor in the pandemic and a model for other countries to follow.

covid19scenario-15-43.sentence: In parallel, where established facts or prevailing narratives could be seen as unfavourable to China or could support criticism of Chinese authorities there seems to be the effort of creating doubt in relation to those.

covid19scenario-15-44.sentence: For example, creating doubts about China’s role in the COVID-19 outbreak[12] and countering international calls for an independent inquiry into the origins of the outbreak of the virus in China[13].

covid19scenario-15-45.sentence: At the same time, there has been a shift towards more directly challenging and mocking[14] the US administration and its response to the pandemic[15].

covid19scenario-15-46.sentence: China’s state-run media has been implying a US cover-up[16] and demanding answers from the country[17].

covid19scenario-15-47.sentence: Multiple Russian state-controlled media channels, including RIA Novosti news agency and RT[18], explicitly defended China in face of international criticism of handing the COVID-19 outbreak.

covid19scenario-15-48.sentence: EU-sanctioned TV host and media manager Dmitry Kiselyov compared criticism of the Chinese government to Russia being held responsible for the chemical attack in Salisbury[19] and meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential elections[20] – referring to two prominent pro-Kremlin disinformation narratives.

covid19scenario-15-49.sentence: Multiple pro-Kremlin outlets have reported (in Russian, French and English) about alleged clandestine US biological laboratories in Ukraine.

covid19scenario-15-50.sentence: The implication behind such disinformation messages is that the US is afraid of leakage[21] of infectious substances on its own territory, that such labs facilitated the US support for Euromaidan[22] that epidemics[23] start around the labs, and more directly that COVID-19 might have been created in one of the labs in Ukraine[24].

covid19scenario-15-51.sentence: These type of messages build on a prominent pro-Kremlin disinformation narrative about the “secret military laboratories”, most notably in the case of Lugar lab in Georgia.

covid19scenario-15-52.sentence: As such, they are easily replicated throughout the region: in Armenia, Georgia, Moldova[25].

covid19scenario-15-53.sentence: The same conspiracy theory about US biological laboratories in former Soviet republics has been also spread by Chinese officials and state media.

covid19scenario-15-54.sentence: This started with statements of a Russian Foreign ministry spokesperson[26] in mid-April, which were later referred to by a Chinese MFA spokesperson[27].

covid19scenario-15-55.sentence: It has been tweeted more than once by an official account of the Chinese MFA[28] and covered by China’s state-run media[29].

covid19scenario-15-56.sentence: RT Russian in turn published an article quoting concerns[30] of a representative of China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs about these alleged laboratories[31].

covid19scenario-15-57.sentence: The messaging by Chinese officials and media talk about the need to address “concerns from local people and surrounding countries” or “international concerns”.

covid19scenario-15-58.sentence: The US biolab theory has become embedded into Chinese state media articles implying a wider cover-up by the US[32].

covid19scenario-15-59.sentence: Nature magazine has reported[33] that Chinese state media[34] and officials[35] have been heavily promoting unproven traditional Chinese medicines (TCM) as treatments for COVID-19, including highlighting the sending of TCM to third countries as international aid.

covid19scenario-15-60.sentence: [36] However, there is currently no scientific proof of any medicine preventing or curing COVID-19, a fact also confirmed by the WHO[37].

covid19scenario-15-61.sentence: Freedom House has stated in their overview of Chinese activities[38] that “since March, coordinated and covert attempts by China-linked actors to manipulate information—particularly regarding COVID-19” have been detected in a number of countries, with content often delivered in local languages.

covid19scenario-15-62.sentence: The analysis also highlights a departure from Beijing’s more traditional model of positive propaganda combined with suppression of criticism.

covid19scenario-15-63.sentence: That expanding nature of the Chinese influence toolbox – including a more confrontational tone and “Russian-style disinformation tactics” – has been also noted by other analysts[39] and illustrated by various cases[40] mentioned in our current and previous reports.

covid19scenario-15-64.sentence: The Syrian regime is further advancing its disinformation campaign against sanctions claiming that Western countries are perpetrating an “economic war” against Syria and the Syrian people and that sanctions have crippled the health sector and are impeding the country’s response to COVID-19.

covid19scenario-15-65.sentence: This was reiterated by Assad claiming that COVID-19 comes in addition to “an economic challenge, which we have been facing as a result of over nine years and unjust sanctions imposed on our people”[41].

covid19scenario-15-66.sentence: Prior to that, the regime’s political representative to the UN further advanced this narrative at a meeting of the UNSC on the humanitarian situation in Syria, claiming that “illegitimate economic measures prevent the medical and health bodies in Syria to obtain the necessary equipment for the test, diagnosis and prevention and treatment of COVID-19”.

covid19scenario-15-68.sentence: Terrorist groups have been calling for an opportunistic use of the chaos and distraction caused by COVID-19 to perpetrate attacks.

covid19scenario-15-71.sentence: When it comes to adverse narratives, the Global Coalition noted that COVID-19 is being described by Da’esh as a retribution for its activities in Iraq and Syria.

covid19scenario-15-72.sentence: An intense appearance of COVID-19 related mis- and disinformation was observed across the Western Balkans, together with an increased activity of local fact-checkers contributing to awareness raising and opening public debate on the issue both locally and internationally.

covid19scenario-15-73.sentence: Local independent fact-checkers are confirming cases of the spread of pseudo-science, conspiracy theories etc., including in relation to health advice and to the alleged impact of 5G networks on COVID-19.

covid19scenario-15-75.sentence: Bill Gates[45] and the Gates Foundation have been attacked by multiple actors throughout the last months.

covid19scenario-15-76.sentence: Similar to other private organisations, they are accused of sinister intentions, like seeking global domination[46].

covid19scenario-15-77.sentence: Building on top of these accusations, multilateral initiatives like the Global Pledging effort[47], which partners with private actors, are accused of generating money not for the fight against COVID-19, but to further their private interests.

covid19scenario-15-78.sentence: The COVID-19 pandemic is also used to undermine NATO presence in the Baltic States[48].

covid19scenario-15-79.sentence: A sophisticated influence operation, jointly targeting NATO, media, fact-checkers and state-institutions in the Baltic States[49], is an example of how the pandemic is instrumentalised in attempts to sow distrust among Western partners and intimidate individual voices of the press.

covid19scenario-15-80.sentence: The disinformation narratives used in such influence operations are consistent with those in pro-Kremlin media outlets, as observed by EUvsDisinfo[50].

covid19scenario-15-83.sentence: Twitter announced it would grant researchers access to a real-time data stream of “tens of millions of daily public tweets about COVID-19”, to track misinformation and disinformation.

covid19scenario-15-84.sentence: Twitter said that any developer or researcher with an approved Twitter developer account can apply for access to the COVID-19 stream if they meet certain criteria and the data is used for “the public good.” Twitter said it had never offered a full stream on a particular topic before.

covid19scenario-15-85.sentence: [51] Additionally, Twitter announced that they are introducing “new labels and warning messages that will provide additional context and information on some Tweets containing disputed or misleading information related to COVID-19”.

covid19scenario-15-87.sentence: Facebook announced in their April 2020 Coordinated Inauthentic Behaviour Report[53] that it took down 8 networks for coordinated inauthentic behaviour in April.

covid19scenario-15-88.sentence: Six of them (in the US, Georgia, Myanmar and Mauritania) focussed on domestic audiences.

covid19scenario-15-89.sentence: However, the other two were taken down for foreign interference, with one network emanating from Russia, and one from Iran.

covid19scenario-15-90.sentence: Facebook[54] removed numerous assets of outlets “News Front”[55] and “South Front”[56] (followed by over 270 thousand users) for coordinated inauthentic behaviour on behalf of a foreign entity.

covid19scenario-15-91.sentence: Ahead of the Facebook takedown, EUvsDisinfo exposed[57] these outlets as disseminating pro-Kremlin disinformation on multiple topics, including conspiracy theories about COVID-19 pandemic, vaccines and the global response[58].

covid19scenario-15-92.sentence: According to Facebook, the coordinated inauthentic activity originated in Russia, the non-government controlled areas in Donbas region and Crimea.

covid19scenario-15-93.sentence: “News Front” has previously been linked to the Russian security services (see: reporting by the DFR Lab[59] and Zeit[60]).

covid19scenario-15-94.sentence: Poynter’s Coronavirus Facts Alliance accounts for over 5.000 COVID-19 related fact-checks since February 2020[61], which signifies a significant burden.

covid19scenario-15-95.sentence: Facebook reported labelling about 50 million pieces of content related to COVID-19 on their platform alone with warnings, based on around 7,500 articles by their independent fact-checking partners[62].

covid19scenario-15-96.sentence: Platforms are also still vulnerable to being the tool for viral distribution of false information and conspiracy theories.

covid19scenario-15-97.sentence: In the beginning of May, for example, a pseudo-documentary[63] containing multiple cases of false, misleading and harmful claims spread with high velocity across the internet.

covid19scenario-15-98.sentence: It was first uploaded to YouTube and amplified by conspiracy groups on Facebook[64], gaining millions of views within only a few days.

covid19scenario-15-99.sentence: YouTube and Facebook have removed the “Plandemic” scene, saying that it spread inaccurate information about Covid-19 that could be harmful to the public.

covid19scenario-15-100.sentence: However, the video continued to circulate, as people post new copies.

covid19scenario-15-103.sentence: Bellingcat[67] has discovered an ongoing information operation on Twitter and Facebook using a network of bots made up of newly created and stolen accounts.

covid19scenario-15-104.sentence: The network is pushing topics supportive of the Chinese government and critical of either popular figures or protestors who are against it.

covid19scenario-15-105.sentence: Bellingcat claims that the “content of the accounts correlates with findings made in the past, both by Twitter[68] and other entities[69], of state-linked information operations that are being run out of People’s Republic of China.”

covid19scenario-15-106.sentence: The Citizen Lab at the University of Toronto, that has previously researched the broad COVID-19 related censorship on Chinese social media platforms[70], has discovered that communications among international users of WeChat – the most popular social media platform in China and third in the world – are subject to surveillance that was previously thought to be exclusively reserved for China-based accounts[71].

covid19scenario-15-107.sentence: Documents and images transmitted among non-China-registered accounts are monitored for content that is politically sensitive in China and then used to invisibly train WeChat’s Chinese online censorship system.

covid19scenario-15-108.sentence: Earlier research had found that all users who have registered their WeChat accounts with a Chinese phone number are subject to Chinese online censorship regime wherever they are located in the world, even if they have later changed their account to a non-Chinese phone number[72].

covid19scenario-15-109.sentence: This export of Chinese online censorship has raised questions about its role on politics in other countries[73].

covid19scenario-15-110.sentence: The Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) has reported a growing significance and impact of Chinese non-state actors on Western social media platforms.

covid19scenario-15-111.sentence: Across March and April, “a loosely coordinated pro-China trolling campaign on Twitter harassed Western media outlets, impersonated Taiwanese users in an effort to undermine Taiwan’s position with the World Health Organization (WHO), spread false information about the COVID-19 outbreak, and joined in pre-existing inauthentic social media campaigns”.

covid19scenario-15-113.sentence: Data from the Hamilton dashboard of GMF’s Alliance for Securing Democracy (ASD) shows that there has been a marked increase in the number of posts by Chinese officials on Twitter – from up to 4000 posts in December 2019 to 17.000 tweets in April since the COVID-19 crisis began in early 2020[75].

covid19scenario-15-115.sentence: ASD also found that COVID-19 related messaging on Chinese state media, government and diplomatic Twitter accounts in the end of April and beginning of May were attacking the United States for its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, accused Washington of spreading conspiracy theories and framed China as a victim of “scapegoating” from the West.

covid19scenario-15-116.sentence: Additionally, there was an aim to cast doubt on the virus’ origins in China and demonstrate China’s support for multilateral efforts to combat its spread.

covid19scenario-15-117.sentence: Other messaging signalled China’s return to normalcy, while highlighting the negative effects the virus is having inside the United States.

covid19scenario-132-1.sentence: Many pools and gyms are closing in an attempt to stop the spread of COVID-19, a virus that has upended daily life for millions of people around the globe.

covid19scenario-132-2.sentence: With lots of conflicting advice and misinformation floating around in cyberspace, we reached out to an expert, Roberta Lavin, a professor of medicine at the University of Tennessee’s College of Nursing, for guidance on how you can safely navigate these uncharted waters.

covid19scenario-132-3.sentence: (Here's some information on when you might be able to swim again and some resources for swimmers who are out of the water.)

covid19scenario-132-4.sentence: Can COVID-19 be transmitted via water?

covid19scenario-132-5.sentence: “It’s actually a respiratory virus,” Lavin says, meaning that the virus is transmitted via tiny droplets of spit and mucus that may be expelled when coughing and sneezing.

covid19scenario-132-6.sentence: These droplets can speed undetected from person to person, causing an infection after the virus enters a person’s eyes, nose, or mouth.

covid19scenario-132-7.sentence: Though this is the typical means of transmission, science is still sorting out the particulars of this new, or novel, coronavirus.

covid19scenario-132-8.sentence: “The question remains about all the modes of transmission, which we don’t know at this point.

covid19scenario-132-9.sentence: However, it’s not believed that it’s transmitted by water,” Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-10.sentence: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on March 10 that “the COVID-19 virus has not been detected in drinking water.

covid19scenario-132-11.sentence: Conventional water treatment methods that use filtration and disinfection, such as those in most municipal drinking water systems, should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-132-12.sentence: Does chlorine in pool water inactivate the virus?

covid19scenario-132-13.sentence: “The good news is that the average amount of chlorine that’s in a pool is going to kill the virus,” Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-14.sentence: Assuming that your pool is properly maintained, the disinfecting chemicals in the water should be enough to render the virus inactive.

covid19scenario-132-15.sentence: The CDC reported on March 10 that “there is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs.

covid19scenario-132-16.sentence: Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (e.g., with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-132-17.sentence: If chlorine inactivates the virus, can I go swim?

covid19scenario-132-18.sentence: “I think of all the things you could do, swimming is probably safer than most activities,” Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-19.sentence: But because most pools are housed inside a gym facility or other public space, that presents possibilities for infection before you ever reach the chlorinated water.

covid19scenario-132-20.sentence: “You have to assume that people are infected,” Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-22.sentence: It would be hard to get in and out of the pool without touching anything or interacting with another person.”

covid19scenario-132-23.sentence: Think about it: How many surfaces do you touch on a normal visit to and from the pool?

covid19scenario-132-24.sentence: You’re reaching for a door handle and using the card scanner or otherwise signing in.

covid19scenario-132-25.sentence: You’re getting changed and putting your clothes in a locker or on a bench.

covid19scenario-132-26.sentence: You’re touching a communal shower tap.

covid19scenario-132-27.sentence: If you use the restroom, that’s a whole other series of doors and surfaces to navigate.

covid19scenario-132-28.sentence: There’s plenty of places for a tiny, invisible virus to cling to and follow you home where it might infect you or a loved one.

covid19scenario-132-29.sentence: Emerging research suggests that the coronavirus can survive on hard surfaces like plastic and steel for up to three days.

covid19scenario-132-30.sentence: It may also hang in the air in tiny droplets called aerosols for up to a half an hour, at which time it can settle on surfaces.

covid19scenario-132-31.sentence: Though the risk of transmission from surfaces is relatively low, especially if you’re practicing good hand-washing hygiene, the bigger concern is the people you’ll meet at the pool.

covid19scenario-132-32.sentence: If you’re planning to take part in an organized Masters workout, it's probably best that you don't.

covid19scenario-132-33.sentence: When several swimmers get into a lane together to complete an interval workout, there’s the inevitable few moments at the wall (often while breathing heavily) in proximity to one another that can be a prime opportunity for viral transmission if one of you is carrying the virus.

covid19scenario-132-34.sentence: And not everyone who has the virus shows signs of infection.

covid19scenario-132-35.sentence: Theoretically, if you could go swim laps alone without touching any surfaces or coming into contact with another person, it might be safe to do so.

covid19scenario-132-36.sentence: “If swimmers were in a large Olympic-style pool swimming laps and there was one swimmer in every other lane, then they are probably 6 feet apart,” Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-37.sentence: But when was the last time you had that sort of arrangement at your local Masters practice?

covid19scenario-132-39.sentence: Part of our nature is to say, ‘Oh, no.

covid19scenario-132-40.sentence: I’m not getting sick,’ and you deny that it could be a possibility.

covid19scenario-132-41.sentence: And you go out and push through,” Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-42.sentence: “I think that’s one of the big problems for a lot of people, especially athletes.

covid19scenario-132-43.sentence: You deny that it could possibly be an injury or that you could possibly be sick and you’re going to soldier on through it.

covid19scenario-132-44.sentence: This is not the time to do that.”

covid19scenario-132-45.sentence: Is swimming in open water a better option?

covid19scenario-132-46.sentence: It’s often been said that the solution to pollution is dilution, and that may be true here, too, Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-47.sentence: “Because of the flow of the water and the amount of dilution in a larger body of water such as a lake or river, the virus would not be a concern.

covid19scenario-132-48.sentence: The bigger concern there is that you shouldn’t be swimming in a lake or river by yourself.

covid19scenario-132-49.sentence: And, of course, with social distancing, the goal is to keep people 6 or more feet away from each other.”

covid19scenario-132-50.sentence: Also, across much of the United States, open water venues are only beginning to thaw or are still very cold, which presents the potential for hypothermia if you’re swimming for too long.

covid19scenario-132-51.sentence: Proceed with caution or find alternative means of working out at home.

covid19scenario-132-52.sentence: U.S. Masters Swimming has canceled Spring Nationals and is recommending LMSCs and clubs not to have events until at least May 10.

covid19scenario-132-55.sentence: “We should have been [canceling large gatherings] sooner probably.” The reason is because of this particular virus’s highly contagious nature.

covid19scenario-132-56.sentence: “We are now fairly certain people are contagious before they ever have symptoms, so they are spreading that virus all over the place before they have any symptoms.

covid19scenario-132-57.sentence: All it takes is a couple of people in an environment in close contact like that” to widen the pandemic, Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-58.sentence: “The average person is spreading the virus to 2.5 more people.

covid19scenario-132-59.sentence: If you put people in an environment like a large gathering and then everyone goes home, they take the virus back home with them and infect others in their community.”

covid19scenario-132-60.sentence: This creates an ongoing cycle of transmission and infection that becomes very difficult to manage.

covid19scenario-132-61.sentence: The CDC has also recommended a cancelation or postponement of all events with 50 or more people, and President Donald Trump went a step further and recommended avoiding gatherings of more than 10 people.

covid19scenario-132-62.sentence: Many Masters meets and open water swims, as well as workouts, easily surpass those totals.

covid19scenario-132-63.sentence: What does it mean to ‘flatten the curve?’

covid19scenario-132-64.sentence: “You keep hearing people talk about ‘flattening the curve,’” Lavin says, referring to a means of reducing the catastrophic potential of COVID-19.

covid19scenario-132-65.sentence: “Part of the purpose of that is to reduce cases a bit, but it’s also to slow the spread so that hospitals will be able to handle patients.

covid19scenario-132-66.sentence: If we keep the spread down below the number of hospital beds and ICU beds, we can provide excellent treatment and more people will live.

covid19scenario-132-67.sentence: If it gets above the number of available hospital beds and ICU beds and doctors and nurses, then we provide poor treatment.”

covid19scenario-132-68.sentence: In addition, the strain on frontline caregivers is significant and grows with each additional transmission.

covid19scenario-132-69.sentence: “Healthcare workers are at greater risk” of infection themselves when they are overwhelmed with patients, Lavin says.

covid19scenario-132-70.sentence: “When they’re tired, they can’t keep up” with safety protocols, such as changing masks and gowns as frequently as they should.

covid19scenario-132-71.sentence: “When people get tired, they make mistakes.”

covid19scenario-132-72.sentence: And if a whole rush of people become ill all at once, that also leads to some difficult decisions for health care workers about who should receive lifesaving care and who might have to go without in times of limited resources.

covid19scenario-132-73.sentence: “Right now, we don’t have enough people or protective gear” to respond adequately to a mass-infection situation, she says.

covid19scenario-132-74.sentence: Therefore, it’s critical that we flatten the curve by following CDC guidelines and reducing person-to-person contact.

covid19scenario-132-76.sentence: Wash your hands frequently, particularly after you’ve been in a public space or after blowing your nose, sneezing, or coughing.

covid19scenario-132-77.sentence: Wash with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds each time.

covid19scenario-132-78.sentence: If soap is not available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60 percent alcohol.

covid19scenario-132-79.sentence: Avoid touching your face, particularly your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.

covid19scenario-132-80.sentence: Avoid close contact with people who are sick or who may have been exposed to the virus.

covid19scenario-132-81.sentence: Stay at least 6 feet away from others.

covid19scenario-132-82.sentence: These recommendations are particularly important for those who are at higher risk of infection, including older adults and those with a chronic medical condition such as heart disease, diabetes, and lung disease.

covid19scenario-132-84.sentence: If you develop symptoms or think you may have been exposed to the virus, call your healthcare provider for advice.

segment-0.sentence: Fact check: An alkaline diet won't kill the coronavirus

segment-1.sentence: The claim: An alkaline diet will help beat the coronavirus

segment-2.sentence: False claims and misinformation about coronavirus cures have circulated on social media as people search for hope and good news during the pandemic.

segment-3.sentence: One viral claim about alkaline diets – eliminating foods that are high in acidity to change the body's pH levels – has been shared on various occasions, and has also been debunked multiple times.

segment-4.sentence: A claim posted on Facebook alleged that the pH of the coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5, and "all we need to do, to beat coronavirus," is eat alkaline foods above the pH levels of the virus.

segment-5.sentence: The pH of the coronavirus

segment-6.sentence: The post cited research from the Journal of Virology from the American Society for Microbiology.

segment-7.sentence: Though an article about a coronavirus and pH was published in the journal in April 1991, the abstract makes it clear that the study was about a different coronavirus, the coronavirus mouse hepatitis virus type 4, or MHV4.

segment-8.sentence: The journal doesn't claim that the MHV4 virus has a specific pH level or range.

segment-9.sentence: Rather, the study looks at what happens when mice or rat cells are infected with MHV4 at pH levels ranging from 5.5 to 8.5.

segment-10.sentence: The idea behind the benefits of an alkaline diet claim is that increasing the body's pH levels will create an environment that's deadly to the virus.

segment-11.sentence: That is incorrect.

segment-12.sentence: The study cited in the post is unrelated to the new coronavirus, because COVID-19 was unknown until the current outbreak.

segment-13.sentence: The body regulates pH levels, meaning that diets don't change the pH levels of blood cells or tissues.

segment-14.sentence: An analysis by the MD Anderson Center about the relationship between alkaline diets and pH levels explained that a dietary change may result in a pH shift in saliva or urine, because these are waste products, but "there’s no way you could ever eat enough that it really impacts your blood."

segment-15.sentence: Alkaline foods and the coronavirus

segment-16.sentence: Eating more alkaline foods is not a proven preventive measure or cure for the coronavirus.

segment-17.sentence: There are no established or approved preventive measures or treatments for COVID-19.

segment-18.sentence: Though a healthy diet can help strengthen an immune system, there is no proof that an alkaline diet specifically is beneficial.

segment-19.sentence: The Facebook post incorrectly states the pH levels of some of the listed foods.

segment-20.sentence: The post listed lemons with a pH of 9.9 and limes with a pH of 8.2, when they both have a pH level of 2 to 3.

segment-21.sentence: Donald Schaffner, a food science specialist, told The Associate Press, "These pH values for these foods are completely wrong," and people can eat these foods if they want, but the best way to prevent getting sick is to stay away from other people.

segment-22.sentence: Our rating: False

segment-23.sentence: The claim that an alkaline diet will help beat the coronavirus is FALSE.

segment-24.sentence: The claim that coronavirus has a pH level of 5.5 to 8.5 cited a study from 1991 about a different coronavirus, not the one that causes COVID-19.

segment-25.sentence: The post misinterpreted the findings of that study.

segment-26.sentence: The idea that alkaline foods will help beat the coronavirus is also false.

segment-27.sentence: There are no confirmed preventive measures or cures for COVID-19.

segment-28.sentence: Though a healthy diet can help strengthen immune systems, there is not enough of an effect to stop the coronavirus.

segment-0.sentence: ‘Cold weather kills coronavirus’ and 13 other COVID-19 myths you may be falling for

segment-1.sentence: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.

segment-2.sentence: (WWLP) – The COVID-19 outbreak is a global pandemic.

segment-3.sentence: And with that, comes a lot of false information on the internet.

segment-4.sentence: 22News has been vigilant in separating fact from fiction when it comes to coronavirus, both nationally and locally.

segment-5.sentence: There are many myths about COVID-19 that have been circulating through social media — here are some of the most common ones, from the World Health Organization.

segment-6.sentence: Myth #1: Cold weather kills the novel coronavirus

segment-7.sentence: Truth: The CDC and the WHO have said this from the start: the most effective way to protect yourself from COVID-19 is with frequent handwashing with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer with at least 60 percent alcohol.

segment-8.sentence: The WHO says there is "no reason to believe cold weather can kill the new coronavirus," or other diseases, for that matter.

segment-9.sentence: Myth #2: COVID-19 cannot be transmitted in hotter, more humid climates

segment-10.sentence: Truth: Protective measures, like proper handwashing and social distancing, need to be taken no matter where you live.

segment-11.sentence: COVID-19 can be transmitted anywhere, regardless of how hot or humid the air is.

segment-12.sentence: Myth #3: Taking a hot bath prevents you from getting COVID-19

segment-13.sentence: Truth: This myth has been stemming from the false idea that cold and hot temperatures can kill the virus.

segment-14.sentence: Just like the cold weather and hot and humid climate myths, this is not true.

segment-15.sentence: Your body temperature stays relatively stable even when you take an extremely hot bath.

segment-16.sentence: This just leaves you with a risk of a burn.

segment-17.sentence: Still, the best way to prevent getting COVID-19 is to wash your hands often.

segment-18.sentence: This prevents viruses on your hands from infecting you when you touch your face.

segment-19.sentence: Myth #4: Coronavirus can be transmitted through mosquito bites

segment-20.sentence: Truth: As temperatures continue to warm as we dive into spring, mosquitoes will become more common again in Western Massachusetts.

segment-21.sentence: That typically brings a risk of Eastern Equine Encephalitis (EEE) and West Nile Virus, but the increasing population of mosquitoes does not create another channel in which you can get COVID-19.

segment-22.sentence: From the WHO, "there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that the new coronavirus could be transmitted by mosquitoes."

segment-23.sentence: This is because the new coronavirus is spread primarily through droplets when someone with the coronavirus sneezes or coughs.

segment-24.sentence: This is why social distancing and frequent hand washing is so important.

segment-25.sentence: Myth #5: Hand dryers are effective in killing the new coronavirus

segment-26.sentence: Truth: The heat from a hand dryer alone is not enough to kill the new coronavirus.

segment-27.sentence: However, in combination with washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, this method is very effective.

segment-28.sentence: You can also dry your hands after using paper towels, or instead use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.

segment-29.sentence: Myth #6: UV lamps kill the new coronavirus

segment-30.sentence: Truth: It’s too soon to tell whether UV light is an effective way to kill the new coronavirus, and the World Health Organization does not suggest its use.

segment-31.sentence: It should especially not be used on hands or your body as it can cause irritation.

segment-32.sentence: UV light has been known to kill the flu virus, however.

segment-33.sentence: Myth #7: Thermal scanners can detect everyone who is infected with coronavirus

segment-34.sentence: Truth: Thermal scanners, like thermometers, can detect people who have a higher-than-normal body temperature due to infection from COVID-19.

segment-35.sentence: But not everyone who is infected with the coronavirus has a fever yet.

segment-36.sentence: According to the WHO, "it takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and develop a fever."

segment-37.sentence: (WHO)

segment-38.sentence: Myth #8: Spraying alcohol and chlorine all over yourself kills the coronavirus

segment-39.sentence: Truth: This will not cure you of COVID-19 if it has already entered your body.

segment-40.sentence: Spraying alcohol and chlorine all over your body can be harmful if it gets into your eyes or mouth.

segment-41.sentence: The World Health Organization says they both can be used to disinfect surfaces, however.

segment-42.sentence: Myth #9: Getting a pneumonia vaccine protects against COVID-19

segment-43.sentence: Truth: The WHO says, "vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and Haemophilus influenza type B vaccine, do not provide protection against the new coronavirus."

segment-44.sentence: COVID-19 is a respiratory infection, yes, but it requires its own vaccine, which is in the testing phase right now.

segment-45.sentence: Myth #10: Rinsing your nose, and gargling, with saline solution helps prevent COVID-19 infection

segment-46.sentence: Truth: The World Health Organization says there is some evidence that regularly rinsing your nose with saline can help you get over the common cold more quickly.

segment-47.sentence: But this does not apply to COVID-19, and other respiratory infections.

segment-48.sentence: The same applies to gargling a saline solution.

segment-49.sentence: Myth #11: Eating garlic helps prevent COVID-19 infection

segment-50.sentence: Truth: There is no scientific evidence that eating garlic prevents you from being infected with the novel coronavirus.

segment-51.sentence: However, according to the National Institutes of Health, it does have some antimicrobial properties.

segment-52.sentence: Myth #12: The coronavirus only affects older people, and not younger people

segment-53.sentence: Truth: The World Health Organization says people of all ages need to take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19.

segment-54.sentence: The best ways are frequent hand washing, the use of hand sanitizer, and social distancing.

segment-55.sentence: However, people who are older are more vulnerable to becoming severely ill with the new coronavirus.

segment-56.sentence: People with preexisting conditions are also at an increased risk for more severe complications, such as people with heart disease, diabetes, and lung disease.

segment-57.sentence: Myth #13: Antibiotics prevent and treat COVID-19

segment-58.sentence: Truth: Antibiotics are used to fight bacteria, not viruses, which is what COVID-19 is.

segment-59.sentence: This myth may have stemmed from the fact some people who are hospitalized for coronavirus have received antibiotics, but that’s because bacterial "co-infections" are possible with COVID-19, according to the WHO.

segment-60.sentence: The antibiotic does not treat the virus itself.

segment-61.sentence: Myth #14: There are medicines to prevent and treat coronavirus

segment-62.sentence: Truth: The World Health Organization is helping with research and development efforts to find treatments for coronavirus, however, they are still under investigation, and must be tested through clinical trials.

segment-63.sentence: Right now, there is no medication recommended to prevent or treat COVID-19.

segment-64.sentence: You can use medication to relieve symptoms, but those with severe symptoms from coronavirus should seek help from a medical professional.

segment-0.sentence: New coronavirus threat galvanizes scientists

segment-1.sentence: Barely 1 month after Chinese health authorities reported the first cases of a mysterious new pneumonia in the city of Wuhan, the world may be on the cusp of a new pandemic.

segment-2.sentence: As

segment-3.sentence: Science

segment-4.sentence: went to press, the number of confirmed cases of the novel coronavirus, dubbed 2019-nCoV, had shot up to more than 4500, most of them in mainland China but more than 80 in 17 other countries and territories.

segment-5.sentence: China has quarantined 35 million people in Wuhan and several other cities in a desperate attempt to slow the spread of the virus.

segment-6.sentence: But as the case numbers keep soaring, the realization has set in that it may be too late to have much impact.

segment-7.sentence: Even seasoned epidemiologists are astonished at the virus's dizzying spread.

segment-8.sentence: Early estimates of the number of infected people—thought to far exceed the number of confirmed cases—became obsolete overnight.

segment-9.sentence: "Our original results are NO LONGER VALID," University of Hong Kong epidemiologist Gabriel Leung tweeted on 22 January, 1 day after his group had posted its first mathematical model of the epidemic.

segment-10.sentence: Leung is now estimating that Wuhan alone had 43,590 infections by 25 January—and that the number is doubling every 6 days.

segment-11.sentence: "How widespread does this go?"

segment-12.sentence: asks Marion Koopmans, a virologist at Erasmus Medical Center.

segment-13.sentence: "This deserves our full attention."

segment-14.sentence: Early this week, the World Health Organization (WHO) had not yet declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), the loudest alarm the agency can sound.

segment-15.sentence: In meetings on 22 and 23 January, a special WHO committee that includes Koopmans was divided on whether a PHEIC was warranted, in part because there was no evidence the disease was spreading between people outside of China.

segment-16.sentence: But by 28 January, several countries had reported local human-to-human transmission, which may change the equation.

segment-17.sentence: Get the latest issue of

segment-18.sentence: Science

segment-19.sentence: delivered right to you!

segment-20.sentence: So far 2019-nCoV appears to be milder than its cousin, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which had a mortality rate of 10%.

segment-21.sentence: Only 106 deaths have been recorded to date.

segment-22.sentence: But hundreds more people are seriously ill, and their fate is unclear.

segment-23.sentence: And countless other questions remain.

segment-24.sentence: Scientists don't know how long the incubation period lasts or whether infected people who show no symptoms can transmit the virus.

segment-25.sentence: China's state-run news agency Xinhua reported on 26 January that a seemingly healthy man appeared to have infected "a few colleagues."

segment-26.sentence: If asymptomatic people frequently infect others, it could vastly complicate efforts to contain 2019-nCoV.

segment-27.sentence: The virus's explosive spread has been met by an unprecedented rush by scientists to uncover its origins, find treatments, and develop vaccines that could save millions of lives if the world really does face a pandemic.

segment-28.sentence: Here are some of the ways researchers are attempting to better understand 2019-nCoV and reduce its harm.

segment-29.sentence: Where Did the Virus Come From?

segment-30.sentence: Almost certainly from animals, but when and how are mysteries.

segment-31.sentence: Genetic analyses are starting to yield some clues.

segment-32.sentence: Chinese researchers first shared a genomic sequence of 2019-nCoV on 11 January.

segment-33.sentence: Labs in China and abroad have since announced nearly three dozen additional sequences of the virus—"a stellar job," Koopmans says.

segment-34.sentence: A team led by Shi Zheng-Li of the Wuhan Institute of Virology reported on 23 January that 2019-nCoV's sequence was 96.2% identical to that of a bat coronavirus and 79.5% identical to the SARS coronavirus.

segment-35.sentence: That doesn't mean 2019-nCoV jumped directly from bats to humans, says evolutionary biologist Kristian Andersen of Scripps Research.

segment-36.sentence: SARS, for example, probably moved from bats to civets—sold as a delicacy in many markets—to humans.

segment-37.sentence: From the start, the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan—which sold mammals as well as fish—was considered a likely source of the outbreak because most of the early patients had visited it.

segment-38.sentence: On 27 January, Xinhua reported that researchers have found evidence of the new coronavirus in 33 of 585 environmental samples taken at the market on 1 January—the day it was closed—and on 12 January.

segment-39.sentence: They all came from the western end, which had a concentration of booths selling wildlife.

segment-40.sentence: That indicates the market played a role in spreading the virus, says Daniel Lucey, an infectious disease specialist at Georgetown University—but he says other data suggest it wasn't the origin.

segment-41.sentence: The first known patient became ill on 1 December 2019 and had no links to the market, according to a paper published by Chinese researchers in

segment-42.sentence: The Lancet

segment-43.sentence: on 24 January that offered details about the first 41 patients in Wuhan.

segment-44.sentence: In that group, 12 others also had no links to the market.

segment-45.sentence: Lucey contends the virus was already circulating silently among humans before it contaminated the seafood market, possibly by infected animals, humans, or both.

segment-46.sentence: The genomic data cannot pinpoint the origin, but they do show that the jump from animals to humans happened recently, Koopmans says.

segment-47.sentence: An analysis of the first 30 publicly posted sequences shows they differ from each other by no more than seven nucleotides (see graphic, right).

segment-48.sentence: Using these differences and presumed mutation rates, several groups have calculated that the virus began to spread around mid-November 2019—which supports the thesis that spread may have occurred before any of the cases linked to the market.

segment-49.sentence: One group put the origin of the outbreak as early as 18 September 2019.

segment-50.sentence: Bin Cao, a pulmonary specialist at Capital Medical University in Beijing and the corresponding author of

segment-51.sentence: The Lancet

segment-52.sentence: article, agrees the story is more complicated than many thought.

segment-53.sentence: "Now it seems clear that [the] seafood market is not the only origin of the virus," he wrote in an email to

segment-54.sentence: Science.

segment-55.sentence: "But to be honest, we still do not know where the virus came from now."

segment-56.sentence: Could Existing Drugs Work?

segment-57.sentence: It may take years to develop treatments specifically designed for 2019-nCoV, but researchers hope existing drugs can help.

segment-58.sentence: Wuhan's Jin Yintan Hospital has already launched a randomized, controlled trial of the anti-HIV drug combination of lopinavir and ritonavir, according to the report in

segment-60.sentence: The duo targets the protease enzyme used by HIV to copy itself, and it might thwart the coronavirus's protease as well.

segment-61.sentence: There's a precedent from the SARS outbreak: In a nonrandomized trial published in 2004, researchers saw an "apparent improved outcome" from the same two protease inhibitors, combined with a third drug, ribavirin, in SARS patients.

segment-62.sentence: Saudi Arabia is now conducting a trial with the same protease inhibitors, combined with interferon beta-1b, against Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), a coronavirus distantly related to SARS and 2019-nCoV that is occasionally spread by camels.

segment-63.sentence: But in a recent mouse study by Ralph Baric of the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, this cocktail had lackluster results against MERS.

segment-64.sentence: The same study showed better outcomes for remdesivir, an experimental drug made by Gilead and previously tested against Ebola that interferes with the viral polymerase enzyme.

segment-65.sentence: Remdesivir combined with interferon slowed viral replication in MERS-infected mice, and their lung function improved.

segment-66.sentence: "Remdesivir has had activity against every coronavirus we've tested, and I'd be surprised if it didn't have activity against" 2019-nCoV, says co-author Mark Denison, a virologist at Vanderbilt University.

segment-67.sentence: Development of entirely new treatments has started as well.

segment-68.sentence: U.S. biotech Regeneron is trying to identify monoclonal antibodies effective against 2019-nCoV, as it did previously for MERS and Ebola.

segment-69.sentence: The ideal treatment for 2019-nCoV may well be a drug like remdesivir plus monoclonal antibodies, Denison says.

segment-70.sentence: "The idea of using those in combination would have profoundly good prospects."

segment-71.sentence: Can Vaccines be Developed in Time?

segment-72.sentence: In the stock pandemic movie, scientists develop a vaccine just in time to save the world.

segment-73.sentence: In real life, new vaccines have never been developed fast enough to have a significant impact on an emerging virus.

segment-74.sentence: But in the case of 2019-nCoV, scientists are trying to work at Hollywood speed.

segment-75.sentence: The Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), a nonprofit formed in 2016 to fund and shepherd the development of new vaccines against emerging infectious diseases, has already given two companies and an academic group a total of $12.5 million to develop 2019-nCoV vaccines.

segment-76.sentence: The efforts began hours after Chinese researchers first published a viral sequence 3 weeks ago.

segment-77.sentence: One is a collaboration between the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) and U.S. biotech Moderna, which makes vaccines by converting viral sequences into messenger RNA (mRNA).

segment-78.sentence: (When injected into the body, mRNA causes the body to produce a viral protein, which triggers immune responses.)

segment-79.sentence: Moderna and NIAID have worked on a vaccine against MERS that consists of mRNA coding for a protein on the viral surface called the spike; in theory, all the team needs to do now is swap in the genetic sequence for 2019-nCoV's spike.

segment-80.sentence: CEPI funded a second company, Inovio, to produce vaccines that work in a similar way but are made of DNA.

segment-81.sentence: It, too, has a template for a 2019-nCoV vaccine: another candidate MERS vaccine that relies on the spike protein.

segment-82.sentence: CEPI's third grant went to researchers at the University of Queensland who are developing a vaccine made of viral proteins produced in cell cultures.

segment-83.sentence: Vaccine projects are also underway in mainland China, Hong Kong, Belgium, and Germany.

segment-84.sentence: Once candidate vaccines are available, researchers will test them in animals, then seek approval for phase I human trials.

segment-85.sentence: "We're building the airplane as we're flying," says Inovio CEO Joseph Kim.

segment-86.sentence: NIAID Director Anthony Fauci says the first clinical trial of the Moderna vaccine could start within 3 months.

segment-87.sentence: In the best-case scenario, Barney Graham, who leads the project for NIAID, says the Moderna vaccine could be ready for larger, real-world efficacy tests in humans by summer.

segment-88.sentence: Even if it works, mass-producing it or any other vaccine quickly would present a huge challenge.

segment-89.sentence: With luck, however, the outbreak will fade by summer, and with it the urgency of having a vaccine at the ready.

segment-90.sentence: "Nobody knows what's going to happen," says Stéphane Bancel, Moderna's CEO.

segment-91.sentence: "We're all hoping we'll never need this vaccine."

covid19scenario-47-0.sentence: -- Authorization Enables Broader Use of Remdesivir to Treat Hospitalized Patients with Severe COVID-19 Disease in the United States --

covid19scenario-47-1.sentence: -- Based on Patients’ Severity of Disease, Authorization Allows 5-day and 10-day Treatment Durations --

covid19scenario-47-2.sentence: FOSTER CITY, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- Gilead Sciences, Inc. (Nasdaq: GILD) today announced that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted emergency use authorization (EUA) for the investigational antiviral remdesivir to treat COVID-19.

covid19scenario-47-3.sentence: The EUA will facilitate broader use of remdesivir to treat hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 disease, enabling access to remdesivir at additional hospitals across the country.

covid19scenario-47-4.sentence: Allocation of the currently limited available supply of remdesivir will be made based on guiding principles that aim to maximize access for appropriate patients in urgent need of treatment, with direction from and in collaboration with the government.

covid19scenario-47-5.sentence: Remdesivir is authorized for the treatment of hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 disease.

covid19scenario-47-6.sentence: The optimal duration of treatment is still being studied in ongoing clinical trials.

covid19scenario-47-7.sentence: Under the EUA, both 5-day and 10-day treatment durations are suggested, based on the severity of disease.

covid19scenario-47-8.sentence: The authorization is temporary and does not take the place of the formal new drug application submission, review and approval process.

covid19scenario-47-9.sentence: The EUA allows for the distribution and emergency use of remdesivir only for the treatment of COVID-19; remdesivir remains an investigational drug and has not been approved by FDA.

covid19scenario-47-10.sentence: The U.S. government will coordinate the donation and distribution of remdesivir to hospitals in cities most heavily impacted by COVID-19.

covid19scenario-47-11.sentence: Given the severity of illness of patients appropriate for remdesivir treatment and the limited availability of drug supply, hospitals with intensive care units and other hospitals that the government deems most in need will receive priority in the distribution of remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-12.sentence: Gilead is working with the U.S. government on the logistics of remdesivir distribution and will provide more information when the company begins shipping the drug under the EUA.

covid19scenario-47-13.sentence: “This EUA opens the way for us to provide emergency use of remdesivir to more patients with severe symptoms of COVID-19,” said Daniel O’Day, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Gilead Sciences.

covid19scenario-47-14.sentence: “We will continue to work with partners across the globe to increase our supply of remdesivir while advancing our ongoing clinical trials to supplement our understanding of the drug’s profile.

covid19scenario-47-15.sentence: We are working to meet the needs of patients, their families and healthcare workers around the world with the greatest sense of urgency and responsibility.”

covid19scenario-47-16.sentence: The EUA is based on available data from two global clinical trials – the National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases’ placebo-controlled Phase 3 study in patients with moderate to severe symptoms of COVID-19, including those who were critically ill, and Gilead’s global Phase 3 study evaluating 5-day and 10-day dosing durations of remdesivir in patients with severe disease.

covid19scenario-47-17.sentence: Multiple additional clinical trials are ongoing to generate more data on the safety and efficacy of remdesivir as a treatment for COVID-19.

covid19scenario-47-19.sentence: The optimal dosing and duration of remdesivir for the treatment of COVID-19 is still unknown.

covid19scenario-47-20.sentence: Under this EUA, the 10-day dosing duration is suggested for patients requiring invasive mechanical ventilation and/or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), and the 5-day dosing duration is suggested for patients not requiring invasive mechanical ventilation and/or ECMO.

covid19scenario-47-21.sentence: If a patient on the 5-day dosing duration does not demonstrate clinical improvement after five days, treatment may be extended for up to five additional days (10 days total).

covid19scenario-47-22.sentence: As previously announced, Gilead has donated the entirety of its existing supply of finished and unfinished product to help address the urgent medical needs posed by this pandemic around the world.

covid19scenario-47-23.sentence: Assuming a 10-day treatment course, Gilead’s donation of 1.5 million individual doses of remdesivir equates to more than 140,000 treatment courses that will be provided at no cost to treat patients following potential emergency authorizations and regulatory approvals, including this EUA.

covid19scenario-47-24.sentence: Gilead will continue to support clinical trials, and expanded access and compassionate use programs for remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-25.sentence: In addition, Gilead will evaluate global allocation of supply on an ongoing basis using multiple, independent data sources to track the incidence and severity of the outbreak.

covid19scenario-47-26.sentence: An EUA is intended to provide availability of a medicine during an emergency; an EUA is not the equivalent of an FDA approval.

covid19scenario-47-27.sentence: See below for important information about remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-29.sentence: Gilead has aggressively implemented a multipronged approach to scale up production and rapidly build supply of the investigational antiviral remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-30.sentence: The company has invested significant capital, at risk, to meet the supply needs for clinical trials and emergency treatment programs, and to prepare for even greater demand following regulatory authorizations, should these occur.

covid19scenario-47-31.sentence: Through process refinements, Gilead has substantially shortened the manufacturing lead time from raw materials through to finished product.

covid19scenario-47-32.sentence: Gilead has also supplemented internal manufacturing with significant additional capacity from multiple partners in North America, Europe and Asia.

covid19scenario-47-33.sentence: The company has set a goal of producing at least 500,000 treatment courses by October, 1 million treatment courses by December 2020 and millions more in 2021, if required.

covid19scenario-47-34.sentence: These goals were based on a 10-day treatment course.

covid19scenario-47-35.sentence: Gilead now anticipates being able to cover significantly more patients based on the SIMPLE study results, which demonstrated similar efficacy with 5-day and 10-day dosing durations in patients with severe disease.

covid19scenario-47-36.sentence: Looking ahead, Gilead is building a geographically diverse consortium of leading pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturing companies to help reach and exceed manufacturing goals, and go above and beyond what any company could do individually.

covid19scenario-47-37.sentence: More details about these efforts are available here.

covid19scenario-47-39.sentence: Remdesivir (GS-5734™) is authorized for use under an EUA only for the treatment of patients with suspected or laboratory-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and severe COVID-19 disease.

covid19scenario-47-40.sentence: SARS-CoV-2 is the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 disease.

covid19scenario-47-41.sentence: Severe disease is defined as patients with an oxygen saturation (SpO2) ≤ 94% on room air or requiring supplemental oxygen or requiring mechanical ventilation or requiring extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

covid19scenario-47-42.sentence: Remdesivir is authorized for adult or pediatric patients who are admitted to a hospital and for whom use of an IV agent is clinically appropriate, as remdesivir must be administered intravenously.

covid19scenario-47-43.sentence: Remdesivir is an investigational drug that has not been approved by the FDA for any use.

covid19scenario-47-44.sentence: It is not yet known if remdesivir is safe and effective for the treatment of COVID-19.

covid19scenario-47-45.sentence: There are limited clinical data available for remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-46.sentence: Serious and unexpected adverse events may occur that have not been previously reported with remdesivir use.

covid19scenario-47-47.sentence: Warnings: In clinical studies with remdesivir, infusion-related reactions and liver transaminase elevations have been observed.

covid19scenario-47-48.sentence: Remdesivir should not be used in patients who are hypersensitive to any ingredient of remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-49.sentence: If signs and symptoms of a clinically significant infusion reaction occur, immediately discontinue administration of remdesivir and initiate appropriate treatment.

covid19scenario-47-50.sentence: Patients should have appropriate clinical and laboratory monitoring to aid in early detection of any potential adverse events.

covid19scenario-47-51.sentence: Monitor renal and hepatic function prior to initiating and daily during therapy with remdesivir; additionally monitor serum chemistries and hematology daily during therapy.

covid19scenario-47-52.sentence: The decision to continue or discontinue remdesivir therapy after development of an adverse event should be made based on the clinical risk benefit assessment for the individual patient.

covid19scenario-47-53.sentence: Healthcare providers and/or their designee are responsible for mandatory FDA MedWatch reporting of all medication errors and serious adverse events or deaths occurring during remdesivir treatment and considered to be potentially attributable to remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-54.sentence: These events must be reported within 7 calendar days from the onset of the event.

covid19scenario-47-55.sentence: MedWatch adverse event reports can be submitted to FDA online at www.fda.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088.

covid19scenario-47-56.sentence: This is not all of the important information for remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-57.sentence: The FDA has authorized distribution of this medicine with accompanying Fact Sheets, which can be accessed at www.gilead.com/remdesivir.

covid19scenario-47-58.sentence: Healthcare providers should review the Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers for more information on the authorized use of remdesivir and mandatory requirements of the EUA.

covid19scenario-47-59.sentence: The distribution of remdesivir has been authorized only for the treatment of COVID-19.

covid19scenario-47-60.sentence: It is not authorized for the treatment of any other viruses or pathogens.

covid19scenario-47-61.sentence: Information from the FDA about the FDA-authorized emergency use of remdesivir is available at https://www.fda.gov/emergency-preparedness-and-response/mcm-legal-regulatory-and-policy-framework/emergency-use-authorization.

covid19scenario-47-63.sentence: Gilead Sciences, Inc. is a research-based biopharmaceutical company that discovers, develops and commercializes innovative medicines in areas of unmet medical need.

covid19scenario-47-64.sentence: The company strives to transform and simplify care for people with life-threatening illnesses around the world.

covid19scenario-47-65.sentence: Gilead has operations in more than 35 countries worldwide, with headquarters in Foster City, California.

covid19scenario-47-67.sentence: This press release includes forward-looking statements, within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, that are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors.

covid19scenario-47-68.sentence: Remdesivir is an investigational agent that has not been approved by the FDA, and it has not been demonstrated to be safe or effective for any use, including for the treatment of COVID-19.

covid19scenario-47-69.sentence: There is the possibility of unfavorable results from ongoing and additional clinical trials involving remdesivir and the possibility that Gilead may be unable to complete one or more of such trials in the currently anticipated timelines or at all.

covid19scenario-47-70.sentence: Further, it is possible that Gilead may make a strategic decision to discontinue development of remdesivir or that FDA and other regulatory agencies may not approve remdesivir, and any marketing approvals, if granted, may have significant limitations on its use.

covid19scenario-47-75.sentence: These and other risks are described in detail in Gilead’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2019, as filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

covid19scenario-47-77.sentence: For more information about remdesivir, please see the Emergency Use Authorization Fact Sheets available at www.gilead.com/remdesivir.
