segment-0.sentence: VERA FILES FACT CHECK: A high-alkaline diet DOES NOT ‘defeat’ COVID-19

segment-1.sentence: Over 2,200 netizens on Facebook (FB) have shared a photo of a printed flier claiming that eating food with high alkaline content can "defeat" COVID-19.

segment-2.sentence: It recommended several fruits and vegetables supposedly "more alkaline" or "above the pH level" of SARS-CoV-2, the virus behind the disease.

segment-3.sentence: The information is inaccurate.

segment-4.sentence: "Viruses themselves do not have pH levels, because they are not water-based solutions," a group of health experts convened by international nonprofit organization Meedan stated in their COVID-19 Expert Database website.

segment-5.sentence: According to Oxford University’s

segment-6.sentence: Lexico,

segment-7.sentence: a solution is considered water-based if its "medium or main ingredient" is water.

segment-8.sentence: The pH scale is used to determine if a water-based solution is acidic (pH level of below 7), neutral (pH level of 7), or basic, oftentimes called alkaline (pH level of above 7).

segment-9.sentence: Eating more alkaline food does not affect blood pH but may affect a person’s saliva and urine pH levels, said Meedan’s team of experts.

segment-10.sentence: However, "these changes are variable from person to person and will not prevent or cure COVID-19."

segment-11.sentence: Maria Carmela Taob, a faculty member of the Department of Food Science and Nutrition (DFSN) of the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, shared a similar sentiment.

segment-12.sentence: In an email to VERA Files, she said: "There is no evidence to support the claim that alkalizing food can cure coronavirus patients."

segment-13.sentence: Taob explained that a food’s designation -- whether acidic, neutral, or alkaline -- is based on the ash it leaves behind after being combusted under laboratory conditions.

segment-14.sentence: Meat, fish, poultry, eggs, cheese, and grains produce "acid-ash," while most fruits and vegetables except for prunes, plums, and cranberries generate "alkaline-ash."

segment-15.sentence: Coffee, tea, certain sweets, fats, and starches are considered neutral.

segment-16.sentence: The flier, which listed seven fruits, garlic, dandelion, and turmeric tea, assigned wrong pH level to each food, ranging from 7.4 to 22.7.

segment-17.sentence: In an April 5 FB post, Benelyn Dumelod, an associate professor from UP DFSN, disputed this, saying the maximum pH value of any "food or nonfood, living or nonliving" is 14.

segment-18.sentence: Below is a comparison of the foods’ pH values as declared in the flier, against their correct pH values according to several sources including Dumelod.

segment-19.sentence: None were alkaline, or had a pH level between 7.1 and 14.

segment-20.sentence: Both Taob and the experts at Meedan pointed out that a well-balanced diet -- including the consumption of a variety of fruits and vegetables -- can help support one’s immune system.

segment-21.sentence: Taob, however, stressed that preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus relies heavily on "physical distancing, wearing masks, frequent handwashing, general hygiene, environmental sanitation, and physical activity."

segment-22.sentence: As far as the World Health Organization (WHO) is concerned, there is still no drug or vaccine proven to cure or prevent one from acquiring COVID-19.

segment-23.sentence: Clinical trials, however, are currently being performed in several parts of the world.

segment-24.sentence: The viral flier, which bore the title "Goodbye Corona Virus!

segment-25.sentence: ", also made false claims on what a person should do on a daily basis to be able to defeat the virus, advising the consumption of eggs and Vitamin C and E, getting sunlight in the morning, and drinking warm water daily.

segment-26.sentence: In an email to VERA Files, WHO Philippines said that "consuming eggs, exposure to sunlight, warm meals and vitamins daily do not kill the coronavirus."

segment-27.sentence: The symptoms listed in the flier indicating "if a person has COVID-19" are also misleading.

segment-28.sentence: While dry cough and fever are listed by WHO as common symptoms of the disease, sore throat and the loss of the sense of smell and taste are "less common" and may affect some patients only.

segment-29.sentence: Shortness of breath, on the other hand, is developed by "seriously-ill" individuals, which is just around one of every five COVID-19 patients, added the WHO’s list of symptoms.

segment-30.sentence: The earliest retrievable online copy of the flier carrying the false claims was uploaded last April 16 on Twitter.

segment-31.sentence: It got over 41,000 retweets and 53,700 likes, and has received comments from netizens pointing out the disinformation.

segment-21.sentence: Fact: Bacteria that causes food-borne illness can be destroyed by exposing it to high temperatures during the cooking process.

segment-22.sentence: The same can be said of some other microorganisms, too.

segment-23.sentence: But contrary to what you might have heard, neither taking a hot bath nor drying your hands with a hair dryer set on high heat will kill the coronavirus — either inside or outside of your body.

segment-24.sentence: The best way to keep surfaces in your environment clean is to wipe them down frequently with germ-killing aerosol sprays and antiseptic wipes.

segment-25.sentence: And washing your hands with soap and water — properly and frequently — is still the most important thing you can do to help prevent the spread of both coronaviruses and other infectious diseases.

segment-26.sentence: If you actually

segment-27.sentence: have

segment-28.sentence: the coronavirus, though, the best thing you can do is stay at home.

segment-29.sentence: Take care of yourself there until the infection has run its course, or until your symptoms become severe enough that you need to seek medical attention.

segment-30.sentence: "There is no existing treatment right now that can actually kill the virus," says Chemaly.

segment-31.sentence: "At this point, we can only treat the symptoms.

segment-32.sentence: That’s why it’s so important to do everything you can to help slow the spread of COVID-19 — that includes staying home, practicing social distancing and practicing good hand hygiene."

segment-33.sentence: Myth #3: COVID-19 is not as bad as the flu.

segment-34.sentence: Fact: COVID-19 is different from the flu in several important ways.

segment-35.sentence: First, the 2019 novel coronavirus appears to be more contagious.

segment-36.sentence: A single individual can infect more people.

segment-37.sentence: Second, symptoms of the flu tend to come on suddenly, then get worse within a day or two.

segment-38.sentence: Symptoms of COVID-19 can be mild and much more gradual, building up over several days or even weeks.

segment-39.sentence: That means people may be spreading germs over a longer period of time and not even realize it.

segment-40.sentence: Third, while most flu-related deaths are caused by secondary infections (such as pneumonia) or other complications, most deaths stemming from COVID-19 are caused by the body’s immune response to the virus itself.

segment-41.sentence: "The severe respiratory distress syndrome that some people develop as a result of infection makes it hard for them to breathe," explains Chemaly.

segment-42.sentence: "Finally, because we haven’t encountered this particular coronavirus before as a species, we have no vaccine, no effective anti-viral treatment, and no immunity, whereas we have all three of those for the flu," Chemaly says.

segment-43.sentence: Myth #4: Social distancing doesn’t apply to me.

segment-44.sentence: Fact: This myth has multiple variations: everything from, "I don’t have any symptoms, so I can still go out," to "my local or state government hasn’t put a stay-at-home order in place, so I don’t need to do it" to "there aren’t that many coronavirus cases in my area, so I don’t need to worry" – or even "I’ve been pretty good about staying home, so it’s OK if I make an exception and go out this time."

segment-45.sentence: But they’re all untrue.

segment-46.sentence: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, some people infected with the coronavirus may not show any symptoms.

segment-47.sentence: That means they might not even know they have COVID-19.

segment-48.sentence: "And just because someone doesn’t

segment-49.sentence: know

segment-50.sentence: they have the coronavirus, doesn’t mean they’re not contagious," says Chemaly.

segment-51.sentence: "They could still easily be spreading it around: whether by spending time in close contact with other people or by touching things like doorknobs and faucet handles.

segment-52.sentence: That’s why social distancing is so critical."

segment-53.sentence: That’s also why no city, part of town or neighborhood can be considered "safe," even if few confirmed cases have been reported there yet.

segment-54.sentence: The lag in testing means the true number of cases is still unknown, so a lot of infected people might be walking around in public, not realizing they’re spreading the virus.

segment-55.sentence: "Don’t underestimate your personal risk for coronavirus — or put others at risk — based on a false claim," says Chemaly.

segment-0.sentence: Study: Hydroxychloroquine Doesn't Help COVID-19 Inpatients

segment-1.sentence: Want to Make an Appointment or Need Patient Information?

segment-4.sentence: PITTSBURGH – UPMC and University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine physician-scientists contributed to a national study published today in the

segment-5.sentence: Journal of the American Medical Association

segment-6.sentence: (JAMA) reporting findings that "do not support" the use of hydroxychloroquine for the treatment of adult patients hospitalized with COVID-19.

segment-7.sentence: The Outcomes Related to COVID-19 treated with Hydroxychloroquine among In-patients with symptomatic Disease (ORCHID) study found that, when compared to inactive placebo, hydroxychloroquine did not significantly improve clinical outcomes of patients hospitalized for respiratory illness related to COVID-19.

segment-8.sentence: The study, which was funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) of the National Institutes of Health, was conducted at 34 hospitals in the Prevention and Early Treatment of Acute Lung Injury (PETAL) Clinical Trials Network, which includes UPMC hospitals.

segment-9.sentence: "Our study—which is supported by the gold-standard in medical research: a blinded, randomized clinical trial—puts to rest any lingering hope that hydroxychloroquine is an effective treatment against COVID-19," said study co-author Donald Yealy, M.D., UPMC’s senior medical director and chair of emergency medicine at Pitt and UPMC.

segment-10.sentence: "This allows us to focus our research and funding toward other, more promising treatments while reinforcing the public health tenants of mask-wearing, physical distancing and hand hygiene to prevent the spread of this disease."

segment-11.sentence: Some laboratory studies suggested hydroxychloroquine can inhibit replication of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.

segment-12.sentence: Observational studies early in the COVID-19 pandemic suggested that the drug may have beneficial effects for patients with the disease, which sparked great enthusiasm for hydroxychloroquine as a potential treatment.

segment-13.sentence: However, clinical trials, which are considered the highest quality research studies for understanding the effect of a drug in patients, have failed to show beneficial effects of hydroxychloroquine for patients with COVID-19, the researchers said.

segment-14.sentence: "Hydroxychloroquine became a very commonly used medication for COVID-19 in the spring of 2020 without strong evidence that it would be beneficial," said the study’s lead investigator, Wesley H.

segment-15.sentence: Self, M.D., M.P.H., an emergency medicine physician and vice president for Clinical Research Networks and Strategy at Vanderbilt University Medical Center.

segment-16.sentence: "Therefore, we conducted a clinical trial with the strongest methods possible to provide high-quality information on whether hospitalized patients with COVID-19 should be treated with hydroxychloroquine," Self said.

segment-17.sentence: "Combined with other studies that showed similar findings, we believe this trial provides compelling data for clinicians to stop using hydroxychloroquine for hospitalized adults with COVID-19."

segment-18.sentence: Between April and June 2020, 479 patients hospitalized for respiratory illness from COVID-19 were enrolled in the ORCHID study, a blinded, placebo-controlled randomized clinical trial.

segment-19.sentence: Patients who were acutely ill and hospitalized with COVID-19 were treated with 10 doses of hydroxychloroquine or placebo over five days.

segment-20.sentence: The patient’s clinical status, including hospital discharge, oxygen use, mechanical ventilator use and death, was followed for a month after the medication was started.

segment-21.sentence: The study showed no evidence that hydroxychloroquine prevented death or helped patients recover from COVID-19 more quickly.

segment-22.sentence: One month after starting the study, 10.4% of patients treated with hydroxychloroquine and 10.6% of patients treated with placebo had died.

segment-23.sentence: In June the NHLBI halted the study after determining that hydroxychloroquine was not likely to be of benefit to hospitalized patients with COVID-19.

segment-24.sentence: Additional study authors from Pitt and UPMC are Derek Angus, M.D., M.P.H., and Alexandra Weissman, M.D., M.P.H. Other institutions contributing to this research are Intermountain Medical Center, University of Utah, Johns Hopkins University, University of California Los Angeles, Duke University, Massachusetts General Hospital, Wake Forest, University of Colorado, Montefiore Medical Center, Oregon Health and Sciences University, University of Washington, University of California San Francisco, University of Michigan, Harvard University, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and University of Massachusetts.

segment-25.sentence: This research was supported by NHLBI grants 3U01HL123009-06S1, U01HL123009, U01HL122998, U01HL123018, U01HL123023, U01HL123008, U01HL123031, U01HL123004, U01HL123027, U01HL123010, U01HL123033, U01HL122989, U01HL123022 and U01HL123020, as well as National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences grant 5UL1TR002243 and UL1TR001102.

segment-26.sentence: Sandoz, a Novartis division, supplied the hydroxychloroquine and placebo used in this trial.

covid19scenario-151-0.sentence: (CNN) As the novel coronavirus -- and panic about the coronavirus -- continues to spread around the world, so too are bogus claims, conspiracy theories and misinformation about the disease.

covid19scenario-151-1.sentence: There's so much inaccurate information floating around out there that the World Health Organization is calling it an "infodemic."

covid19scenario-151-2.sentence: In perhaps the clearest sign of the times, WHO has joined TikTok to help set the record straight.

covid19scenario-151-3.sentence: The myths exist both on the fringes of the internet and in more mainstream outlets.

covid19scenario-151-4.sentence: And while social media platforms are now taking steps to elevate credible information and remove content that could confuse people, they're fighting an uphill battle.

covid19scenario-151-5.sentence: Meanwhile, censorship and government mistrust in some countries have created a petri dish for misinformation to spread.

covid19scenario-151-6.sentence: Here's the truth about the new coronavirus.

covid19scenario-151-8.sentence: Reality: Don't believe everything you read on the internet.

covid19scenario-151-9.sentence: As the coronavirus outbreak turned into a full-fledged public health crisis, a fringe theory about the virus' origins started to take hold on the internet: that the virus didn't come from nature, but had instead been created in a lab.

covid19scenario-151-10.sentence: The rumors, which originated from unverified social media accounts and weren't supported by any credible evidence, got more elaborate as time went on.

covid19scenario-151-11.sentence: One version popularized outside China suggested that a Chinese lab had been secretly working on a bioweapon that got leaked.

covid19scenario-151-12.sentence: Another that gained traction among nationalistic parts of the Chinese social mediasphere suggested that the virus originated in the US -- and that many Americans thought to have died of the flu this season were actually killed by COVID-19.

covid19scenario-151-13.sentence: Scientists in both China and the West have widely dismissed these theories, though that hasn't stopped them from spreading.

covid19scenario-151-14.sentence: Experts are still trying to figure out the exact source of the virus, but research indicates that it likely originated in bats and was transmitted to an intermediate host before jumping to people -- just like its cousin that caused the 2003 SARS epidemic.

covid19scenario-151-15.sentence: Myth: Home remedies can cure or prevent the virus

covid19scenario-151-16.sentence: Reality: Garlic is good for you.

covid19scenario-151-18.sentence: And vitamin C. But despite what some corners of social media would have you believe, there's Garlic is good for you.

covid19scenario-151-20.sentence: And vitamin C. But despite what some corners of social media would have you believe, there's no evidence from the outbreak that eating garlic, sipping water every 15 minutes or taking vitamin C will protect people from the new coronavirus.

covid19scenario-151-21.sentence: Same goes for using essential oils, colloidal silver and steroids.

covid19scenario-151-22.sentence: Some posts have suggested that putting sesame oil on your body or spraying yourself with alcohol or chlorine will kill the virus.

covid19scenario-151-24.sentence: There are some chemical disinfectants , including bleach, 75% ethanol, peracetic acid and chloroform, that may kill the virus on surfaces.

covid19scenario-151-25.sentence: But if the virus is already in your body, putting those substances on your skin or under your nose won't kill it -- and can actually be dangerous.

covid19scenario-151-26.sentence: And this should go without saying, but please, please, do not ingest chemical disinfectants either.

covid19scenario-151-27.sentence: There's currently no cure for the novel coronavirus.

covid19scenario-151-28.sentence: And while research is underway, it could be more than a year before a vaccine becomes available.

covid19scenario-151-29.sentence: The best way to protect yourself right now is to do what you would every cold and flu season.

covid19scenario-151-30.sentence: Stay at least three feet away from anyone who may be infected.

covid19scenario-151-31.sentence: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.

covid19scenario-151-32.sentence: Cover your mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze with your elbow or a tissue that you throw away immediately after.

covid19scenario-151-33.sentence: And disinfect the objects and surfaces you touch.

covid19scenario-151-34.sentence: If you have symptoms that feel worse than a common cold, seek treatment early.

covid19scenario-151-35.sentence: Myth: Black people don't get coronavirus

covid19scenario-151-37.sentence: Any person who comes into close contact with someone who is infected is at risk for contracting the virus, according to the CDC.

covid19scenario-151-38.sentence: Take it from Dr. Jennifer Caudle, an African American family medicine physician and on-air health expert who has also been debunking coronavirus myths .

covid19scenario-151-39.sentence: Caudle said she worries that some people may not take proper precautions to protect themselves against the virus because they may have heard this myth.

covid19scenario-151-40.sentence: "Black people can get coronavirus, just like other people," she told CNN.

covid19scenario-151-41.sentence: Look no further than Africa, where the pandemic is gaining a foothold.

covid19scenario-151-42.sentence: So far, the virus hasn't spread in Africa as quickly as it has on some other continents.

covid19scenario-151-43.sentence: But numbers there are rising fast

covid19scenario-151-44.sentence: Ten African nations have reported nearly 100 coronavirus cases.

covid19scenario-151-45.sentence: Egypt has been the worst hit with at least 59 cases -- more than half of all confirmed cases on the continent.

covid19scenario-151-46.sentence: Myth: Everyone should wear a mask

covid19scenario-151-47.sentence: Reality: This one's a little trickier, and varies from country to country.

covid19scenario-151-48.sentence: Given the shortage of masks in the US and the resulting price-gouging , US officials have warned the public not to hoard masks, particularly N95 respirators, so that they remain available to those most at risk.

covid19scenario-151-49.sentence: Those who should wear masks are people who already have the new coronavirus and could potentially infect others, those caring for an infected patient in close settings and health care workers.

covid19scenario-151-50.sentence: Outside the US, the guidance around face masks is different.

covid19scenario-151-51.sentence: Authorities across Asia, which has now been dealing with the virus for months, have urged that people wear surgical masks particularly on public transportation or in other crowded places to prevent transmission of the virus.

covid19scenario-151-52.sentence: However, Hong Kong's health authority does say that N95 respirators are generally not recommended for use by the general public, given that wearing and removing it properly requires special training.

covid19scenario-151-53.sentence: To determine whether you need to wear a mask or not, it's best to check the latest guidance issues by your country's health authorities.

covid19scenario-151-54.sentence: Myth: Heat can kill the virus

covid19scenario-151-55.sentence: Reality: Hand dryers can't kill the virus, Hand dryers can't kill the virus, according to WHO .

covid19scenario-151-56.sentence: The organization also says that UV lamps shouldn't be used to sterilize hands or other areas of the body because the radiation can irritate skin.

covid19scenario-151-57.sentence: President Donald Trump has previously suggested that heat kills the virus and that because of this, the current outbreak will have dissipated by spring.

covid19scenario-151-58.sentence: Myth: The virus can be transmitted through mail

covid19scenario-151-59.sentence: Reality: Feel free to check your mail.

covid19scenario-151-60.sentence: Getting a letter or package from China won't put you at risk of contracting the virus, according to WHO

covid19scenario-151-61.sentence: Researchers are still studying exactly how the new coronavirus infects people, but judging by previous coronaviruses, it doesn't stay alive for long on objects and surfaces.

covid19scenario-151-62.sentence: Myth: Kids can't get the coronavirus

covid19scenario-151-63.sentence: Reality: Anyone of any age can get the new coronavirus, though older people and those with pre-existing medical conditions appear to be more vulnerable to serious infections.

covid19scenario-151-64.sentence: While most confirmed cases of the virus have occurred in adults, children have been infected too, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

covid19scenario-151-65.sentence: Myth: People who get the coronavirus will die

covid19scenario-151-66.sentence: Reality: Officials Officials estimate the death rate for the virus to be around 3% to 4% globally, based on the information they have, though they expect that number to fall.

covid19scenario-151-67.sentence: People who get coronavirus will typically get sick with a mild to moderate upper respiratory tract illness, similar to a common cold.

covid19scenario-151-68.sentence: Symptoms include a runny nose, cough, sore throat, headache and a fever that can last for a couple of days.

covid19scenario-151-69.sentence: Most of the time, symptoms will go away on their own.

covid19scenario-151-70.sentence: The disease can be fatal but those cases are rarer.

covid19scenario-151-71.sentence: For those with a weakened immune system, the elderly and the very young, there's a chance the virus could cause a lower, and much more serious, respiratory tract illness like pneumonia or bronchitis.

covid19scenario-151-72.sentence: Given that thousands of people have been infected and authorities are still struggling to contain the virus, though, even a 3% to 4% mortality rate is worrisome.

covid19scenario-151-73.sentence: CORRECTION: This story has been corrected to reflect the varied guidance around face masks in countries outside the US.

covid19scenario-145-0.sentence: A clinical hold on a potential treatment for COVID-19 is becoming political.

covid19scenario-145-1.sentence: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) placed a hold on the Emergency Use Authorization for convalescent plasma as a potential treatment for COVID-19 over what was described as a lack of robust data supporting its use.

covid19scenario-145-2.sentence: Some small studies have demonstrated the potential for convalescent plasma in treating COVID-19 patients, but there are also some contradictory studies as well.

covid19scenario-145-3.sentence: First reported by The New York Times, the hold was placed after senior U.S. public health policy officials in charge of the national COVID-19 response, including National Institutes of Health Director Francis Collins, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Director Anthony Fauci and Clifford Lane, NIAID deputy director, argued the emerging data was not strong enough to support approval under EUA.

covid19scenario-145-4.sentence: "The three of us are pretty aligned on the importance of robust data through randomized control trials, and that a pandemic does not change that," Lane told the Times, as reported by CNN.

covid19scenario-145-5.sentence: Convalescent plasma is collected from patients who have recovered from a virus such as the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19.

covid19scenario-145-6.sentence: The idea is that the plasma, which contains antibodies against the virus, will be administered into patients who are critically ill.

covid19scenario-145-7.sentence: In March, the FDA created a pathway with strict guidelines for physicians to use convalescent plasma on seriously ill COVID-19 patients.

covid19scenario-145-8.sentence: That pathway is still available for physicians to use should they deem it necessary, but the granting of a broader EUA is still up for debate – and that is not sitting well with President Donald Trump.

covid19scenario-145-9.sentence: During a press briefing Wednesday, Trump questioned whether or not the decision to withhold EUA was political, rather than clinical.

covid19scenario-145-10.sentence: “I hear great things about it ... that’s all I can tell you,” Trump said, according to CNBC.

covid19scenario-145-11.sentence: “It could be a political decision because you have a lot of people over there who don’t want to rush things because they want to do it after Nov. 3, and you’ve heard that one before.”

covid19scenario-145-12.sentence: Trump added that he heard convalescent plasma was “good” from “people at the FDA” and said it should be approved “if it’s good.” He stated that success rates from the use of convalescent plasma are “way over” 50% and urged approval of the plasma treatment.

covid19scenario-145-13.sentence: In July, the National Institute of Health updated its treatment guidelines which suggest there is “insufficient data” to support convalescent plasma as an approved treatment for COVID-19, CNBC said.

covid19scenario-145-14.sentence: That guideline could change as there are multiple convalescent plasma clinical studies being conducted across the globe.

covid19scenario-145-15.sentence: Takeda Pharmaceutical is known to be working on developing a treatment for COVID-19 from the blood of patients who have recovered.

covid19scenario-145-16.sentence: Takeda’s TAK-888 is an anti-SARS-CoV-2 polyclonal hyperimmune globulin currently in development to treat high-risk individuals with COVID-19.

covid19scenario-145-17.sentence: The state of New York, which was the U.S. epicenter for COVID-19 in the spring, initiated a clinical trial to study the efficacy of the blood-based treatment.

covid19scenario-145-18.sentence: This week, the U.S. Department of Defense awarded Plasma Technologies a $750,000 contract to scale up convalescent plasma as a potential COVID-19 treatment.

covid19scenario-145-19.sentence: The use of convalescent plasma has been studied in outbreaks of other respiratory infections, including the 2009-2010 H1N1 influenza virus pandemic, 2003 SARS-CoV-1 epidemic, and the 2012 MERS-CoV epidemic.

covid19scenario-145-20.sentence: “Although promising, convalescent plasma has not been shown to be effective in every disease studied.

covid19scenario-145-21.sentence: It is therefore important to determine through clinical trials, before routinely administering convalescent plasma to patients with COVID-19, that it is safe and effective to do so,” the FDA said in its guidance back in March.

segment-0.sentence: Denmark plans to cull its mink population after coronavirus mutation spreads to humans

segment-1.sentence: COPENHAGEN (Reuters) - Denmark will cull its mink population of up to 17 million after a mutation of the coronavirus found in the animals spread to humans, the prime minister said on Wednesday.

segment-2.sentence: Slideshow ( 2 images )

segment-3.sentence: Health authorities found virus strains in humans and in mink which showed decreased sensitivity against antibodies, potentially lowering the efficacy of future vaccines, Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said.

segment-4.sentence: "We have a great responsibility towards our own population, but with the mutation that has now been found, we have an even greater responsibility for the rest of the world as well," Frederiksen told a news conference.

segment-5.sentence: The findings, which have been shared with the World Health Organization and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, were based on laboratory tests by the State Serum Institute, the Danish authority dealing with infectious diseases.

segment-6.sentence: The head of the WHO’s emergencies programme, Mike Ryan, called on Friday for full-scale scientific investigations of the complex issue of humans - outside China - infecting mink which in turn transmitted the virus back to humans.

segment-7.sentence: "We have been informed by Denmark of a number of persons infected with coronavirus from mink, with some genetic changes in the virus," WHO said in a statement emailed to Reuters in Geneva.

segment-8.sentence: "The Danish authorities are investigating the epidemiological and virological significance of these findings."

segment-9.sentence: Authorities in Denmark said five cases of the new virus strain had been recorded on mink farms and 12 cases in humans, and that there were between 15 million and 17 million mink in the country.

segment-10.sentence: Outbreaks at mink farms have persisted in the Nordic country, the world’s largest producer of mink furs, despite repeated efforts to cull infected animals since June.

segment-11.sentence: Denmark’s police, army and home guard will be deployed to speed up the culling process, Frederiksen said.

segment-12.sentence: Christian Sonne, professor of Veterinary and Wildlife Medicine at Aarhus University, said in an email he believed culling the herd now as a precautionary measure was a sound decision and could prevent a future outbreak that would be more difficult to control.

segment-13.sentence: Sonne co-authored a letter published in the journal Science last week calling for the cull.

segment-14.sentence: "China, Denmark, and Poland should support and extend the immediate and complete ban of mink production," Sonne and his co-authors wrote last week.

segment-15.sentence: Tougher lockdown restrictions and intensified tracing efforts will be implemented to contain the virus in some areas of Northern Denmark, home to a large number of mink farms, authorities said.

segment-16.sentence: "The worst case scenario is a new pandemic, starting all over again out of Denmark," said Kare Molbak, director at the State Serum Institute.

segment-17.sentence: Minks have also been culled in the Netherlands and Spain after infections were discovered.

segment-18.sentence: Reporting by Nikolaj Skydsgaard and Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen; additional reporting by Stephanie Nebehay in Geneva and Michael Erman in Maplewood, N.J. Editing by Jon Boyle, Nick Macfie, Timothy Heritage and Tom Brown

covid19scenario-129-0.sentence: An ambulance crosses a deserted bridge in Wuhan, China, which has been cordoned off from the outside world.

covid19scenario-129-2.sentence: Barely 1 month after Chinese health authorities reported the first cases of a mysterious new pneumonia in the city of Wuhan, the world may be on the cusp of a new pandemic.

covid19scenario-129-3.sentence: As Science went to press, the number of confirmed cases of the novel coronavirus, dubbed 2019-nCoV, had shot up to more than 4500, most of them in mainland China but more than 80 in 17 other countries and territories.

covid19scenario-129-4.sentence: China has quarantined 35 million people in Wuhan and several other cities in a desperate attempt to slow the spread of the virus.

covid19scenario-129-5.sentence: But as the case numbers keep soaring, the realization has set in that it may be too late to have much impact.

covid19scenario-129-6.sentence: Even seasoned epidemiologists are astonished at the virus's dizzying spread.

covid19scenario-129-7.sentence: Early estimates of the number of infected people—thought to far exceed the number of confirmed cases—became obsolete overnight.

covid19scenario-129-8.sentence: “Our original results are NO LONGER VALID,” University of Hong Kong epidemiologist Gabriel Leung tweeted on 22 January, 1 day after his group had posted its first mathematical model of the epidemic.

covid19scenario-129-9.sentence: Leung is now estimating that Wuhan alone had 43,590 infections by 25 January—and that the number is doubling every 6 days.

covid19scenario-129-10.sentence: “How widespread does this go?” asks Marion Koopmans, a virologist at Erasmus Medical Center.

covid19scenario-129-12.sentence: Early this week, the World Health Organization (WHO) had not yet declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), the loudest alarm the agency can sound.

covid19scenario-129-13.sentence: In meetings on 22 and 23 January, a special WHO committee that includes Koopmans was divided on whether a PHEIC was warranted, in part because there was no evidence the disease was spreading between people outside of China.

covid19scenario-129-14.sentence: But by 28 January, several countries had reported local human-to-human transmission, which may change the equation.

covid19scenario-129-15.sentence: So far 2019-nCoV appears to be milder than its cousin, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which had a mortality rate of 10%.

covid19scenario-129-16.sentence: Only 106 deaths have been recorded to date.

covid19scenario-129-17.sentence: But hundreds more people are seriously ill, and their fate is unclear.

covid19scenario-129-19.sentence: Scientists don't know how long the incubation period lasts or whether infected people who show no symptoms can transmit the virus.

covid19scenario-129-20.sentence: China's state-run news agency Xinhua reported on 26 January that a seemingly healthy man appeared to have infected “a few colleagues.” If asymptomatic people frequently infect others, it could vastly complicate efforts to contain 2019-nCoV.

covid19scenario-129-21.sentence: The virus's explosive spread has been met by an unprecedented rush by scientists to uncover its origins, find treatments, and develop vaccines that could save millions of lives if the world really does face a pandemic.

covid19scenario-129-22.sentence: Here are some of the ways researchers are attempting to better understand 2019-nCoV and reduce its harm.

covid19scenario-129-23.sentence: Where Did the Virus Come From?

covid19scenario-129-24.sentence: Almost certainly from animals, but when and how are mysteries.

covid19scenario-129-25.sentence: Genetic analyses are starting to yield some clues.

covid19scenario-129-26.sentence: Chinese researchers first shared a genomic sequence of 2019-nCoV on 11 January.

covid19scenario-129-27.sentence: Labs in China and abroad have since announced nearly three dozen additional sequences of the virus—“a stellar job,” Koopmans says.

covid19scenario-129-28.sentence: A team led by Shi Zheng-Li of the Wuhan Institute of Virology reported on 23 January that 2019-nCoV's sequence was 96.2% identical to that of a bat coronavirus and 79.5% identical to the SARS coronavirus.

covid19scenario-129-29.sentence: That doesn't mean 2019-nCoV jumped directly from bats to humans, says evolutionary biologist Kristian Andersen of Scripps Research.

covid19scenario-129-30.sentence: SARS, for example, probably moved from bats to civets—sold as a delicacy in many markets—to humans.

covid19scenario-72-5.sentence: Acting DHS Secretary Chad Wolf told Fox News on Saturday that "we have no plans for a national lockdown or a national quarantine," calling that disinformation.

covid19scenario-72-7.sentence: Please do not pass it along.

covid19scenario-72-8.sentence: Use trusted local and federal government sources."

covid19scenario-72-13.sentence: "And I think in any time we face a situation like that, there's going to be kind of an explosion in information.

covid19scenario-72-14.sentence: And not all of that is going to be credible and accurate information."

covid19scenario-72-16.sentence: "So many people rely on it to communicate with friends and family members.

covid19scenario-72-17.sentence: And it's for many people a primary source of information," he says.

covid19scenario-72-18.sentence: "But at the same time, we know that social media can also be bombarded with inaccurate information."

covid19scenario-72-20.sentence: Some of the misinformation that spreads in times of crisis is less than harmful.

covid19scenario-72-21.sentence: There were rumors claiming sharks were swimming in the streets during Hurricane Florence — perhaps the inspiration for recent false claims that dolphins were spotted frolicking in the canals of Venice because the water was now clean due to a coronavirus-related lack of boat traffic.

covid19scenario-72-22.sentence: It's not clear where much of this material originates, although Trump administration officials have blamed foreign governments.

covid19scenario-72-23.sentence: "What we know — whether it's Russia, or whether it's other cyber actors... [is] they like to sow discord on any controversial issue," Wolf said on another Fox show.

covid19scenario-72-24.sentence: "So, it doesn't just have to be elections.

segment-1.sentence: Background

segment-2.sentence: Azithromycin, an antibiotic with potential antiviral and anti-inflammatory properties, has been used to treat COVID-19, but evidence from community randomised trials is lacking.

segment-3.sentence: We aimed to assess the effectiveness of azithromycin to treat suspected COVID-19 among people in the community who had an increased risk of complications.

segment-4.sentence: Methods

segment-5.sentence: In this UK-based, primary care, open-label, multi-arm, adaptive platform randomised trial of interventions against COVID-19 in people at increased risk of an adverse clinical course (PRINCIPLE), we randomly assigned people aged 65 years and older, or 50 years and older with at least one comorbidity, who had been unwell for 14 days or less with suspected COVID-19, to usual care plus azithromycin 500 mg daily for three days, usual care plus other interventions, or usual care alone.

segment-6.sentence: The trial had two coprimary endpoints measured within 28 days from randomisation: time to first self-reported recovery, analysed using a Bayesian piecewise exponential, and hospital admission or death related to COVID-19, analysed using a Bayesian logistic regression model.

segment-7.sentence: Eligible participants with outcome data were included in the primary analysis, and those who received the allocated treatment were included in the safety analysis.

segment-8.sentence: The trial is registered with ISRCTN, ISRCTN86534580.

segment-9.sentence: Findings

segment-10.sentence: The first participant was recruited to PRINCIPLE on April 2, 2020.

segment-11.sentence: The azithromycin group enrolled participants between May 22 and Nov 30, 2020, by which time 2265 participants had been randomly assigned, 540 to azithromycin plus usual care, 875 to usual care alone, and 850 to other interventions.

segment-12.sentence: 2120 (94%) of 2265 participants provided follow-up data and were included in the Bayesian primary analysis, 500 participants in the azithromycin plus usual care group, 823 in the usual care alone group, and 797 in other intervention groups.

segment-13.sentence: 402 (80%) of 500 participants in the azithromycin plus usual care group and 631 (77%) of 823 participants in the usual care alone group reported feeling recovered within 28 days.

segment-14.sentence: We found little evidence of a meaningful benefit in the azithromycin plus usual care group in time to first reported recovery versus usual care alone (hazard ratio 1·08, 95% Bayesian credibility interval [BCI] 0·95 to 1·23), equating to an estimated benefit in median time to first recovery of 0·94 days (95% BCI −0·56 to 2·43).

segment-15.sentence: The probability that there was a clinically meaningful benefit of at least 1·5 days in time to recovery was 0·23.

segment-16.sentence: 16 (3%) of 500 participants in the azithromycin plus usual care group and 28 (3%) of 823 participants in the usual care alone group were hospitalised (absolute benefit in percentage 0·3%, 95% BCI −1·7 to 2·2).

segment-17.sentence: There were no deaths in either study group.

segment-18.sentence: Safety outcomes were similar in both groups.

segment-19.sentence: Two (1%) of 455 participants in the azothromycin plus usual care group and four (1%) of 668 participants in the usual care alone group reported admission to hospital during the trial, not related to COVID-19.

segment-21.sentence: Our findings do not justify the routine use of azithromycin for reducing time to recovery or risk of hospitalisation for people with suspected COVID-19 in the community.

covid19scenario-115-1.sentence: When news of any new, fast-spreading virus starts making the rounds, two things happen: public panic ensues and misinformation starts to proliferate—and the new coronavirus has sparked both.

covid19scenario-115-2.sentence: In December 2019, an outbreak of a novel coronavirus—now known as SAR-CoV-2 (initially named 2019-nCoV)—was detected in Wuhan, a city in Central China's Hubei province.

covid19scenario-115-3.sentence: Since then, more than 9.6 million people worldwide have developed the infection, and at least 490,000 people have died, according to Johns Hopkins University's real-time tracker, which maps confirmed cases of the illness we now know as COVID-19.

covid19scenario-115-9.sentence: (Seriously—the searches for "bat soup" in Google Trends truly skyrocketed).

covid19scenario-115-10.sentence: Where exactly did the "bat soup" claim come from?

covid19scenario-115-11.sentence: According to Foreign Policy, a video recently surfaced of a Chinese woman holding an entire bat with chopsticks, appearing to eat the creature in a soup.

covid19scenario-115-12.sentence: The Daily Mail also reported on the video, and YouTube channel RT shared the footage.

covid19scenario-115-13.sentence: The clip was reportedly met with outrage from Twitter users, who quickly began calling out Chinese eating habits as the cause of the outbreak.

covid19scenario-115-14.sentence: But here's the thing, per Foreign Policy: That video in question reportedly wasn't filmed in Wuhan or China in general—the woman in the video, who news outlets have identified as Wang Mengyun, is a host of an online travel show who was actually eating a dish in Palau, an island country located in the western Pacific ocean.

covid19scenario-115-15.sentence: The video was also reportedly filmed in 2016—well before the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan.

covid19scenario-115-16.sentence: Mengyun has also reportedly apologized for the footage.

covid19scenario-115-18.sentence: I should not have eaten a bat," she said, according to the South China Morning Post.

covid19scenario-115-19.sentence: “[I] had no idea during filming that there was such a virus,” she continued.

covid19scenario-115-21.sentence: So where did coronavirus originate—and is it linked to bats at all?

covid19scenario-115-22.sentence: This is where it gets tricky: Coronaviruses in general are a large family of viruses that can affect many different species of animals, including camels, cattle, and bats, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

covid19scenario-115-23.sentence: In rare cases, those viruses are also zoonotic, which means they can pass between humans and animals—as was the case with Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) and severe acute respiratory system (SARS), two severe coronaviruses in people.

covid19scenario-115-24.sentence: Initially, this novel coronavirus was believed to have started in a large seafood or wet market, suggesting animal-to-person spread, according to the CDC.

covid19scenario-115-25.sentence: But a large number of people diagnosed with the virus reportedly didn't have exposure to the wet markets, and now it's clear that the virus is primarily spreading person-to-person, says the CDC.

covid19scenario-115-26.sentence: Is it possible that the novel coronavirus began with an infected animal at the market—and then went on to person-to-person transmission once people were infected?

covid19scenario-115-27.sentence: While experts still haven't pinpointed the actual source, new research released online by the CDC on April 21 concludes that SARS-CoV-2 "is probably a novel recombinant virus"—one that has features closely related to coronaviruses found in bats and pangolins (scaly-skinned mammals).

covid19scenario-115-28.sentence: However, none of the existing coronaviruses represents its immediate ancestor, notes Susanna K. P. Lau, MBBS, MD, head of microbiology at the University of Hong Kong, and colleagues, who analyzed the genome of the novel coronavirus.

covid19scenario-115-29.sentence: "Although the Wuhan market was initially suspected to be the epicenter of the epidemic, the immediate source remains elusive," Dr. Lau and colleagues write.

covid19scenario-115-30.sentence: If the Wuhan market were the source, it's possible, they say, that bats carrying the bat coronavirus were mixed in the market, enabling a new combination virus to develop.

covid19scenario-115-31.sentence: "However, no animal samples from the market were reported to be positive," the team points out.

covid19scenario-115-32.sentence: What's more, neither the first identified case in a human nor other early patients had visited the market, "suggesting the possibility of an alternative source."

covid19scenario-115-33.sentence: Dr. Lau and colleagues' study, released ahead of publication in the CDC journal Emerging Infectious Diseases, also throws cold water on an Internet rumor that the virus may have been created in a lab: "there is currently no evidence showing that SARS-CoV-2 is an artificial recombinant."

covid19scenario-115-34.sentence: Another recent paper in Nature Medicine underscores that point.

covid19scenario-115-35.sentence: “By comparing the available genome sequence data for known coronavirus strains, we can firmly determine that SARS-CoV-2 originated through natural processes,” Kristian Andersen, PhD, an associate professor of immunology and microbiology at Scripps Research and corresponding author on the paper, said in a statement.

covid19scenario-115-36.sentence: Andersen and colleagues' research implicates bats and possibly pangolins.

covid19scenario-115-37.sentence: Overall, the origin of the novel coronavirus is still filled with what-ifs and maybes, but even if bats are partly to blame, the likelihood that "bat soup" played a role is just an extremely misinformed (and potentially xenophobic) rumor.

9-0.sentence: As the COVID-19 crisis worsens, the world also faces a global misinformation pandemic.

9-1.sentence: Conspiracy theories that behave like viruses themselves are spreading just as rapidly online as SARS-CoV-2 does offline.

9-2.sentence: Here are the top 10 conspiracy theories making the rounds.

9-4.sentence: This conspiracy theory should be easy to debunk: it is biologically impossible for viruses to spread using the electromagnetic spectrum.

9-5.sentence: The latter are waves/photons, while the former are biological particles composed of proteins and nucleic acids.

9-6.sentence: But that isn’t really the point — conspiracy theories are enticing because they often link two things which at first might appear be correlated; in this case, the rapid rollout of 5G networks was taking place at the same time the pandemic hit.

9-7.sentence: Cue a viral meme linking the two, avidly promoted by anti-vaccine activists who have long been spreading fears about electromagnetic radiation, egged on by the Kremlin.

9-8.sentence: It’s worth repeating, as the World Health Organization (WHO) points out, that viruses cannot travel on mobile networks, and that COVID-19 is spreading rapidly in many countries that do not have 5G networks.

9-9.sentence: Even so, this conspiracy theory — after being spread by celebrities with big social media followings — has led to cellphone towers being set on fire in the UK and elsewhere.

9-11.sentence: Most conspiracy theories, like the viruses they resemble, constantly mutate and have several variants circulating at any one time.

9-12.sentence: Many of these plots and subplots seem to involve Bill Gates, who became a new target of disinformation after gently criticizing the defunding of the World Health Organization.

9-13.sentence: According to the New York Times, anti-vaxxers, members of QAnon and right-wing pundits have seized on a video of a 2015 Ted talk given by Gates — where he discussed the Ebola outbreak and warned of a new pandemic — to bolster their claims he had foreknowledge of the COVID pandemic or even purposely caused it.

9-14.sentence: A recent variant of this conspiracy theory, particularly beloved by anti-vaccination activists, is the idea that COVID is part of a dastardly Gates-led plot to vaccinate the world’s population.

9-15.sentence: There is some truth in this, of course: vaccinating much of the world’s population may well be the only way to avoid an eventual death toll in the tens of millions.

9-16.sentence: But anti-vaxxers don’t believe vaccines work.

9-17.sentence: Instead some have spread the myth that Gates wants to use a vaccination program to implant digital microchips that will somehow track and control people.

9-18.sentence: The spread of misinformation has meant that ID2020, a small non-profit that focuses on establishing digital IDs for poorer people around the world, has had to call in the FBI.

9-19.sentence: (The Cornell Alliance for Science is partly funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.)

9-20.sentence: The virus escaped from a Chinese lab

9-21.sentence: This one at least has the benefit of being plausible.

9-22.sentence: It is true that the original epicenter of the epidemic, the Chinese city of Wuhan, also hosts a virology institute where researchers have been studying bat coronaviruses for a long time.

9-23.sentence: One of these researchers, Shi Zhengli, a prominent virologist who spent years collecting bat dung samples in caves and was a lead expert on the earlier SARS outbreak, was sufficiently concerned about the prospect that she spent days frantically checking lab records to see if anything had gone wrong.

9-24.sentence: She admits breathing a “sigh of relief” when genetic sequencing showed that the new SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus did not match any of the viruses sampled and studied in the Wuhan Institute of Virology by her team.

9-25.sentence: However, the sheer coincidence of China’s lead institute studying bat coronaviruses being in the same city as the origin of the COVID outbreak has proven too juicy for conspiracists to resist.

9-26.sentence: The idea was seeded originally via a slick hour-long documentary produced by the Epoch Times, an English-language news outlet based in the United States with links to the Falun Gong religious cult that has long been persecuted by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).

9-27.sentence: The Epoch Times insists on calling COVID “the CCP virus” in all its coverage.

9-28.sentence: The theory has now tipped into the mainstream, being reported in the Washington Post, the Times (UK) and many other outlets.

9-29.sentence: COVID was created as a biological weapon

9-30.sentence: A spicier variant is that COVID not only escaped from a lab, but it was intentionally created by Chinese scientists as a biowarfare weapon.

9-31.sentence: According to Pew Research, “nearly three-in-10 Americans believe that COVID-19 was made in a lab,” either intentionally or accidentally (the former is more popular: specifically, 23 percent believe it was developed intentionally, with only 6 percent believing it was an accident).

9-32.sentence: This theory that the Chinese somehow created the virus is particularly popular on the US political right.

9-33.sentence: It gained mainstream coverage thanks to US Sen. Tom Cotton (Republican, Arkansas) who amplified theories first aired in the Washington Examiner (a highly conservative media outlet) that the Wuhan Institute of Virology “is linked to Beijing’s covert bio-weapons program.”

9-34.sentence: This theory can be easily debunked now that there is unambiguous scientific evidence — thanks to genetic sequencing — that the SARS-CoV-2 virus has entirely natural origins as a zoonotic virus originating in bats.

9-35.sentence: The Examiner has since added a correction at the top of the original piece admitting the story is probably false.

9-36.sentence: The US military imported COVID into China

9-37.sentence: The Chinese government responded to the anti-China theories with a conspiracy theory of its own that seeks to turn blame back around onto the United States.

9-38.sentence: This idea was spread initially by Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian, who Tweeted “it’s possible that the US military brought the virus to Wuhan.”

9-39.sentence: These comments, according to Voice of America news, “echoed a rumored conspiracy, widely circulated in China, that US military personnel had brought the virus to China during their participation in the 2019 Military World Games in Wuhan last October.”

9-40.sentence: For China, as the Atlantic reported, this conspiracy theory, and an accompanying attempt to rename COVID the “USA virus,”’ was a transparent “geopolitical ploy” — useful for domestic propaganda but not widely believed internationally.

9-42.sentence: Genetically modified crops have been a target of conspiracy theorists for years, so it was hardly a surprise to see GMOs blamed in the early stages of the COVID pandemic.

9-43.sentence: In early March, Italian attorney Francesco Billota penned a bizarre article for Il Manifesto, falsely claiming that GM crops cause genetic pollution that allows viruses to proliferate due to the resulting environmental “imbalance.”

9-44.sentence: Anti-GMO activists have also tried to blame modern agriculture, which is strange, since the known path of the virus into the human population — as with Ebola, HIV and many others — was through the very ancient practice of people capturing and killing wildlife.

9-45.sentence: Ironically, GMOs will almost certainly be part of any vaccine solution.

9-46.sentence: If any of the ongoing 70 vaccine projects work (which is a big if), that would be pretty much the only guaranteed way the world can get out of the COVID mess.

9-51.sentence: Early weaker versions of this theory were prevalent on the political right in the notion that the novel coronavirus would be “no worse than flu” and later versions are now influencing anti-lockdown protests across several states in the US.

9-52.sentence: Because believers increasingly refuse to observe social distancing measures, they could directly help to spread the epidemic further in their localities and increase the resulting death rate.

covid19scenario-41-0.sentence: Disclaimer: The objective of this report is to provide a snapshot overview of the current trends and insights into disinformation activities related to COVID-19/Coronavirus.

covid19scenario-41-1.sentence: The report draws on open sources, does not provide a comprehensive or complete overview and focusses primarily on the external dimension, in line with the European External Action Service (EEAS) mandate.

covid19scenario-41-2.sentence: The report was authored by the EEAS Strategic Communications and Information Analysis Division, which contributes to the EU’s efforts to counter disinformation, including through detection, analysis and exposure of disinformation campaigns.

covid19scenario-41-3.sentence: In addressing disinformation and identifying and analysing disinformation surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic, the EEAS is working closely with the European Commission, European Parliament services and EU Member States.

covid19scenario-41-4.sentence: The EEAS also cooperates on this issue with international partners (G7, NATO and civil society).

covid19scenario-41-5.sentence: The results are regularly published on EUvsDisinfo.eu and social media channels.

covid19scenario-41-6.sentence: Insights are shared with EU institutions and EU Member States in real time, including through the Rapid Alert System on Disinformation.

covid19scenario-41-8.sentence: Since the last special report, COVID-19 related online mis- and disinformation decreased and shifted focus towards vaccines, according to multiple analyses of thousands of available fact-checks since the beginning of the pandemic.

covid19scenario-41-9.sentence: The spread and reach of mis- and disinformation online remains worryingly high.

covid19scenario-41-10.sentence: A lack of tools and access to relevant data hinders research to estimate its direct impact on human behaviour.

covid19scenario-41-11.sentence: Based on current developments and observations, we expect that the health crisis around COVID-19 will continue to provide ample of opportunities worldwide for the spread of mis- and disinformation.

covid19scenario-41-12.sentence: They can be expected especially concerning tightening confinement measures as well as vaccine development and distribution.

covid19scenario-41-13.sentence: State actors like China and Russia are maximising the effect of the so-called “vaccine diplomacy” in their communication efforts, most likely with the intent to enhance their reputation and economic position abroad.

covid19scenario-41-14.sentence: They are leveraging diplomatic channels, state-controlled media and networks of supportive and alternative media outlets and social media to distribute their messages.

covid19scenario-41-15.sentence: While in the MENA region disinformation narratives are not yet at play given the delayed COVID-19 second wave, in Syria the regime continues to leverage COVID-19 to advance its political agenda through recurring disinformation on the EU sanctions.

covid19scenario-41-16.sentence: the regime continues to leverage COVID-19 to advance its political agenda through recurring disinformation on the EU sanctions.

covid19scenario-41-17.sentence: In the EU and its neighbouring countries, pro-Kremlin outlets continue to amplify voices that downplay the threat of the virus and aim to undermine governments’ strategies of curbing the second wave of infections.

covid19scenario-41-18.sentence: Assessments facilitated by the EU Code of Practice on Disinformation show continuous efforts by platforms to curb the spread of mis- and disinformation.

covid19scenario-41-19.sentence: However, proliferation, profitability and visibility of potentially harmful information remains high across online platforms.

covid19scenario-41-20.sentence: The work of fact-checkers and professional, independent media since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic remains indispensable to uncover and debunk false, misleading and potentially harmful information.

covid19scenario-41-21.sentence: Fact-checking spread has shown to have a positive impact in reducing misinformation about specific COVID-19 related claims[1].

covid19scenario-41-22.sentence: This activity is paramount in mitigating the potential harmful consequences and enhancing societal resilience.

covid19scenario-41-23.sentence: In detail: COVID-19 related disinformation, misinformation and other activities (May – November)

covid19scenario-41-24.sentence: With respect to the ongoing debate[2] to establish clearly outlined definitions for various types of false, misleading and potentially harmful information, this report will make conscious references to misinformation, which “refers to untrue information that individuals spread without any intent to mislead, though the effects of such misinformation can still be harmful” and disinformation, which describes “verifiably false content that is created, presented and disseminated for economic gain or to intentionally deceive the public, and may cause public harm”.

covid19scenario-41-25.sentence: These are often part of Information Influence Operations, which refer to coordinated efforts by either domestic or foreign actors to influence a target audience using a range of deceptive means, including suppressing independent information sources in combination with disinformation.

covid19scenario-41-26.sentence: If in earlier reporting periods, pro-Kremlin media cast doubts on EU actions and solidarity in response to COVID-19, now the main narrative shifted towards vaccines.

covid19scenario-41-27.sentence: Throughout the summer, conspiratorial narratives such as the virus being a laboratory creation or a tool of globalist elites for wrecking economic havoc continued to fade[3].

covid19scenario-41-28.sentence: Triumphant narratives[4] about Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine replaced them.

covid19scenario-41-29.sentence: Pro-Kremlin media hail the Sputnik V vaccine across the different language audiences, at times falsely alleging strong international support[5], and accusing the West of attempts to sabotage the Sputnik V vaccine for political and economic reasons[6].

covid19scenario-41-30.sentence: Western vaccine manufacturers are openly mocked on multi-lingual Russian state-controlled media, including for developing “the monkey vaccine”[7] (as some of the manufacturers use a chimpanzee viral vector).

covid19scenario-41-31.sentence: In some cases, this lead to conspiracy narratives that the vaccine will “turn people into monkeys”[8].

covid19scenario-41-32.sentence: To reach domestic audiences, Russian state-controlled media employ similar narratives as for audiences abroad: according to these, China [9] and Russia are handling the pandemic situation better than EU member states [10] or Ukraine, with safe and effective vaccines [11] at an advanced stage of development, which are sought after by other countries [12] .

covid19scenario-41-33.sentence: In Europe, pro-Kremlin media has been actively amplifying voices against lock-down measures.

covid19scenario-41-34.sentence: In Italy pro-Kremlin media consistently amplify [13] local voices, which call the government’s strategy of handling the second wave of the infections senseless, including claims that the wearing of masks is useless.

covid19scenario-41-35.sentence: Pro-Kremlin media has also called COVID-19 restrictions “a result of a bizarre psychosis and collective paranoia[14]”.

covid19scenario-41-36.sentence: At the same time, Sputnik regularly publishes updates on the success [15] of the Russian vaccine.

covid19scenario-41-37.sentence: In Germany, RT has also amplified voices questioning the threat of COVID-19, and calling testing and mask-wearing into question.

covid19scenario-41-38.sentence: An RT video[16] interview with a local physician expressing such views has been viewed over 1 million times.

covid19scenario-41-39.sentence: There is a risk that COVID-19 related disinformation may increase as Europe is undergoing new lockdowns.

covid19scenario-41-40.sentence: The Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) documented[17] the strategical use and rapid, international spread of disinformation during the pandemic.

covid19scenario-41-41.sentence: A completely fabricated report of fatal US COVID-19 vaccine trials was circulated via the website of the so-called “Luhansk People’s Republic” in the non-government-controlled areas, and “achieved widespread dissemination in multiple languages and across multiple communities” from the US to Australia – despite fact checks by multiple organisations across Europe.

covid19scenario-41-42.sentence: The press release was published the day after Russia announced plans to mass-produce its own vaccine in a matter of weeks[18].

covid19scenario-41-43.sentence: Since the last reporting period (23rd April – 18th May), over 100 new examples of pro-Kremlin linked disinformation about COVID-19 have been added to the EUvsDisinfo public database.

covid19scenario-41-44.sentence: Articles containing these examples of disinformation received over 230 thousand likes, shares, comments on social media.

covid19scenario-41-45.sentence: Since the outbreak of the pandemic, EUvsDisinfo has collected over 640 examples of pro-Kremlin disinformation related to COVID-19.

covid19scenario-41-46.sentence: According to our findings, currently the volume of pro-Kremlin disinformation surrounding the pandemic is smaller compared to spring (likely due to other events presenting fertile ground for disinformation campaigns, including Navalny poisoning, protests in Belarus, etc.

covid19scenario-41-48.sentence: An analysis across more than 9000 fact checks by the International Fact Checking Network (IFCN) underlined that false claims, disinformation and conspiracies also follow in magnitude and focus on the informational needs of users[19].

covid19scenario-41-49.sentence: First Draft explained this trend with information vacuums (“data deficits”[20]), where high levels of demand for information only meet low supply of available authoritative information.

covid19scenario-41-50.sentence: Overall, Google Trends data offers indicators that online public interest in COVID-19 related information appears to be substantially lower compared to the beginning of the pandemic.

covid19scenario-41-52.sentence: With the Middle-East and North-Africa (MENA) region potentially experiencing a delayed second COVID-19 wave compared to Europe, it is likely to assume a similarly delayed resurge of disinformation and a prevalence of vaccines-related disinformation narratives, if any.

covid19scenario-41-53.sentence: In Syria, the regime continues to leverage COVID-19 to advance its political goals.

covid19scenario-41-54.sentence: In line with a recurring narrative, the regime’s representative to the UN blamed the EU and the US for allegedly hindering through their sanctions the medical assistance to Syrians in the COVID-19 context as well as the reconstruction process and the returns of refugees.

covid19scenario-41-56.sentence: A variety of false information and misleading narratives on COVID-19 have been circulating in the Western Balkans media environment since mid-March.

covid19scenario-41-57.sentence: Local independent fact-checkers confirmed a multitude of cases of misinformation, including in relation to vaccines and health advice.

covid19scenario-41-58.sentence: Many of these included a supportive narrative focused on children and the need to protect them, targeting family audiences.

covid19scenario-41-59.sentence: [23] Across the region, claims that COVID-19 is a ‘fraud’ and that face masks are ‘harmful’ were shared widely on platforms such as Facebook, often in the form of sweeping statements based on ‘twisted’ statistical data.

covid19scenario-41-61.sentence: Since spring 2020, the fact-checking community in Turkey stepped up its efforts[27] to debunk COVID-19-related misinformation.

covid19scenario-41-62.sentence: In autumn, the number of COVID-19 related debunks was lower.

covid19scenario-41-63.sentence: In this period, claims about the ineffectiveness or risk[28] of wearing masks, different ‘natural methods’ to prevent or test for [29] COVID-19 and some conspiracy narratives (like masks carrying tracking chips[30]) were debunked.

covid19scenario-41-65.sentence: Since the beginning of the outbreak, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has utilised the pandemic to positively influence its image abroad, both by highlighting its efforts in countering COVID-19 and/or attacking and casting doubt[31] on any criticism towards it.

covid19scenario-41-66.sentence: Assertions that the virus did not originate from China still appear in state-controlled media[32] as of November 2020 [33] , which has also highlighted the “imported”[34] nature of new cases.

covid19scenario-41-67.sentence: Generally, the communication strategy appears to be two-fold: blaming others[35] and emphasising own successes.

covid19scenario-41-68.sentence: The current trend marks the continuation of the “mask diplomacy” now focusing on vaccines and correspondingly dubbed “vaccine diplomacy”[36].

covid19scenario-41-69.sentence: China’s “vaccine diplomacy” is well-advanced and promoted in state-controlled media: China is promising preferential access to its COVID-19 vaccines[37] to developing countries across Asia[38], Africa[39] and Latin America[40].

covid19scenario-41-70.sentence: According to large-scale surveys by Pew Research Center[41] and YouGov-Cambridge Globalism Project[42] (called an “illustration of Western brainwashing”[43] in the CCP-owned Global Times), China’s image abroad has suffered over the handling of the COVID-19 crisis and “vaccine diplomacy” is seen as a way to bolster diplomatic ties[44].

covid19scenario-41-71.sentence: Chinese media and officials on Twitter have criticized the US handling of the crisis[45] and their withdrawal from multilateral initiatives[46] while reinforcing China’s commitment to the United Nations system.

covid19scenario-41-72.sentence: In parallel, some media and officials have dismissed the US’ advances on vaccine[47] and accused it in pursuing a “new cold war”[48].

covid19scenario-41-77.sentence: In official diplomatic channels, it translates into the promotion of China’s commitment to COVAX[56] as a sign of mutual support and justifies cooperation (like with Finland[57], Morocco[58] and other African countries[59]).

covid19scenario-41-78.sentence: Externally, emphasis on multilateralism is tied to objectives like building a “global community of health”[60] and China’s recovering economy is depicted as exceptional and beneficial[61] to the post-pandemic world.

covid19scenario-41-80.sentence: The European Commission’s most recent assessment of reports[62] provided by the signatories of the EU Code of Practice on Disinformation, which highlight the actions taken to limit disinformation on COVID-19 on signatories’ respective platforms, presents the efforts to address disinformation around COVID-19.

covid19scenario-41-81.sentence: Actions by signatories range from the promotion of authoritative information sources to limiting the appearance of content containing false or misleading information, cooperation with fact-checkers as well as review of rules regarding online advertisement.

covid19scenario-41-82.sentence: Platforms also established dedicated portals to update users on their actions to better protect users during the pandemic[63].

covid19scenario-41-83.sentence: Despite these continuous efforts, academic research showed that mis- and disinformation continue to thrive online.

covid19scenario-41-84.sentence: The Oxford Internet Institute found and analysed over 8000 COVID-related videos containing misinformation and conspiracies that were “shared almost 20 million times on social media, which is more than the shares gathered by the five largest English-language news sources on YouTube combined”.

covid19scenario-41-85.sentence: [64] A study published in Nature Magazine shows that the situation could be worse on less compliant and emerging social media platforms.

covid19scenario-41-87.sentence: The same study highlights that cross-platform traffic undermines individual platforms’ actions, which suggests a need for closer cooperation between them to effectively curb the dissemination and spread of potentially harmful material.

covid19scenario-41-88.sentence: The need for better access to platform data to estimate impact, spread and trends of misinformation narratives remains largely unaddressed, despite privacy compliant proposals like the creation of a “Google Trends” for social media platforms[66].

covid19scenario-41-89.sentence: August 2020 study[67] from non-profit organisation Avaaz estimated that “[g]lobal health misinformation spreading networks spanning at least five countries generated an estimated 3.8 billion views on Facebook in the last year.” Peaking in April 2020, “[h]ealth misinformation spreading websites at the heart of the networks received up to 460 million views on Facebook.” Avaaz concluded that Facebook is “failing to keep people safe and informed during the pandemic”, but could “provide all users who have seen misinformation with independently fact-checked corrections” and downgrade misinformation systematically in users’ news feeds to address the problem.

covid19scenario-41-90.sentence: Research[68] by threat intelligence company CounterAction highlighted that over two million Germans are part of Facebook groups where COVID-19 related mis- and disinformation is circulating and amplified.

covid19scenario-41-91.sentence: According to the research, half of the analysed posts include language that incites people to harmful behaviour, mostly concerning the vaccine.

covid19scenario-41-92.sentence: Data showed that engagement with misinformation is not limited to political fringes, but spans party affiliation and geography.

covid19scenario-41-93.sentence: The economic incentives are an important driver for the spread of mis-and disinformation and remain strong.

covid19scenario-41-94.sentence: Brussels-based NGO EU Disinfo Lab found[69] that “[i]t is possible to monetise disinformation or conspiratorial narratives on crowdfunding platforms both indirectly and directly” and that while “[s]ome crowdfunding platforms have taken action against instances of monetisation attempts connected to COVID-19 disinformation and scams […] these actions seem incoherent and are not regularly enforced.” These monetisation streams continued even when the content in question has been demonetised or removed on other social media platforms like Facebook and YouTube.

covid19scenario-41-95.sentence: The Global Disinformation Index (GDI) found[70] that over one-third (about 200) of English language websites publishing high volumes of divisive and polarising content on inter alia COVID-19 carry advertisement which generates an estimated US$350 000 in monthly income for these websites.
