covid19scenario-32-0.sentence: As the world continues to battle the coronavirus, it is also fighting a different sort of epidemic: misinformation.

covid19scenario-32-1.sentence: This “infodemic” is just as harmful as COVID-19 itself, leading people to downplay the severity of the disease and ignore public health advice in favor of unproved treatments or “cures.” A recent survey by the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation and Gallup found that four in five Americans say the online spread of misinformation is the biggest problem facing the media.

covid19scenario-32-2.sentence: Even with widely available evidence to the contrary, beliefs are hard to change.

covid19scenario-32-3.sentence: Here are some of the most insidious falsehoods about the pandemic, and why they are wrong.

covid19scenario-32-4.sentence: Myth 1: The novel coronavirus was engineered in a lab in China.

covid19scenario-32-5.sentence: Because the pathogen first emerged and began infecting people in Wuhan, China, President Donald Trump has claimed—without evidence—that it started in a laboratory there.

covid19scenario-32-6.sentence: Some conspiracy theorists have even speculated it was engineered as a bioweapon, although U.S. intelligence agencies have categorically denied this possibility, stating that the intelligence community “concurs with the wide scientific consensus that the COVID-19 virus was not manmade or genetically modified.” No credible evidence has emerged to support an accidental lab release either.

covid19scenario-32-7.sentence: As Scientific American reported earlier this year, Chinese virologist Shi Zhengli—who studies bat coronaviruses and whose laboratory Trump and others had suggested was COVID-19’s source—compared the pathogen’s sequence against that of other coronaviruses her team had sampled from bat caves and found that it did not match any of them.

covid19scenario-32-8.sentence: Zhengli also explained in detail why her lab could not have been the source of the virus in a lengthy response in Science.

covid19scenario-32-9.sentence: In reaction to calls for an independent, international investigation into how the virus originated, China has invited researchers from the World Health Organization to discuss the scope of such a mission.

covid19scenario-32-10.sentence: But the evidence suggests SARS-CoV-2 was not created in a lab.

covid19scenario-32-11.sentence: Myth 2: Wealthy elites intentionally spread the virus to win power and profit.

covid19scenario-32-12.sentence: In a video from a conspiracy theory film entitled Plandemic and a book she co-authored, a woman named Judy Mikovits, who once published a high-profile, now retracted study on chronic fatigue syndrome, makes unsubstantiated claims about National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director Anthony Fauci and Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, suggesting they have used their power to profit from disease.

covid19scenario-32-13.sentence: Science and the Web site PolitiFact have fact-checked some of the film’s claims, many of which appear elsewhere in this article.

covid19scenario-32-14.sentence: The video was widely shared by anti-vaxxers and the conspiracy theory group QAnon.

covid19scenario-32-15.sentence: It garnered more than eight million views on YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram before it was taken down because of its false statements.

covid19scenario-32-16.sentence: Yet the large number of people who watched it suggests misinformation spreads perniciously.

covid19scenario-32-17.sentence: Myth 3: COVID-19 is no worse than the flu.

covid19scenario-32-18.sentence: Starting in the early days of the pandemic, Trump repeatedly claimed that the disease is not more dangerous than seasonal influenza.

covid19scenario-32-19.sentence: But on September 9 the Washington Post published recordings of Trump​ telling journalist and author Bob Woodward—in interviews in early February and late March—that the president knew COVID-19 was more deadly than the flu and that he wanted to play down its severity.

covid19scenario-32-20.sentence: Although COVID-19’s exact mortality rate is hard to pin down, epidemiologists suspect it is far higher than that of the flu.

covid19scenario-32-21.sentence: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that the latter causes roughly 12,000 to 61,000 deaths per year in the U.S. By contrast, COVID-19 has caused more than 191,000 deaths in the country as of this writing.

covid19scenario-32-23.sentence: Many people also have partial immunity to the flu because of vaccination or prior infection, whereas most of the world has not yet encountered COVID-19.

covid19scenario-32-24.sentence: So no, coronavirus is not “just the flu.”

covid19scenario-32-25.sentence: Myth 4: You don’t need to wear a mask.

covid19scenario-32-26.sentence: Although early guidance on masks from the CDC and the WHO was confusing and inconsistent, there is now a strong consensus among public health authorities—supported by numerous studies—that wearing a face covering can limit the transmission of the coronavirus through small exhaled droplets.

covid19scenario-32-27.sentence: Masks have long been known as an effective means of source control (preventing a sick patient from spreading a disease to others), but the early guidance was based, in part, on the fact that there was a shortage of high-quality “N95” and surgical masks.

covid19scenario-32-28.sentence: We now know that cloth face masks can be an effective alternative.

covid19scenario-32-29.sentence: But despite the evidence, many people still refuse to wear one, considering it a violation of civil liberties or emasculating.

covid19scenario-32-30.sentence: Georgia’s governor Brian Kemp went so far as to sign an executive order banning city governments from implementing mask mandates.

covid19scenario-32-31.sentence: And he sued Atlanta’s mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms when she instituted one, although he has now dropped the lawsuit.

covid19scenario-32-32.sentence: But as coronavirus cases have spiked around the U.S. in recent months, even states that were once staunch holdouts have now implemented mask orders.

covid19scenario-32-33.sentence: Myth 5: Hydroxychloroquine is an effective treatment.

covid19scenario-32-34.sentence: When a small, now widely criticized study in France suggested the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine might be effective at treating the disease, Trump and others seized on it and have continued to tout the medication despite growing evidence that it does not benefit COVID-19 patients.

covid19scenario-32-35.sentence: In a tweet, Trump called the hydroxychloroquine treatment “one of the biggest game changers in the history of medicine,” and he has mentioned it repeatedly in his public coronavirus briefings.

covid19scenario-32-36.sentence: The Food and Drug Administration initially issued an emergency use authorization for the drug, but the agency later warned against its use because of the risk of heart problems and ultimately revoked its authorization.

covid19scenario-32-37.sentence: Several studies have shown that hydroxychloroquine does not protect against COVID-19 in those who are exposed.

covid19scenario-32-38.sentence: And in June the National Institutes of Health halted its clinical trial of the medication, stating that while it was not harmful to patients, it did not provide any benefit.

covid19scenario-32-39.sentence: Yet Trump continues to hype the drug.

covid19scenario-32-40.sentence: Just a few weeks ago, he retweeted a video—viewed tens of millions of times before social media companies took it down—featuring Stella Immanuel, a Houston, Tex.–based physician (who has made questionable assertions in the past, including that doctors had used alien DNA in treatments and that demons cause certain medical conditions by having sex with people in their dreams) claiming hydroxychloroquine is an effective treatment for COVID-19.

covid19scenario-32-41.sentence: Myth 6: The Black Lives Matter protests led to increased transmission.

covid19scenario-32-42.sentence: When thousands of people started taking to the streets in late May and June to protest the police killing of George Floyd and violence against Black Americans, some people questioned whether the mass gatherings would cause a spike in coronavirus cases.

covid19scenario-32-43.sentence: But despite the concerns of Republicans such as Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio that the demonstrations pose as big a risk as going to church or the gym, such a marked increase from the protests has not been observed.

covid19scenario-32-44.sentence: A white paper analysis of protests in 315 of the largest U.S. cities by the National Bureau of Economic Research found no evidence that they led to more COVID-19 cases or deaths.

covid19scenario-32-45.sentence: And those who did not attend the protests may actually have stayed home more than they would have otherwise.

covid19scenario-32-46.sentence: The fact that the demonstrations happened outdoors, where the risk of transmission is much lower, and that many protesters wore masks likely prevented superspreading events.

covid19scenario-32-47.sentence: Meanwhile, as states have reopened, there has been a notable increase in cases tied to bars and restaurants, as well as other indoor environments—likely because of the risk of airborne spread.

covid19scenario-32-48.sentence: Myth 7: Spikes in cases are because of increased testing.

covid19scenario-32-49.sentence: As coronavirus cases began surging in many parts of the U.S. in recent months, Trump has frequently claimed that these spikes are merely to the result of more people being tested.

covid19scenario-32-50.sentence: He has tweeted that “without testing ... we would be showing almost no cases” and has said in interviews that the reason they appear to have gone up is because of increased testing.

covid19scenario-32-51.sentence: If that scenario were true, we would expect the percentage of positive tests to go down.

covid19scenario-32-52.sentence: But numerous analyses have shown the opposite.

covid19scenario-32-53.sentence: The rate has risen in many states with big outbreaks (such as Arizona, Texas and Florida), while it has decreased in those that have controlled their outbreaks (such as New York), indicating that the national increase in positive tests reflects a true increase in cases.

covid19scenario-32-54.sentence: Myth 8: We can achieve herd immunity by letting the virus spread through the population.

covid19scenario-32-55.sentence: Early on in the pandemic, some speculated that the polices chosen by the U.K. and Sweden gave the impression that they planned on letting the virus circulate through their population until they reached herd immunity—the point at which enough people are immune to the virus to prevent it from spreading to others.

covid19scenario-32-56.sentence: (Both nations’ governments have denied that this idea was their official strategy, but the U.K. was late to issue a full lockdown, and Sweden had decided against widespread restrictions.)

covid19scenario-32-57.sentence: There is a fundamental flaw with this approach, however: Experts estimate that roughly 60 to 70 percent of people would need to get COVID-19 to achieve herd immunity.

covid19scenario-32-58.sentence: And given the relatively high mortality rate of the disease, letting it infect that many individuals could lead to millions of deaths.

covid19scenario-32-59.sentence: That tragedy is what happened during the 1918 influenza pandemic, in which roughly 50 million people are thought to have perished.

covid19scenario-32-60.sentence: The U.K.’s COVID-19 death rate is among the world’s highest.

covid19scenario-32-61.sentence: Sweden, for its part, has had significantly more deaths than neighboring countries, and its economy has suffered, despite not shutting down.

covid19scenario-32-62.sentence: It is likely that many lives could have been saved if these countries had acted sooner.

covid19scenario-32-63.sentence: Myth 9: Any vaccine will be unsafe and a bigger risk than getting COVID-19.

covid19scenario-32-64.sentence: As scientists race to develop a vaccine against the disease, worrying reports have emerged that many people may refuse to get one once it is available.

covid19scenario-32-65.sentence: Conspiracy theories about potential vaccines have circulated among anti-vax groups and in viral videos.

covid19scenario-32-66.sentence: In Plandemic, Mikovits falsely claims that any COVID-19 vaccine will “kill millions” and that other vaccines have done so (in fact, vaccines save millions of lives each year).

covid19scenario-32-67.sentence: Another conspiracy theory asserts that Bill Gates has a secret plan to use vaccines to implant trackable microchips in people; Gates has denied the claim, which is not supported by evidence.

covid19scenario-32-68.sentence: Most Americans still support vaccination, yet the few voices of opposition have been growing.

covid19scenario-32-69.sentence: A recent study observed that although clusters of anti-vaxxers on Facebook are smaller than pro-vaccination groups, they are more heavily interconnected with clusters of undecided people.

covid19scenario-32-70.sentence: A recent Gallup poll found that one in three Americans would not get a COVID-19 vaccine if it were available today, with Republicans being less likely to be vaccinated than Democrats.

covid19scenario-32-71.sentence: There is good reason to be cautious about the safety of a new vaccine, but that need for prudence is why the top contenders are currently conducting large-scale clinical trials in tens of thousands of people to determine safety and efficacy.

covid19scenario-32-72.sentence: If one or more of them pass muster, it will be critical for people to get vaccinated to save lives—including, perhaps, their own.

covid19scenario-32-73.sentence: Read more about the coronavirus outbreak from Scientific American here.

covid19scenario-32-74.sentence: And read coverage from our international network of magazines here.

covid19scenario-32-75.sentence: *Editor's Note (9/10/20): This paragraph has been updated in light of a report in the Washington Post that Donald Trump told journalist Bob Woodward in recorded interviews from February and March that he knew COVID-19 was more deadly than the flu and that he had intentionally downplayed the threat.

covid19scenario-144-0.sentence: A Peruvian criminal court recently issued an order accusing Bill Gates, George Soros and the Rockefeller family of creating the COVID-19 virus.

covid19scenario-144-1.sentence: In the official document, the magistrates assumed the conspiracy theory according to which business elites and global policies planned the pandemic in order to control the population through vaccines and establish a “new world order.”

covid19scenario-144-2.sentence: A few days earlier, a group of Donald Trump supporters violently stormed the U.S. Capitol, disrupting the Congressional session that was to certify Joe Biden’s victory in the 2020 presidential election.

covid19scenario-144-3.sentence: The iconic image of the assault was that of Jacob Anthony Chansley, a man with a painted face and dressed in animal skin and horns.

covid19scenario-144-4.sentence: Chansley calls himself “the shaman” of QAnon, one of the groups that participated in the Capitol break-in.

covid19scenario-144-5.sentence: This movement is made up of followers of a conspiracy theory promoted by the U.S. far-right that claims Trump is leading the resistance against the political elites, businessmen and media who profess Satanism and practice pederasty.

covid19scenario-144-6.sentence: Theories like QAnon have multiplied in Latin America in recent decades.

covid19scenario-144-7.sentence: Although they rely on fake news disseminated massively through social networks, they are presented as “alternative information” and have an increasing impact on political systems, even affecting democratic institutions.

covid19scenario-144-9.sentence: These theories consider that secret conspiracies are behind some of the most important events in history, and like fake news, are found in Internet forums, social networks and instant messaging applications: ideal channels to be disseminated.

covid19scenario-144-10.sentence: It is a phenomenon that is difficult to define.

covid19scenario-144-11.sentence: According to Peter Knight, it can apply to anything from elaborate theories to mere suspicions about hidden agendas.

covid19scenario-144-12.sentence: Jack Bratich points out that one of the main characteristics of these theories is that they are labeled by society as “conspiracy theories” with the intention of marginalizing and dismissing them.

covid19scenario-144-13.sentence: As a result, their believers tend to reinforce ties among themselves in order to seek identity reaffirmation in the face of a social majority that disdains their discourse.

covid19scenario-144-14.sentence: In recent months, the world has witnessed unusual historical events such as the COVID-19 pandemic, the start of vaccination to combat the virus, or the assault on the Capitol in the United States.

covid19scenario-144-15.sentence: Although there have always been conspiracy hypotheses that seek to shed light on historical events, in exceptional circumstances such as the current one, they spread more effectively.

covid19scenario-144-16.sentence: Some of the most recognized theories have emerged at critical junctures such as the French Revolution, the Bolshevik Revolution, the Crash of ’29, the World Wars, the Cold War, the Kennedy assassination, the HIV/AIDS pandemic or 9/11, to name a few.

covid19scenario-144-17.sentence: Simple explanations such as these provide emotional reassurance to those who believe in them because they argue that the traumatic events that are occurring have a planned origin, i.e., they are intentionally provoked within the framework of a hidden plan and not by factors beyond their control.

covid19scenario-144-18.sentence: Moreover, they acquire greater legitimacy when they are given credibility by the mass media itself.

covid19scenario-144-20.sentence: In a region as convulsed as Latin America, conspiracy theories have played an important role.

covid19scenario-144-21.sentence: Those with a global impact have coexisted with other more homegrown ones, such as the one that claims that, after the Soviet occupation of Germany, Adolf Hitler did not commit suicide but went into exile in Argentina, or one of the most recent ones that claims that former Peruvian president Alan García faked his death to escape justice.

covid19scenario-144-22.sentence: For Mark Fenster, conspiracy theories can be effective in challenging the established order, simplifying complex political and historical events.

covid19scenario-144-23.sentence: However, at other times they put the democratic system at risk because they can be used by extremist political groups to defame their rivals, condition electoral processes or stigmatize certain ethno-cultural, religious or political groups.

covid19scenario-144-24.sentence: As pointed out by Karl Popper in The Open Society and its Enemies, political movements with authoritarian or totalitarian inclinations often disseminate these theories as an additional argument to discredit, persecute and repress the opposition.

covid19scenario-144-25.sentence: These tales of hidden intrigues reinforce in their followers a Manichean vision of the world in which a minority (it can be a political, business or media elite, or an ethnic-cultural or religious group), the “bad guys”, are the ones guilty of conspiring in some way or another against the country or humanity from positions of power, while they, the “good guys”, lead the resistance.

covid19scenario-144-26.sentence: Dictatorships and populists have resorted to conspiracy theories

covid19scenario-144-27.sentence: In Latin America, both military dictatorships and populist movements have resorted to conspiracy theories to attack their opponents, dividing society into two antagonistic political camps.

covid19scenario-144-28.sentence: In the 1970s, far-right academics in Argentina claimed that Jews were maneuvering a plan to transform Argentine Patagonia into a state similar to Israel.

covid19scenario-144-29.sentence: At the beginning of the 21st century Chavista sectors in Venezuela accused the opposition of conspiring internationally with the United States and Colombia to provoke the assassination of President Hugo Chávez.

covid19scenario-144-30.sentence: In 2016, during the plebiscite campaign about the peace accords in Colombia, extremist groups linked to the party of former President Alvaro Uribe spread the false theory that the negotiations between the government of Juan Manuel Santos and the FARC were a maneuver of “Castro-Chavism” to establish a “gay dictatorship” in the country.

covid19scenario-144-31.sentence: In all cases these theories were used to point out who the enemies of the country are and, in this way, legitimize actions aimed at confronting them.

covid19scenario-144-32.sentence: As Carlos Malamud points out, these discourses are not “conspiratorial” because they warn of the presence, sometimes real, of groups seeking to interfere in national affairs or subvert the established order, but because they are assigned a much greater influence and capacity than they have.

covid19scenario-144-33.sentence: 2021 is a year with many electoral processes in Latin America in which conspiracy theories, global or regional, will play an important role.

covid19scenario-144-34.sentence: This is a crucial issue, although complex to analyze and difficult to combat.

covid19scenario-144-35.sentence: They are complex to analyze because there is a risk of labeling dissident discourses as “conspiracy theories” just because they question the established order.

covid19scenario-144-36.sentence: They are difficult to combat because those who believe in these types of theories do not do so because they consider them reasonable or proven, but because they reinforce a sense of individual or collective belonging to a particular group.

segment-0.sentence: Steroid Drugs Are an Effective Treatment for Severe COVID-19: WHO

segment-1.sentence: Dexamethasone and other corticosteroid drugs are effective treatments for seriously ill COVID-19 patients, according to a meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials including a total of more than 1,700 participants.

segment-2.sentence: The analysis, conducted by a team at the World Health Organization (WHO) and published yesterday (September 2) in

segment-3.sentence: JAMA

segment-4.sentence: , concluded that the drugs reduced the risk of dying within 28 days compared with standard care or placebo.

segment-5.sentence: The organization has issued new guidelines recommending use of the drugs in the treatment of patients with severe or critical COVID-19.

segment-6.sentence: "Steroids are a cheap and readily available medication, and our analysis has confirmed that they are effective in reducing deaths amongst the people most severely affected by Covid-19," Jonathan Sterne, a professor of medicine and epidemiology at Bristol University who helped conduct the meta-analysis, tells

segment-7.sentence: The Guardian

segment-9.sentence: "The results were consistent across the trials and show benefit regardless of age or sex."

segment-10.sentence: Dexamethasone has been in use in hospitals as a COVID-19 treatment for seriously ill patients for several months now, after the UK RECOVERY trial reported in June that the drug reduced mortality in COVID-19 patients ill enough to require mechanical ventilation.

segment-11.sentence: The new meta-analysis reviewed data from this and two other trials of dexamethasone, plus three trials of hydrocortisone and one small study of methylprednisolone.

segment-12.sentence: All three drugs are often prescribed by doctors to help dampen inflammation and other immune system responses.

segment-13.sentence: They had been proposed as potential COVID-19 treatments partly because patients who die from the disease often succumb to overreactive immune responses.

segment-14.sentence: The WHO has cautioned that the findings do not mean that steroids should be given to all COVID-19 patients, and the organization currently recommends doctors not to prescribe the drugs to people with mild disease.

segment-15.sentence: One study included in the meta-analysis found that corticosteroids might even increase mortality in non-severe patients.

segment-16.sentence: It’s still not clear exactly when steroids should be given to patients with worsening disease for the best outcome, Nahid Bhadelia, the medical director of the Special Pathogens Unit at the Boston University School of Medicine, tells

segment-17.sentence: STAT

segment-19.sentence: For patients who don’t yet require oxygen support but maybe be developing an overreactive immune response, "it would be interesting to know if co-administration of an antiviral may help reduce viral load while the earlier steroids work on the inflammatory component," Bhadelia adds.

segment-0.sentence: COVID-19: reminder of risk of serious side effects with chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine

segment-1.sentence: Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are known to potentially cause heart rhythm problems, and these could be exacerbated if treatment is combined with other medicines, such as the antibiotic azithromycin, that have similar effects on the heart.

segment-2.sentence: Recent studies

segment-5.sentence: have reported serious, in some cases fatal, heart rhythm problems with chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine, particularly when taken at high doses or in combination with the antibiotic azithromycin.

segment-6.sentence: Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are currently authorised for treating malaria and certain autoimmune diseases.

segment-7.sentence: In addition to side effects affecting the heart, they are known to potentially cause liver and kidney problems, nerve cell damage that can lead to seizures (fits) and low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia).

segment-8.sentence: These medicines are being used in the context of the ongoing pandemic for treating patients with COVID-19 and investigated in clinical trials.

segment-9.sentence: However, clinical data are still very limited and inconclusive, and the beneficial effects of these medicines in COVID-19 have not been demonstrated.

segment-10.sentence: Results from large, well-designed studies are needed to make any conclusions.

segment-11.sentence: Some clinical trials currently investigating the effectiveness of chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine in treating COVID-19 use higher doses than those recommended for the authorised indications.

segment-12.sentence: While serious side effects can occur with recommended doses, higher doses can increase the risk of these side effects, including abnormal electrical activity that affects the heart rhythm (QT-prolongation).

segment-13.sentence: Healthcare professionals are recommended to closely monitor patients with COVID-19 receiving chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine and to take into account pre-existing heart problems that can make patients more prone to heart rhythm issues.

segment-14.sentence: They should carefully consider the possibility of side effects, particularly with higher doses, and exercise extra caution when combining treatment with other medicines such as azithromycin that may cause similar side effects on the heart.

segment-15.sentence: Patients and healthcare professionals are reminded to report any suspected side effects to their national regulatory authorities.

segment-16.sentence: A number of large, randomised clinical trials are looking at the benefits and risks of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine in patients with COVID-19.

segment-17.sentence: In the context of COVID-19, these medicines should only be used as part of clinical trials or in line with nationally agreed protocols.

segment-18.sentence: They must not be used without a prescription and without supervision by a doctor.

segment-19.sentence: EMA and the national competent authorities are monitoring the situation closely and have enhanced their safety monitoring of medicines used in the treatment of COVID-19 in order to take timely action when necessary.

segment-20.sentence: This EMA public health statement has been issued by the COVID-19 EMA pandemic Task Force (COVID-ETF) in consultation with EMA’s safety Committee (PRAC), in light of the ongoing discussions on the use of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine in the treatment of COVID-19.

segment-21.sentence: EMA is committed to providing available information to help healthcare professionals and their patients make informed decisions while awaiting clinical trial data on whether the medicines have a positive benefit-risk balance in the treatment of COVID-19.

segment-0.sentence: Coronavirus: there are no miracle foods or diets that can prevent or cure COVID-19

segment-1.sentence: Fake news spread on social media claims "super foods" can cure COVID-19.

segment-2.sentence: Since the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2), there have been widespread claims on social media that certain foods and supplements can prevent or cure COVID-19.

segment-3.sentence: Even though the World Health Organization (WHO) has tried to dispel such myths surrounding "miracle" foods and coronavirus, misinformation continues to circulate.

segment-4.sentence: Though we all want to protect ourselves against COVID-19, there is currently no evidence that eating certain foods or following certain diets will protect you against coronavirus.

segment-5.sentence: Here are some of the most common myths debunked:

segment-6.sentence: Myth 1: garlic

segment-7.sentence: There is some evidence showing that garlic has antibacterial effects, with existing studies indicating the active compounds of garlic (including allicin, allyl alcohol and diallyl disulfide) are protective against some types of bacteria like salmonella and staphylococcus aureus.

segment-8.sentence: However, research investigating garlic’s antiviral properties is limited.

segment-9.sentence: Though garlic is considered to be a healthy food, there’s no evidence showing that eating it can prevent or cure COVID-19.

segment-10.sentence: Myth 2: lemons

segment-11.sentence: One viral Facebook video claimed that drinking warm water with lemon slices could combat novel coronavirus.

segment-12.sentence: However, there’s no scientific evidence that lemon can cure the disease.

segment-13.sentence: Lemon is a good source of vitamin C, which is important for helping immune cells work properly.

segment-14.sentence: However, many other citrus fruits and vegetables contain vitamin C.

segment-15.sentence: Myth 3: vitamin C

segment-16.sentence: As previously stated, Vitamin C is known to play a role in supporting the normal functioning of the immune system.

segment-17.sentence: Yet, it’s not the only nutrient that maintains the the immune system.

segment-18.sentence: Most of the misinformation on vitamin C and coronavirus comes from studies that have investigated the links between vitamin C and the common cold.

segment-19.sentence: Despite claims online that vitamin C can prevent and treat the common cold, the evidence in support of this is not only limited, but conflicting too.

segment-20.sentence: There are also significant differences between the common cold and coronavirus.

segment-21.sentence: There’s currently no strong evidence that supplementing with vitamin C will prevent or cure COVID-19.

segment-22.sentence: Most adults will also meet their vitamin C requirements from a diet that includes a variety of fruits and vegetables.

segment-23.sentence: Myth 4: alkaline foods

segment-24.sentence: Misinformation spread on social media suggests the virus can be cured by eating foods with a pH (level of acidity) that is higher than the virus’s pH.

segment-25.sentence: A pH below 7.0 is considered acidic, a 7.0 pH is neutral, and above pH 7.0 is alkaline.

segment-26.sentence: Some of the "alkaline foods" said to "cure" coronavirus were lemons, limes, oranges, turmeric tea and avocados.

segment-27.sentence: However, many of these online sources give incorrect pH values to these foods.

segment-28.sentence: For example, the pH of a lemon was said to be 9.9, when it’s actually very acidic, with a pH of 2.

segment-29.sentence: There are claims that acidic foods can become alkaline after being metabolised by the body.

segment-30.sentence: Overall, there’s no evidence indicating that foods can even affect the pH levels of blood, cells or tissues – let alone cure viral infections.

segment-31.sentence: The body regulates acidity levels, regardless of the types of food being consumed.

segment-32.sentence: Myth 5: keto diet

segment-33.sentence: The ketogenic (keto) diet, which is a high-fat and low-carbohydrate diet, has been said to be protective against COVID-19.

segment-34.sentence: The ketogenic diet won’t prevent coronavirus.

segment-35.sentence: This comes from the idea that it can "boost" the immune system.

segment-36.sentence: Though one study showed that keto might prevent or treat the flu, this study used mice models.

segment-37.sentence: This makes it difficult to know if keto would have a similar effect on humans at preventing or treating the flu.

segment-38.sentence: There is also currently no existing scientific evidence demonstrating that a ketogenic diet can prevent coronavirus.

segment-39.sentence: Current advice

segment-40.sentence: The British Dietetic Association (BDA) has stated no specific food or supplements can prevent a person from catching COVID-19.

segment-41.sentence: Alongside WHO advice, the BDA encourages people to consume a healthy, balanced diet to support the immune system.

segment-42.sentence: A healthy and varied diet containing the five main food groups can help provide most people with the nutrients they need.

segment-43.sentence: Most of the nutrients we already get from our regular diet (including copper, folate, iron, zinc, selenium, and vitamins A, B6, B12, C, and D) are all involved in maintaining normal immune function.

segment-44.sentence: People are also encouraged to take protective measures against COVID-19, including washing hands frequently, maintaining social distancing, and following lockdown orders.

segment-45.sentence: However, the BDA does advise adults living in the UK to take a daily supplement of 10 micrograms of vitamin D and eat vitamin D rich foods, like oily fish, egg yolks, and fortified breakfast cereals to ensure adequate vitamin D levels.

segment-46.sentence: This is because our main source of vitamin D is sunlight – and because of lockdown measures, many of us aren’t getting enough sunlight exposure.

segment-47.sentence: When it comes to online misinformation, it can sometimes be difficult to spot what is and isn’t true.

segment-48.sentence: But in general, a claim is likely to be "fake" if it:

segment-49.sentence: Recommends eating a specific food, drink, or supplement (especially in high doses) to cure and prevent coronavirus

segment-50.sentence: Encourages restricting main food groups from your diet

segment-51.sentence: Singles out a certain food over others to protect or treat the virus

segment-52.sentence: Includes buzzwords – such as "cleanse", "cure", "treat", "boost", "detox" or "superfoods" – when recommending a single food item or supplement

segment-53.sentence: It’s not provided by a reliable and trusted health authority or organisation, like the NHS or WHO.

segment-54.sentence: Social media is a powerful and great tool.

segment-55.sentence: However, it can also be a catalyst for spreading misinformation.

segment-56.sentence: The bottom line is that there are no miracle foods or supplements guaranteed to protect people from novel coronavirus.

segment-57.sentence: In addition, there are no EU approved nutrition and health claims that a single food or supplement can fight viral infections, like COVID-19.

0-0.sentence: Scripps Research's analysis of public genome sequence data from SARS-CoV-2 and related viruses found no evidence that the virus was made in a laboratory or otherwise engineered

0-1.sentence: The novel SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus that emerged in the city of Wuhan, China, last year and has since caused a large scale COVID-19 epidemic and spread to more than 70 other countries is the product of natural evolution, according to findings published today in the journal Nature Medicine.

0-2.sentence: The analysis of public genome sequence data from SARS-CoV-2 and related viruses found no evidence that the virus was made in a laboratory or otherwise engineered.

0-3.sentence: "By comparing the available genome sequence data for known coronavirus strains, we can firmly determine that SARS-CoV-2 originated through natural processes," said Kristian Andersen, PhD, an associate professor of immunology and microbiology at Scripps Research and corresponding author on the paper.

0-4.sentence: In addition to Andersen, authors on the paper, "The proximal origin of SARS-CoV-2," include Robert F. Garry, of Tulane University; Edward Holmes, of the University of Sydney; Andrew Rambaut, of University of Edinburgh; W. Ian Lipkin, of Columbia University.

0-5.sentence: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that can cause illnesses ranging widely in severity.

0-6.sentence: The first known severe illness caused by a coronavirus emerged with the 2003 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) epidemic in China.

0-7.sentence: A second outbreak of severe illness began in 2012 in Saudi Arabia with the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS).

0-8.sentence: On December 31 of last year, Chinese authorities alerted the World Health Organization of an outbreak of a novel strain of coronavirus causing severe illness, which was subsequently named SARS-CoV-2.

0-9.sentence: As of February 20, 2020, nearly 167,500 COVID-19 cases have been documented, although many more mild cases have likely gone undiagnosed.

0-10.sentence: The virus has killed over 6,600 people.

0-11.sentence: Shortly after the epidemic began, Chinese scientists sequenced the genome of SARS-CoV-2 and made the data available to researchers worldwide.

0-12.sentence: The resulting genomic sequence data has shown that Chinese authorities rapidly detected the epidemic and that the number of COVID-19 cases have been increasing because of human to human transmission after a single introduction into the human population.

0-13.sentence: Andersen and collaborators at several other research institutions used this sequencing data to explore the origins and evolution of SARS-CoV-2 by focusing in on several tell-tale features of the virus.

0-14.sentence: The scientists analyzed the genetic template for spike proteins, armatures on the outside of the virus that it uses to grab and penetrate the outer walls of human and animal cells.

0-15.sentence: More specifically, they focused on two important features of the spike protein: the receptor-binding domain (RBD), a kind of grappling hook that grips onto host cells, and the cleavage site, a molecular can opener that allows the virus to crack open and enter host cells.

0-17.sentence: The scientists found that the RBD portion of the SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins had evolved to effectively target a molecular feature on the outside of human cells called ACE2, a receptor involved in regulating blood pressure.

0-18.sentence: The SARS-CoV-2 spike protein was so effective at binding the human cells, in fact, that the scientists concluded it was the result of natural selection and not the product of genetic engineering.

0-19.sentence: This evidence for natural evolution was supported by data on SARS-CoV-2's backbone - its overall molecular structure.

0-20.sentence: If someone were seeking to engineer a new coronavirus as a pathogen, they would have constructed it from the backbone of a virus known to cause illness.

0-21.sentence: But the scientists found that the SARS-CoV-2 backbone differed substantially from those of already known coronaviruses and mostly resembled related viruses found in bats and pangolins.

0-22.sentence: "These two features of the virus, the mutations in the RBD portion of the spike protein and its distinct backbone, rules out laboratory manipulation as a potential origin for SARS-CoV-2" said Andersen.

0-23.sentence: Josie Golding, PhD, epidemics lead at UK-based Wellcome Trust, said the findings by Andersen and his colleagues are "crucially important to bring an evidence-based view to the rumors that have been circulating about the origins of the virus (SARS-CoV-2) causing COVID-19."

0-24.sentence: "They conclude that the virus is the product of natural evolution," Goulding adds, "ending any speculation about deliberate genetic engineering."

0-26.sentence: Based on their genomic sequencing analysis, Andersen and his collaborators concluded that the most likely origins for SARS-CoV-2 followed one of two possible scenarios.

0-27.sentence: In one scenario, the virus evolved to its current pathogenic state through natural selection in a non-human host and then jumped to humans.

0-28.sentence: This is how previous coronavirus outbreaks have emerged, with humans contracting the virus after direct exposure to civets (SARS) and camels (MERS).

0-29.sentence: The researchers proposed bats as the most likely reservoir for SARS-CoV-2 as it is very similar to a bat coronavirus.

0-30.sentence: There are no documented cases of direct bat-human transmission, however, suggesting that an intermediate host was likely involved between bats and humans.

0-31.sentence: In this scenario, both of the distinctive features of SARS-CoV-2's spike protein--the RBD portion that binds to cells and the cleavage site that opens the virus up--would have evolved to their current state prior to entering humans.

0-32.sentence: In this case, the current epidemic would probably have emerged rapidly as soon as humans were infected, as the virus would have already evolved the features that make it pathogenic and able to spread between people.

0-33.sentence: In the other proposed scenario, a non-pathogenic version of the virus jumped from an animal host into humans and then evolved to its current pathogenic state within the human population.

0-34.sentence: For instance, some coronaviruses from pangolins, armadillo-like mammals found in Asia and Africa, have an RBD structure very similar to that of SARS-CoV-2.

0-35.sentence: A coronavirus from a pangolin could possibly have been transmitted to a human, either directly or through an intermediary host such as civets or ferrets.

0-36.sentence: Then the other distinct spike protein characteristic of SARS-CoV-2, the cleavage site, could have evolved within a human host, possibly via limited undetected circulation in the human population prior to the beginning of the epidemic.

0-37.sentence: The researchers found that the SARS-CoV-2 cleavage site, appears similar to the cleavage sites of strains of bird flu that has been shown to transmit easily between people.

0-38.sentence: SARS-CoV-2 could have evolved such a virulent cleavage site in human cells and soon kicked off the current epidemic, as the coronavirus would possibly have become far more capable of spreading between people.

0-39.sentence: Study co-author Andrew Rambaut cautioned that it is difficult if not impossible to know at this point which of the scenarios is most likely.

0-40.sentence: If the SARS-CoV-2 entered humans in its current pathogenic form from an animal source, it raises the probability of future outbreaks, as the illness-causing strain of the virus could still be circulating in the animal population and might once again jump into humans.

0-41.sentence: The chances are lower of a non-pathogenic coronavirus entering the human population and then evolving properties similar to SARS-CoV-2.

0-43.sentence: Funding for the research was provided by the US National Institutes of Health, the Pew Charitable Trusts, the Wellcome Trust, the European Research Council, and an ARC Australian Laureate Fellowship.

covid19scenario-138-0.sentence: The race is on to find a cure for Covid-19.

covid19scenario-138-1.sentence: Researchers are testing new vaccines, resurrecting old drugs, and repurposing treatments originally developed for other diseases.

covid19scenario-138-2.sentence: Things are moving fast; by the time you read this, the situation may have changed (for the better, we hope).

covid19scenario-138-3.sentence: So how are scientists thinking they'll fend off this tiny viral adversary?

covid19scenario-138-4.sentence: Here are a few lines of attack.

covid19scenario-138-9.sentence: Each particle of the new virus, SARS-CoV-2, is studded with spikes, which allow it to attach itself to a human cell, poke a hole, and burrow inside.

covid19scenario-138-10.sentence: Like the germ that caused the SARS epidemic in 2003, it sticks to a protein on human cells called ACE2, which is especially prevalent in the lungs and small intestine.

covid19scenario-138-11.sentence: (SARS-CoV-2 is at least 10 times stickier than its cousin, which may account for its rapid spread.)

covid19scenario-138-12.sentence: One way to stop the invader is to keep it from attaching in the first place.

covid19scenario-138-13.sentence: This is what your immune system tries to do—it sends out antibodies that gum up the spikes so the virus can't stick to ACE2.

covid19scenario-138-14.sentence: But there are other ways of achieving the same effect.

covid19scenario-138-17.sentence: For powerful, long-lasting immunity, a so-called live attenuated vaccine is the gold standard.

covid19scenario-138-18.sentence: It contains a defanged version of the virus that your immune system can use for target practice—but it can also cause infection.

covid19scenario-138-19.sentence: That's why many researchers are working on vaccines that contain not the whole virus but just the outer spikes.

covid19scenario-138-20.sentence: Mixed with immune-boosting molecules called adjuvants, they'll elicit a safe antibody response.

covid19scenario-138-22.sentence: Take antibody-rich blood plasma from people who have survived Covid-19 and inject it into newly infected or at-risk patients.

covid19scenario-138-23.sentence: Plasma won't teach the body how to fend off the virus, and one injection won't last forever—but it could be a good way to prepare health workers before they head to a hot spot.

covid19scenario-138-25.sentence: Flood the zone with decoys—synthetic molecules that look like ACE2 and trick the virus into binding with them instead, protecting lung cells from damage.

covid19scenario-138-27.sentence: Invent drugs that hinder ACE2 from binding with the virus.

covid19scenario-138-28.sentence: In theory, these compounds would work on both SARS and Covid-19, stopping the viruses from sticking to cells.

covid19scenario-138-29.sentence: But ACE2 plays a number of other roles throughout the body; it helps regulate blood pressure, kidney function, and even fertility.

covid19scenario-138-30.sentence: Messing with it could have dangerous consequences.

covid19scenario-138-32.sentence: All viruses wear heavy-duty protein coats to protect their precious genetic material from the elements.

covid19scenario-138-33.sentence: The new coronavirus sports an extra outer layer of fatty molecules.

covid19scenario-138-34.sentence: That's great news for humans, because it's easy to tear open with soap or alcohol-based disinfectants.

covid19scenario-138-35.sentence: (Soap works best, and you don't need to bother with the antibacterial stuff.)

covid19scenario-138-36.sentence: Without its fatty layer, the virus dies.

covid19scenario-138-37.sentence: Wipe it away or wash it down the drain.

covid19scenario-138-38.sentence: How Long Does the Coronavirus Live on Surfaces?

covid19scenario-138-39.sentence: Plus: What it means to “flatten the curve,” and everything else you need to know about the coronavirus.

covid19scenario-138-41.sentence: A virus's sole purpose in life is to hijack the machinery of its host cell and force it to make viral copies.

covid19scenario-138-42.sentence: By changing how that machinery operates, it's possible to stymie the virus's attempts.

covid19scenario-138-43.sentence: Drugs that were developed to fight other ailments could have off-label applications for Covid-19.

covid19scenario-138-45.sentence: Chloroquine phosphate, used for decades to treat malaria, changes the pH level in human cells, making them less acidic—and less hospitable to certain viruses.

covid19scenario-138-46.sentence: Researchers are exploring whether SARS-CoV-2 might be one of them.

covid19scenario-138-47.sentence: Chloroquine can also reduce the lung inflammation that kills some patients with severe Covid-19 infection.

covid19scenario-138-48.sentence: One problem: An overdose can be fatal.

covid19scenario-138-50.sentence: A class of drugs called protease inhibitors, long used to treat HIV and hepatitis C, disrupt the viral replication process.

covid19scenario-138-51.sentence: Proteases are like molecular scissors; once inside the host cell, SARS-CoV-2 uses them to slice long strands of protein into usable chunks.

covid19scenario-138-52.sentence: Without these scissors, the virus's life cycle can't continue.

covid19scenario-138-54.sentence: Another class of medications targets an enzyme called polymerase, which strings together copies of the virus's genetic material, RNA, inside the host cell.

covid19scenario-138-55.sentence: Two promising candidates in this category—remdesivir, originally developed to treat Ebola, and favipiravir, first deployed against the flu—impersonate the building blocks of RNA and get incorporated into the chain.

covid19scenario-138-56.sentence: Once they're there, the polymerase can't add new pieces, and replication halts.

covid19scenario-172-1.sentence: There is a lot of information circulating about COVID-19 and it is important for people to be educated about the virus and how to help keep it from spreading.

covid19scenario-172-2.sentence: But with so much information available there also comes misinformation.

covid19scenario-172-3.sentence: Which is why we turned to our medical experts to set the record straight by dispelling some of the common myths.

covid19scenario-172-4.sentence: People with COVID-19 may not show signs of infection for many days.

covid19scenario-172-6.sentence: The following symptoms may develop 2-14 days after exposure: fever (77-98%), cough (46-88%), or shortness of breath (3-31%).

covid19scenario-172-7.sentence: Most people (75%) develop symptoms by 7 days following exposure.

covid19scenario-172-8.sentence: Most people have mild symptoms and do not require care from a medical provider and should stay home until well.

covid19scenario-172-9.sentence: Patients with more serious symptoms, like shortness of breath, should call their medical provider.

covid19scenario-172-13.sentence: Most patients with COVID-19 have mild symptoms, like the common cold.

covid19scenario-172-15.sentence: is not helpful in determining whether someone has infection or not.

covid19scenario-172-16.sentence: People with mild symptoms do not need to be tested and should stay home until well.

covid19scenario-172-21.sentence: You should also gargle as a prevention.

covid19scenario-172-22.sentence: A simple solution of salt in warm water will suffice.

covid19scenario-172-25.sentence: Gargling with saltwater may help make your throat feel better but does not prevent infection or make it go away more quickly.

covid19scenario-172-26.sentence: Drinking warm water is effective for all viruses.

covid19scenario-172-27.sentence: Try not to drink liquids with ice.

covid19scenario-113-5.sentence: Recently, Chandra Wickramasinghe, known for his work in astronomy and astrobiology, spread the idea that the virus was living on a comet and a piece of that space rock may have fallen to Earth during a brief fireball event over China in October 2019.

covid19scenario-113-10.sentence: He even co-wrote a book with Fred Hoyle in the 1970s called "Diseases from Space" and, for decades, has tried to prove that diseases like SARS or influenza have come from space.

covid19scenario-113-11.sentence: However, scientists have rebuked Wickramasinghe's suggestions that any such illness might have extraterrestrial origins, and his ideas have largely been considered pseudoscience or "bad science."

covid19scenario-113-12.sentence: It would be unprecedented to discover that a virus could survive the radiation it would be exposed to on such a long journey through space (never mind the trip back to Earth) and still be able to infect humans after it landed, astrobiologist Graham Lau, who hosts NASA's "Ask an Astrobiologist" series, told Space.com.

covid19scenario-113-13.sentence: However, while it would be an incredibly unique and groundbreaking finding if this were true, Wickramasinghe simply does not have evidence to support his claims, Lau said.

covid19scenario-113-15.sentence: "Even though it's an interesting idea, we just don't have any reason to embrace that idea right now.

covid19scenario-113-17.sentence: "If this was real, it'd be great, but we just can't allow ourselves to jump to the feel-good conclusion without doing our due diligence as scientists."

1-0.sentence: President Joe Biden has ordered US intelligence agencies to conduct a 90-day review of what is known about the origins of Covid-19 and whether it could have escaped from a laboratory in Wuhan.

1-1.sentence: So what does this mean for the lab leak theory?

1-3.sentence: Despite the Biden announcement and various stories in the US media claiming support is growing for the Wuhan lab leak theory, the answer is that surprisingly little has changed in terms of good quality evidence – at least in the public domain.

1-4.sentence: The most striking new claim in recent days, ahead of Biden’s announcement, was in the Wall Street Journal, which reported that US intelligence agencies were told that three unnamed staff at the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV) were sick enough to go hospital in November 2019 with symptoms that might have been coronavirus.

1-6.sentence: The intelligence relating to the three staff at the WIV has been described as uncorroborated evidence from a foreign source, ie it was not obtained – or so far verified – by a US intelligence agency, and was initially looked at under the Trump administration.

1-7.sentence: “It was very precise,” one source told the WSJ, but added the crucial caveat: “What it didn’t tell you was exactly why they got sick.”

1-8.sentence: According to the New York Times, not one but two intelligence documents were produced discussing the sick workers, one focused on the three individuals, the second about what was known about the origins of the coronavirus.

1-9.sentence: There are multiple issues, however, with how to interpret this information.

1-10.sentence: Questions include whether the symptoms seen were of coronavirus or bad flu (or something else) and whether the sickness – if it was coronavirus – was related to work in their lab, or simply suggests that Covid-19 was circulating in the general population in Wuhan a few weeks earlier than assumed.

1-11.sentence: Biden’s comments, launching the review, are revealing – not least when he said that the US intelligence community does “not believe there is sufficient information” to fully understand the likelihood of different scenarios for explaining the origin of the virus that causes Covid-19.

1-12.sentence: Biden also revealed that two of the 18 US intelligence agencies lean towards the theory it jumped from an animal species to humans and “one leans more toward” the lab theory, suggesting a striking lack of clarity.

1-13.sentence: Meanwhile, outside of US intelligence circles, the broad consensus among scientific experts remains that the most likely explanation is that Covid-19 jumped to humans from an animal host in a natural event.

1-14.sentence: So where are we with the animal host theory?

1-15.sentence: Much has been made by some of the fact that no intermediate animal host – between humans and bats – has so far been identified, which has been cited in some places as somehow supporting the lab leak theory.

1-16.sentence: The reality is that identifying animal hosts in past coronavirus outbreaks has been a lengthy and uncertain process.

1-17.sentence: While it is known that dromedaries were a major reservoir host for Mers, even now the role of the animals in transmitting the virus is poorly understood.

1-18.sentence: The same was true with the Sars outbreak.

1-19.sentence: While civet cats were suspected as intermediate hosts, it took years to confirm.

1-20.sentence: In neither case was there was a suggestion of a lab leak.

1-21.sentence: Because of that, the model of transmission via an intermediate host has remained the predominant one under consideration.

1-22.sentence: Another issue is that a lot of focus of research into the origins of Covid-19 so far has relied on the very specialised field of the interpretation of gene sequences of the virus, an area that is less accessible to non-experts including journalists.

1-23.sentence: But wasn’t there a World Health Organization mission to Wuhan to study the origins of Covid-19?

1-25.sentence: But the terms of reference of that mission, agreed with China, were to study the potential animal origins of the coronavirus, a fact that was well known to the US and other countries.

1-26.sentence: It did not include provisions for an audit of the WIV laboratory or to look into so-called “gain of function” research at the lab into viruses, which the Chinese are unlikely to have agreed to.

1-27.sentence: During that mission to Wuhan, researchers spent just three hours at the lab.

1-28.sentence: However, in public comments team members were sceptical of the lab leak theory after their visit, on the basis of what they were allowed to see – although that does not rule other material having been hidden.

1-29.sentence: And China, as the WHO’s head, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, made clear, did not provide all the information that many had been hoping for, including full epidemiological data on some 174 early cases.

1-30.sentence: Why has the lab leak theory come back now?

1-32.sentence: The overt hostility of the Trump administration to China, and the way it pushed the lab leak claims, including a dodgy dossier that was doing the rounds last year, made it a pretty tainted source.

1-33.sentence: The advent of a Biden administration, which is less hostile to China, combined with the limitations in the WHO investigation, created an environment where some have felt able to ask questions about Covid-19’s origins without appearing to buy into Trump-era conspiracies.

1-34.sentence: However, like the Benghazi attack in 2012, the Wuhan lab leak theory remains something of a cause celebre for the US right in the midst of what is essentially a cold war between the US and China.

1-35.sentence: In particular, it has been seen as a stick to beat the Biden administration’s handling of it, not least following the decision to close down a state dDepartment group that had been looking into the lab leak theory.

1-36.sentence: That effort, first reported by CNN, was quietly launched by the then secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, last autumn and reportedly became quickly mired in concern that it was part of a politicised effort by the Trump administration to blame China and cherry-pick facts to prove a theory.

1-37.sentence: Indeed, one source quoted by CNN was highly critical of the work being done.

1-38.sentence: “They basically conducted it in secret, cutting out the state department’s technical experts and the intelligence community, and then trying to brief certain senior officials in the interagency on their ‘tentative conclusions’ even before they’d let the department leaders they worked for know an investigation was under way at all.”

1-41.sentence: Many aspects of Wuhan lab leak story have echoes of the search for WMD in the run-up to the Iraq war in 2003 which included efforts to “stove pipe” intelligence analysis to fit the operating theory.

1-42.sentence: Then as now, experts (then weapons inspectors also under the aegis of a UN body) were sent into a highly obstructive environment amid a highly politicised debate.

1-43.sentence: Leaks of dubious intelligence – some of it provided by third party countries like the infamous Curveball claims – were reported without sufficient scepticism and expert warnings sidelined.

1-44.sentence: So has the lab leak theory become more credible or not?

1-45.sentence: The bottom line is that it is still impossible to know with any certainty, as Biden has said.

1-46.sentence: Lab accidents do happen all the time, meaning that without further evidence a lab leak remains a possibility.

1-47.sentence: The experience of Sars and Mers suggests that coronaviruses do break out naturally and that understanding their origins is difficult.

1-48.sentence: Chinese obstruction of research into Covid-19’s origins, combined with its own promotion of conspiracy theories over a foreign origin of the disease, make it look like it has something sinister to hide.

1-49.sentence: As the experience of the Iraq weapons inspectors demonstrated, obstruction can be profoundly misunderstood as suggesting a motive: ie Saddam Hussein was not hiding WMD but had substantially disarmed.

1-50.sentence: And where we are today, as Adam Taylor put it cleverly in the Washington Post on Thursday, is nowhere close to a resolution.

1-51.sentence: “Although the resurgent chatter may suggest new clues or proof, the inverse is in fact true.

1-52.sentence: It is the persistent absence of any convincing evidence either for or against the theory that has prompted calls for more investigation.”

covid19scenario-21-0.sentence: The EUvsDisinfo database has been accumulating coronavirus-related disinformation cases for more than two months – it’s time to take a look and see what’s hiding in plain sight.

covid19scenario-21-1.sentence: Comparing the cases on the coronavirus published between January 22 and March 25 with the caseload from this week alone, it appears that the anti-American vibe is still going strong.

covid19scenario-21-2.sentence: In total, we have collected 39 cases claiming that the US created the coronavirus.

covid19scenario-21-3.sentence: The second most common narrative is that the EU is failing to cope with the crisis and is disintegrating as a result, together with the border-free Schengen area.

covid19scenario-21-4.sentence: In particular, this narrative of failure and lack of EU solidarity is trending after the delivery of Russian aid to Italy – we have added 26 new disinformation cases to the database.

covid19scenario-21-5.sentence: The narrative that the virus is being used as a weapon against China and its economy comes in third place with 24 cases.

covid19scenario-21-6.sentence: And in fourth place is the rather creative notion that the whole coronavirus crisis is a secret plan of the global elite, with 17 cases and counting.

covid19scenario-21-7.sentence: Rounding out our top five is a group of messages targeting Ukraine in the context of the coronavirus crisis, with the pro-Kremlin media successfully managing to mix in accusations of Nazism.

covid19scenario-21-9.sentence: Do the most common narratives also mean most engagement?

covid19scenario-21-10.sentence: In order to answer this question, we looked at the 152 cases collected between January 22 and March 25, which have had more time to age on social media and generate likes, shares, and comments.

covid19scenario-140-0.sentence: As news and misinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic has spread, many Americans have encountered conflicting narratives about how the new coronavirus originated.

covid19scenario-140-1.sentence: Scientists have determined the virus came about naturally, but there is some uncertainty about how it first infected people.

covid19scenario-140-2.sentence: While a plurality of Americans (43%) say the new coronavirus most likely came about naturally, nearly three-in-ten (29%) say it most likely was created in a lab, according to a Pew Research Center survey conducted from March 10 to 16, 2020, as part of the Center’s nearly yearlong Election News Pathways project.

covid19scenario-140-3.sentence: Around a quarter of adults (23%) say it is most likely that the current strain of coronavirus was developed intentionally in a lab; another 6% say it was most likely made accidentally in a lab.

covid19scenario-140-4.sentence: A quarter say they aren’t sure where the virus originated.

covid19scenario-140-5.sentence: To explore the extent to which misinformation has made its way into the news people get about the COVID-19 outbreak, we focused on the belief of some Americans that the virus was created in a lab.

covid19scenario-140-6.sentence: We used data from a survey of 8,914 U.S. adults conducted March 10 to 16, 2020, as part of the Center’s nearly yearlong Election News Pathways project.

covid19scenario-140-7.sentence: All survey participants are members of the Center’s American Trends Panel, a nationally representative online survey panel.

covid19scenario-140-8.sentence: Panelists were recruited by telephone or mail so that nearly every U.S. adult has a known chance of being selected.

covid19scenario-140-9.sentence: The data is weighted to further ensure it reflects the U.S. adult population by gender, race, ethnicity, partisan affiliation, education and other categories.

covid19scenario-140-10.sentence: Here are the questions asked for this report, along with responses, and its methodology.

covid19scenario-140-11.sentence: Visit our interactive data tool to access the data on the coronavirus pandemic and other issues related to news and the election.

covid19scenario-140-12.sentence: Americans differ by age, education level and race and ethnicity when it comes to who believes that the virus was created in a lab:

covid19scenario-140-13.sentence: Younger adults are more likely than older people to say the virus was developed in a lab.

covid19scenario-140-14.sentence: For example, about a third of adults ages 18 to 29 say the virus was developed in a lab (35%), compared with 21% of adults 65 and older.

covid19scenario-140-15.sentence: Nearly four-in-ten (39%) adults under 30 say it came about naturally, while 51% of those 65 and older say this.

covid19scenario-140-16.sentence: Educational attainment is also a factor.

covid19scenario-140-17.sentence: Those with a bachelor’s degree or more education are less likely than those with a high school diploma or less education to say the coronavirus was created in a lab (19% vs. 35%).

covid19scenario-140-18.sentence: A majority (61%) of those with at least a bachelor’s degree say the virus came about naturally, compared with 31% of those with a high school diploma or less.

covid19scenario-140-19.sentence: The belief that the coronavirus was created in a lab also is more prevalent among Hispanic and black Americans than among whites.

covid19scenario-140-20.sentence: About four-in-ten Hispanic adults (39%) say the virus was created in a lab.

covid19scenario-140-21.sentence: Among black adults, 34% say the same.

covid19scenario-140-22.sentence: Around a quarter of white adults (26%) say it was developed in a lab.

covid19scenario-140-23.sentence: When it comes to political affiliation and ideology, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to say the coronavirus was created in a lab (37% vs. 21%).

covid19scenario-140-24.sentence: About four-in-ten conservative Republicans say this (39%), the largest share of any ideological group.

covid19scenario-140-25.sentence: Confusion surrounding these facts parallels Americans’ overall experience with misinformation during the outbreak.

covid19scenario-140-26.sentence: About half of U.S. adults (48%) report having come across at least some news and information about COVID-19 that seemed completely made up, with 12% saying they have seen a lot of it and 35% saying they have seen some.

segment-0.sentence: Convalescent plasma therapy

segment-1.sentence: Print

segment-2.sentence: Overview

segment-3.sentence: Convalescent plasma (kon-vuh-LES-unt PLAZ-muh) therapy uses blood from people who've recovered from an illness to help others recover.

segment-4.sentence: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorized convalescent plasma therapy for people with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

segment-5.sentence: The FDA is allowing its use during the pandemic because there's no approved treatment for COVID-19.

segment-6.sentence: Blood donated by people who've recovered from COVID-19 has antibodies to the virus that causes it.

segment-7.sentence: The donated blood is processed to remove blood cells, leaving behind liquid (plasma) and antibodies.

segment-8.sentence: These can be given to people with COVID-19 to boost their ability to fight the virus.

segment-9.sentence: Why it's done

segment-10.sentence: Convalescent plasma therapy may be given to people who are hospitalized with COVID-19.

segment-11.sentence: Convalescent plasma therapy may help people recover from COVID-19.

segment-12.sentence: It may lessen the severity or shorten the length of the disease.

segment-13.sentence: Risks

segment-14.sentence: Blood has been used to treat many other conditions.

segment-15.sentence: It's usually very safe.

segment-16.sentence: The risk of getting COVID-19 from convalescent plasma hasn't been tested yet.

segment-17.sentence: But researchers believe that the risk is low because donors have fully recovered from the infection.

segment-18.sentence: Convalescent plasma therapy has some risks, such as:

segment-19.sentence: Allergic reactions

segment-20.sentence: Lung damage and difficulty breathing

segment-21.sentence: Infections such as HIV and hepatitis B and C

segment-22.sentence: The risk of such infections is low.

segment-23.sentence: Donated blood must be tested for safety.

segment-24.sentence: Some people may have mild complications or none at all.

segment-25.sentence: Other people may have severe or life-threatening complications.

segment-26.sentence: What you can expect

segment-27.sentence: Your doctor may consider convalescent plasma therapy if you're in the hospital with COVID-19.

segment-28.sentence: If you have questions about convalescent plasma therapy, ask your doctor.

segment-29.sentence: Your doctor will order convalescent plasma that is compatible with your blood type from your hospital's local blood supplier.

segment-30.sentence: Before the procedure

segment-31.sentence: Before convalescent plasma therapy, your health care team prepares you for the procedure.

segment-32.sentence: A health care team member inserts a sterile single-use needle connected to a tube (intravenous, or IV, line) into a vein in one of your arms.

segment-33.sentence: During the procedure

segment-34.sentence: When the plasma arrives, the sterile plasma bag is attached to the tube and the plasma drips out of the bag and into the tube.

segment-35.sentence: It takes about one to two hours to complete the procedure.

segment-36.sentence: After the procedure

segment-37.sentence: You'll be closely monitored after you receive the convalescent plasma.

segment-38.sentence: Your doctor will record your response to the treatment.

segment-39.sentence: He or she also may record how long you need to stay in the hospital and if you need other therapies.

segment-40.sentence: Results

segment-41.sentence: It's not yet known if convalescent plasma therapy will be an effective treatment for COVID-19.

segment-42.sentence: You might not experience any benefit.

segment-1.sentence: - New data show therapy reduced risk of hospitalizations and death by 87 percent - Second positive Phase 3 trial readout for bamlanivimab and etesevimab together - Results support use of bamlanivimab 700 mg and etesevimab 1400 mg, the dose authorized in U.S. and several countries around the world

segment-2.sentence: INDIANAPOLIS, March 10, 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- Eli Lilly and Company (NYSE: LLY) today announced new data from the randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled BLAZE-1 Phase 3 study, demonstrating bamlanivimab (LY-CoV555) 700 mg and etesevimab (LY-CoV016) 1400 mg together significantly reduced COVID-19 related hospitalizations and deaths ("events") in high-risk patients recently diagnosed with COVID-19.

segment-3.sentence: These results provide additional efficacy and safety data that support the use of the dose recently granted both Emergency Use Authorization by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and a positive scientific opinion by the European Medicines Agency's (EMA) Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP).

segment-4.sentence: This new Phase 3 cohort of BLAZE-1 included 769 high-risk patients, aged 12 and older with mild to moderate COVID-19 (therapy: n=511; placebo: n=258).

segment-5.sentence: There were four events in patients taking bamlanivimab with etesevimab and 15 events in patients taking placebo, representing an 87 percent risk reduction (p0.0001).

segment-6.sentence: Bamlanivimab and etesevimab together also demonstrated statistically significant improvements on key secondary endpoints.

segment-7.sentence: These results are consistent with those seen in other data sets from BLAZE-1: in the previous Phase 3 cohort, bamlanivimab 2800 mg with etesevimab 2800 mg reduced the risk of hospitalizations and deaths by 70 percent and in the Phase 2 cohort, bamlanivimab alone reduced the risk of hospitalizations and ER visits by approximately 70 percent.

segment-8.sentence: The viral load reductions were also consistent with what was observed in the previous Phase 3 cohort of the study.

segment-9.sentence: In this new Phase 3 cohort, there were four deaths total, all of which were deemed related to COVID-19 and all of which occurred in patients taking placebo; no deaths occurred in patients receiving treatment with bamlanivimab and etesevimab together.

segment-10.sentence: Across the two Phase 3 cohorts of the study that have been analyzed to date, there have been no deaths in patients receiving treatment with bamlanivimab and etesevimab together, and 14 deaths in patients receiving placebo, 13 of which were deemed COVID-19 related.

segment-11.sentence: In this data set, the safety profile of bamlanivimab and etesevimab together was consistent with observations from other Phase 1, Phase 2 and Phase 3 trials evaluating these antibodies.

segment-13.sentence: "These positive results reinforce our previous findings and support the authorized dose of bamlanivimab 700 mg with etesevimab 1400 mg.
