covid19scenario-48-0.sentence: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced that COVID-19, a disease caused by the coronavirus, had been found in toilet paper, and that people should use wet cloths instead.

covid19scenario-48-1.sentence: On March 10, 2020, Now8News published an article positing that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced that COVID-19, a disease caused by the new coronavirus, had been found in packages of toilet paper, and that people should start using a wet washcloth to clean themselves instead:

covid19scenario-48-2.sentence: COVID-19 Found in Toilet Paper […] The coronavirus has been found in the one place people never expected, toilet paper.

covid19scenario-48-3.sentence: An estimated 6000 more people have contracted the virus in the United States tied to a contamination of toilet paper.

covid19scenario-48-4.sentence: Testing by Washington State Health department confirmed the COVID-19 virus particles were present in the samples they took from five separate packages of toilet paper from Big Box stores.

covid19scenario-48-5.sentence: The CDC said this strain of deadly virus “breeds rapidly in tissue fibers.” The CDC is urging people to using a wet washcloth when cleaning themselves after using the bathroom instead of toilet paper.

covid19scenario-48-6.sentence: This is not a genuine news article.

covid19scenario-48-7.sentence: Now8News is a junk news site that traffics in misinformation.

covid19scenario-48-8.sentence: Now8News does not carry a readily available disclaimer labeling its content as “satire” or “fake news,” but this website’s content is undoubtedly fiction.

covid19scenario-48-9.sentence: We’ve been debunking misinformation from Now8News since at least 2015, including junk news articles about people having sex with pigs at Walmart, a cannibal eating a person at a haunted house in Texas, and a lottery winner who died after dipping his testicles in gold.

covid19scenario-48-10.sentence: Those unfamiliar with this site, however, were given no indications that this toilet-paper story was false.

covid19scenario-48-11.sentence: It was presented like a traditional news story and even includes fabricated quotes from the CDC.

covid19scenario-48-13.sentence: The CDC is urging people to using a wet washcloth when cleaning themselves after using the bathroom instead of toilet paper.

covid19scenario-48-14.sentence: “Use a washcloth to clean yourself after you go to the bathroom, it’s not a big deal, that’s what we did back in the old days,” said Peter Lendl, who headed the investigation of the contaminated toilet paper.

covid19scenario-48-16.sentence: This is not a genuine quote from the CDC.

covid19scenario-48-17.sentence: We were unable to find this quote in news articles, social media posts from someone named “Peter Lendl,” or from a CDC press release.

covid19scenario-48-18.sentence: In fact, the only results for this quote pointed back to this junk news article from Now8News.

covid19scenario-48-19.sentence: In sum, the CDC did not announce in March 2020 that the new strain of coronavirus was “rapidly breeding” on toilet paper and that people should use a wet washcloth instead.

covid19scenario-48-20.sentence: You can find genuine information about how to deal with the coronavirus on the CDC website.

segment-0.sentence: Airborne Transmission of Coronavirus

segment-1.sentence: Airborne Transmission in Tight Spaces

segment-2.sentence: Medical professionals from the preeminent organizations on public health Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the World Health Organization have started changing their stance that COVID-19 is airborne.

segment-3.sentence: This is important news.

segment-4.sentence: Prior to this, doctors hypothesized that COVID-19 was transmitted by droplets larger than aerosols and primarily through contaminated surfaces.

segment-5.sentence: Unlike these heavier droplets, airborne diseases can be picked up in airstreams, can travel farther than heavier droplets, and require different prevention strategies.

segment-6.sentence: For the sake of comparison and understanding, heavier droplets are like a bowling ball and smaller airborne droplets are like a ping-pong ball.

segment-7.sentence: The wind or airstream is going to have a greater impact on redirecting a ping-pong ball than it is a bowling ball.

segment-8.sentence: Subsequently, airborne droplets can be caught up in the airstream and recirculated throughout a poorly ventilated building.

segment-9.sentence: This recent development has fast-tracked the recent requirement for wearing masks while indoors.

segment-10.sentence: A New York Times model shows how these droplets can spread from you to others around you.

segment-11.sentence: Loud and Crammed Indoor Spaces

segment-12.sentence: Loud and crammed indoor spaces like bars are also more vulnerable to airborne transmission.

segment-13.sentence: People are congregating in tight spaces and because of the noise levels; they have to talk louder thus expelling droplets more rapidly and forcefully.

segment-14.sentence: The same thing can be said about weddings, church services, birthday parties, and funerals.

segment-15.sentence: These settings usually have people talking, singing, laughing, and crying in small indoor spaces leading to a higher chance of transmission and infection.

segment-16.sentence: Many of these same principles extend to office spaces, schools, healthcare settings, and other indoor places with large gatherings that require face-to-face communication.

segment-17.sentence: For safe social gatherings, health professionals recommend heading outdoors.

segment-18.sentence: Despite the infinite amount of ventilation provided by the outdoors, droplets can still start concentrating after a long enough time of talking, laughing, etc.

segment-19.sentence: increasing the possibility of infection.

segment-20.sentence: For this, health professionals recommend staying distanced, moving, limiting guests, and wearing a mask.

segment-21.sentence: If you are not staying in the same spot, like moving through a grocery store or walking, then your rate of infection decreases.

segment-22.sentence: Doctors are concerned with the dosage of droplets that leads to infection.

segment-23.sentence: As of the publication of this blog, doctors have not specified a dosage rate required for infection.

segment-24.sentence: Asymptomatic Superspreaders

segment-25.sentence: Doctors are also still exploring the differences between super-spreaders and less efficient spreaders.

segment-26.sentence: Superspreaders can rapidly spread coronavirus to others even if they are asymptomatic.

segment-27.sentence: To help deter infections by asymptomatic superspreaders, cities and states are implementing mask mandates for indoor spaces since they help filter out larger droplets and can reduce spread.

segment-28.sentence: Many major retailers like Target, Walmart, Kroger, and Aldi are also requiring masks in stores, even if the local government has not mandated it.

segment-29.sentence: Many other retailers have erected Plexiglas barriers between shoppers and workers.

segment-30.sentence: Check with your local store to see their current mandates.

segment-31.sentence: Detering Airborne Transmission with an Air Filter

segment-32.sentence: Besides those physical barriers, another weapon to combat airborne transmission is an air filter.

segment-33.sentence: An air filter can capture these small particles and trap them, limiting their spread.

segment-34.sentence: MERV 16 filters capture up to 96% of virus-sized airborne particles and virus-sized airborne particles*.

segment-35.sentence: The American Society of Heating, Refrigeration, and Air-Conditioning Engineers recommends a minimum MERV rating of 13 to neutralize airborne viruses.

segment-36.sentence: Using these filters in conjunction with an air purifier, helps you quickly change out the air.

segment-37.sentence: This process helps reduce the spread of airborne viruses.

segment-38.sentence: Filters are critical in helping capture those droplets circulating in the airstream.

segment-39.sentence: They do not have a 100 percent success rate and virus-laden droplets can still circulate even with an air purifier.

segment-40.sentence: Along with our precautionary measures, air filters do help in limiting the spread of airborne viruses whether it is a whole-home or portable system.

segment-41.sentence: Experts are also still trying to determine how long the virus lives on surfaces.

segment-42.sentence: This determines the risk involved in changing out those virus-filled air filters.

segment-43.sentence: Protecting yourself against COVID-19 and other airborne viruses require a multi-part approach.

segment-44.sentence: Social distancing, frequently washing hands and surfaces, shielding your mouth and nose with a mask, and installing an air purifier are the best methods to keep you and your family safe.

segment-52.sentence: Until there is a vaccine, it is best to take as many precautions to protect yourself and your family.

covid19scenario-67-0.sentence: As the COVID-19 pandemic continues, a host of untruths has surrounded the topic.

covid19scenario-67-1.sentence: In this Special Feature, we address some of these myths and conspiracy theories.

covid19scenario-67-2.sentence: Share on Pinterest A variety of myths have sprung up around the novel coronavirus.

covid19scenario-67-3.sentence: This article was updated on November 8, 2020

covid19scenario-67-4.sentence: The novel coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, has spread from Wuhan, China, to every continent except Antarctica.

covid19scenario-67-5.sentence: The World Health Organization (WHO) changed their classification of the situation from a public health emergency of international concern to a pandemic on March 11, 2020.

covid19scenario-67-6.sentence: The virus has been responsible for tens of millions of infections globally, causing more than a million deaths.

covid19scenario-67-7.sentence: The United States has been the most affected country.

covid19scenario-67-8.sentence: As ever, when the word “pandemic” began appearing in headlines, people became fearful — and with fear came misinformation and rumors.

covid19scenario-67-9.sentence: Below, we dissect some of the most common myths currently circulating on social media and beyond.

covid19scenario-67-10.sentence: Stay informed with live updates on the current COVID-19 outbreak and visit our coronavirus hub for more advice on prevention and treatment.

covid19scenario-67-12.sentence: Spraying chlorine or alcohol on the skin kills viruses in the body

covid19scenario-67-13.sentence: Applying alcohol or chlorine to the skin can cause harm, especially if it enters the eyes or mouth.

covid19scenario-67-14.sentence: These chemicals can disinfect surfaces, but people should not use them on their bodies.

covid19scenario-67-15.sentence: Also, these products cannot kill viruses inside the body.

covid19scenario-67-17.sentence: Only older adults and people with preexisting conditions are at risk of infections and complications

covid19scenario-67-18.sentence: SARS-CoV-2, like other coronaviruses, can transmit to people of any age.

covid19scenario-67-19.sentence: However, older adults and individuals with preexisting health conditions, such as diabetes, obesity, or asthma, are more likely to become severely ill.

covid19scenario-67-20.sentence: While people under 40 , including children, are less likely to become severely ill with COVID-19, the disease can lead to complications and death in anyone.

covid19scenario-67-23.sentence: Anyone, of any age, can develop the infection that causes COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-24.sentence: So far, most COVID-19 cases have been in adults, but children are not immune.

covid19scenario-67-25.sentence: That said, most children who develop COVID-19 have mild symptoms or none at all.

covid19scenario-67-26.sentence: Also, on May 15, 2020, the WHO released a commentary about an inflammatory condition in children and adolescents that may have links with COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-27.sentence: The condition, called multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children , known as MIS-C, has features similar to Kawasaki disease and toxic shock syndrome.

covid19scenario-67-28.sentence: Scientists currently know little about this condition, but research from May suggests that it is rare, “probably affecting no more than 1 in 1,000 children exposed to SARS-CoV-2.”

covid19scenario-67-30.sentence: COVID-19 is just like the flu

covid19scenario-67-31.sentence: Infection with the virus SARS-CoV-2 can cause COVID-19, an illness that can cause flu-like symptoms, such as body aches, a fever, and a cough.

covid19scenario-67-32.sentence: Symptoms of either COVID-19 or the flu can be mild, severe, or rarely, fatal.

covid19scenario-67-33.sentence: Both illnesses can also cause pneumonia.

covid19scenario-67-34.sentence: However, the overall profile of COVID-19 is more serious.

covid19scenario-67-35.sentence: Different countries have reported different mortality rates, and the case fatality rate in the U.S. appears to be around 2.6%.

covid19scenario-67-36.sentence: While scientists are still determining the exact mortality rate based on developing data, it is likely to be many times higher than that of the seasonal flu.

covid19scenario-67-37.sentence: Learn about the differences between COVID-19 and the flu here.

covid19scenario-67-41.sentence: As we explain above, COVID-19 is fatal for a small percentage of people who develop the illness.

covid19scenario-67-42.sentence: The WHO have reported that around 80% of people with COVID-19 experience a relatively form of the illness and do not need specialist treatment in a hospital.

covid19scenario-67-43.sentence: Mild symptoms may include a fever, a cough, a sore throat, tiredness, and shortness of breath.

covid19scenario-67-44.sentence: Also, many people with the underlying infection experience no symptoms.

covid19scenario-67-46.sentence: Cats and dogs spread the coronavirus

covid19scenario-67-47.sentence: There have been several reports of pets developing the infection, including in the U.S.

covid19scenario-67-48.sentence: In most cases, the pets became sick after coming into contact with people who had COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-49.sentence: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) , “There is no evidence that animals play a significant role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-67-50.sentence: Scientists are debating the importance of these cases in animals.

covid19scenario-67-51.sentence: For instance, Jonathan Ball, a professor of molecular virology at the University of Nottingham, in the United Kingdom, says:

covid19scenario-67-52.sentence: “We have to differentiate between real infection and just detecting the presence of the virus.

covid19scenario-67-53.sentence: I still think it’s questionable how relevant it is to the human outbreak, as most of the global outbreak has been driven by human-to-human transmission.”

covid19scenario-67-55.sentence: Face masks always protect against the coronavirus

covid19scenario-67-56.sentence: Healthcare workers use professional face masks that fit tightly to protect themselves from infections.

covid19scenario-67-57.sentence: Disposable and cloth masks can protect against droplets, but neither can protect against aerosolized particles.

covid19scenario-67-58.sentence: The CDC recommend that all people wear cloth face masks in public areas where it is difficult to maintain a 6-foot, or 2-meter, distance from others.

covid19scenario-67-59.sentence: This helps slow the spread of the virus.

covid19scenario-67-60.sentence: Even while wearing a mask, it is essential to continue with other precautions, such as not touching the face, physical distancing, and washing the hands frequently.

covid19scenario-67-61.sentence: Instructions for making masks at home are available here .

covid19scenario-67-62.sentence: Surgical masks and N95 respirators provide greater protection, but reserve these for healthcare workers.

covid19scenario-67-65.sentence: Hand dryers do not kill SARS-CoV-2.

covid19scenario-67-66.sentence: The best way to protect oneself and others from the virus is to wash the hands with soap and water frequently for at least 20 seconds at a time.

covid19scenario-67-67.sentence: When this is not possible, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.

covid19scenario-67-69.sentence: SARS-CoV-2 is just a mutated form of the common cold virus

covid19scenario-67-70.sentence: Coronaviruses are a large family, and each has spiky proteins on their surface.

covid19scenario-67-71.sentence: Some use humans as their primary host and cause the common cold.

covid19scenario-67-72.sentence: Other coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2, primarily infect animals.

covid19scenario-67-73.sentence: Like COVID-19, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) are caused by coronaviruses.

covid19scenario-67-74.sentence: These viruses also initially passed to humans from animals.

covid19scenario-67-76.sentence: You have to be with someone for 10 minutes to catch the virus

covid19scenario-67-77.sentence: The longer a person is close to someone with the infection, the likelier the virus is to transmit.

covid19scenario-67-78.sentence: However, the virus can pass from person to person in under 10 minutes.

covid19scenario-67-80.sentence: Rinsing the nose with saline protects against the coronavirus

covid19scenario-67-81.sentence: There is no evidence that a saline nasal rinse protects against any respiratory infections.

covid19scenario-67-82.sentence: Some research suggests that a rinse might ease the symptoms of acute upper respiratory tract infections, but scientists have not found that this technique reduces the risk of infection.

covid19scenario-67-84.sentence: You can protect yourself by gargling bleach

covid19scenario-67-85.sentence: People should never put bleach in their mouths.

covid19scenario-67-86.sentence: Gargling bleach could never benefit a person’s health.

covid19scenario-67-87.sentence: Bleach is corrosive and can cause serious damage.

covid19scenario-67-93.sentence: Thermal scanners can diagnose the coronavirus

covid19scenario-67-94.sentence: Thermal scanners can detect whether someone has a fever — which might result from any number of health issues.

covid19scenario-67-95.sentence: Symptoms of COVID-19 can appear 2–14 days after the infection develops.

covid19scenario-67-96.sentence: This means that even if a person develops symptoms, they may have a normal temperature for days before a fever begins.

covid19scenario-67-99.sentence: Some research suggests that garlic may slow the growth of some species of bacteria.

covid19scenario-67-100.sentence: COVID-19 results from a virus, not bacteria.

covid19scenario-67-101.sentence: There is no evidence that garlic can protect people from COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-103.sentence: Parcels from China can spread the coronavirus

covid19scenario-67-104.sentence: From previous research into coronaviruses similar to SARS-CoV-2, including those that cause SARS and MERS, scientists believe that the virus cannot survive on letters or packages for extended periods.

covid19scenario-67-105.sentence: The CDC explain that “Although the virus can survive for a short period on some surfaces, it is unlikely to be spread from domestic or international mail, products, or packaging.”

covid19scenario-67-107.sentence: Home remedies can cure and protect against COVID-19

covid19scenario-67-108.sentence: No home remedies can protect against COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-109.sentence: This goes for vitamin C, essential oils, silver colloid, sesame oil, garlic, fish tank cleaner, sage, or water, even when a person sips it every 15 minutes.

covid19scenario-67-110.sentence: The best approach is to wash the hands frequently, for 20 seconds at a time, to use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer, to wear a face covering in public, and to avoid crowded places.

covid19scenario-67-112.sentence: You can catch the coronavirus from eating Chinese food in the US

covid19scenario-67-115.sentence: You can catch the coronavirus from urine and feces

covid19scenario-67-116.sentence: This is likely false, but the jury is currently out.

covid19scenario-67-117.sentence: According to Prof. John Edmunds, from the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, in the U.K.:

covid19scenario-67-118.sentence: “It isn’t a very pleasant thought, but every time you swallow, you swallow mucus from your upper respiratory tract.

covid19scenario-67-119.sentence: In fact, this is an important defensive mechanism.

covid19scenario-67-120.sentence: This sweeps viruses and bacteria down into our gut where they are denatured in the acid conditions of our stomachs.”

covid19scenario-67-121.sentence: “With modern, very highly sensitive detection mechanisms, we can detect these viruses in feces.

covid19scenario-67-122.sentence: Usually, the viruses that we can detect in this way are not infectious to others, as they have been destroyed by our guts.”

covid19scenario-67-123.sentence: However, it is worth noting that some research suggests that viruses similar to SARS-CoV-2 might persist in feces.

covid19scenario-67-124.sentence: A research letter in JAMA also concludes that SARS-CoV-2 is present in feces.

covid19scenario-67-126.sentence: The virus will die off when temperatures rise

covid19scenario-67-127.sentence: Some viruses, such as cold and flu viruses, spread more easily in colder months.

covid19scenario-67-128.sentence: This does not mean that their transmission stops in warmer weather.

covid19scenario-67-129.sentence: As it stands, scientists do not know how temperature changes influence the behavior of SARS-CoV-2.

covid19scenario-67-131.sentence: The coronavirus is the deadliest virus known to humans

covid19scenario-67-132.sentence: While SARS-CoV-2 does appear to be more dangerous than influenza viruses, it is not the deadliest virus that people have faced.

covid19scenario-67-133.sentence: Others, such as the Ebola virus, have higher mortality rates.

covid19scenario-67-135.sentence: Flu and pneumonia vaccines can protect against COVID-19

covid19scenario-67-136.sentence: Because SARS-CoV-2 is distinct from other viruses, no existing vaccines can protect against it.

covid19scenario-67-138.sentence: The virus originated in a laboratory in China

covid19scenario-67-139.sentence: There is no evidence to back up this rumor, which has circulated on the internet.

covid19scenario-67-140.sentence: As a recent study demonstrates, SARS-CoV-2 is a natural product of evolution.

covid19scenario-67-141.sentence: Some researchers believe that SARS-CoV-2 jumped from pangolins to humans.

covid19scenario-67-142.sentence: Others think that it passed to us from bats , like SARS did.

covid19scenario-67-144.sentence: The outbreak began because people ate bat soup

covid19scenario-67-145.sentence: While scientists are confident that the virus started in animals, there is no evidence that soup was involved.

covid19scenario-67-148.sentence: As the world becomes more connected, some regions are rolling out 5G mobile technology.

covid19scenario-67-149.sentence: This has prompted a raft of conspiracy theories.

covid19scenario-67-150.sentence: One of the most recent to emerge is that 5G is responsible for the swift spread of SARS-CoV-2 across the globe.

covid19scenario-67-152.sentence: Some people believe that 5G helps viruses communicate, often citing a paper from 2011.

covid19scenario-67-153.sentence: In this study, the authors conclude that bacteria can communicate via electromagnetic signals.

covid19scenario-67-155.sentence: In any case, SARS-CoV-2 is a virus, not a bacterium.

covid19scenario-67-156.sentence: Wuhan was one of the first cities to trial 5G in China, which helps explain the origin of some of these theories.

covid19scenario-67-157.sentence: However, Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou also rolled out 5G at a similar time.

covid19scenario-67-158.sentence: It is also worth noting that COVID-19 has significantly impacted countries with very little 5G coverage, such as Iran.

covid19scenario-67-159.sentence: Learn about the health implications of 5G in depth here.

covid19scenario-67-161.sentence: Drinking alcohol reduces the risk of infection

covid19scenario-67-162.sentence: The WHO have released a response to the series of myths surrounding alcohol and COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-163.sentence: They explain that while alcohol can disinfect the skin, it does not have this effect inside the body.

covid19scenario-67-164.sentence: They continue, “Consuming any alcohol poses health risks, but consuming high-strength ethyl alcohol (ethanol), particularly if it has been adulterated with methanol, can result in severe health consequences, including death.”

covid19scenario-67-165.sentence: Also, in a fact sheet on the subject, they explain that “Alcohol use, especially heavy use, weakens the immune system — and thus reduces the ability to cope with infectious diseases.”

covid19scenario-67-166.sentence: And because alcohol is associated with a number of diseases, it may make people more vulnerable to COVID-19.

covid19scenario-67-168.sentence: Injecting or consuming bleach or disinfectant kills the virus

covid19scenario-67-169.sentence: Consuming or injecting disinfectant or bleach does not wipe out viruses in the body, and it can be extremely dangerous.

covid19scenario-67-170.sentence: As Dr. Wayne Carter, an associate professor at the University of Nottingham’s Faculty of Medicine & Health Sciences, in the U.K., explains, “Disinfectants and bleach are strong oxidizing agents, useful to kill bacteria or viruses when they are deposited on surfaces, but these agents should not be ingested or injected.

covid19scenario-282-0.sentence: The novel coronavirus likely originated in bats, but the pathogen may have then hopped into dogs before infecting humans, a new study suggests.

covid19scenario-282-1.sentence: But not everyone agrees with that hypothesis.

covid19scenario-282-2.sentence: One expert told Live Science that "there are a lot of weaknesses" in the study and that the data don't support the study's conclusions.

covid19scenario-282-4.sentence: Before the new coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 made the jump to humans, two other coronaviruses , SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, evolved in bats and passed through other animals on their way to people.

covid19scenario-282-5.sentence: SARS-CoV passed through civets and MERS-CoV through camels, and the molecular structure of SARS-CoV-2 suggests that the virus also passed through an intermediate animal , but scientists don't yet know which one.

covid19scenario-282-6.sentence: In February, authors of a preliminary study published to the preprint database bioRxiv suggested that pangolins may bridge the gap between bats and humans, since SARS-CoV-2 and related coronaviruses that infect pangolins sport similar spike proteins — a structure on the surface of the virus that allows it to infect cells.

covid19scenario-282-7.sentence: But other scientists argued that, despite their spike proteins, pangolin coronaviruses bear many differences to SARS-CoV-2 that make pangolins unlikely to be the source of infection, The New York Times reported .

covid19scenario-282-8.sentence: With the mystery unresolved, biology professor Xuhua Xia of the University of Ottawa in Canada launched his own investigation into how the coronavirus passed from bats to people.

covid19scenario-282-9.sentence: His analysis, published April 14 in the journal Molecular Biology and Evolution , offered a new solution: dogs.

covid19scenario-282-10.sentence: Xia reached his conclusion by scanning the genetic code of SARS-CoV-2 and other coronaviruses for a specific feature known as a CpG site, a sequence of genetic code in which the compound cytosine (C) is followed by the compound guanine (G).

covid19scenario-282-11.sentence: The human immune system sees CpG sites as a red flag, signaling that an invasive virus is present.

covid19scenario-282-12.sentence: A human protein called zinc finger antiviral protein (ZAP) latches onto the CpG sites on the viral genetic code and recruits help to break down the pathogen, according to UniProt , an online protein database.

covid19scenario-282-13.sentence: The theory follows that, the fewer CpG sites, the less vulnerable a virus will be to ZAP.

covid19scenario-282-14.sentence: Related: 10 deadly diseases that hopped across species

covid19scenario-282-15.sentence: Xia found that SARS-CoV-2 carries fewer CpG sites than the other known coronaviruses that first evolved in animals, including SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV.

covid19scenario-282-16.sentence: In addition, the closest known relative of SARS-CoV-2 , the bat coronavirus RaTG13, contains fewer CpG sites than related bat coronaviruses , according to the analysis.

covid19scenario-282-17.sentence: "This suggests that SARS-CoV-2 may have evolved in a new host (or new host tissue) with high ZAP expression," which would place evolutionary pressure on the virus to shed CpG sites, Xia wrote.

covid19scenario-282-18.sentence: Essentially, in order to survive and reproduce, a pathogen like SARS-CoV-2 needs to be able to evade the host’s immune fighters, and in this case it would mean getting rid of CpG sites that could alert ZAP proteins to the virus.

covid19scenario-282-20.sentence: Unfortunately, little data exists on exactly how much ZAP appears in different animal tissues, Xia told Live Science.

covid19scenario-282-21.sentence: So he worked backwards, looking for animal coronaviruses with low CpG levels.

covid19scenario-282-22.sentence: He found a coronavirus that primarily infects the canine intestine, and thus inferred that the dog gut might contain adequate ZAP levels to drive viral evolution in this way.

covid19scenario-282-23.sentence: "Only canids seem to have the tissue generating low-CpG CoVs during my study," Xia said.

covid19scenario-282-24.sentence: If a precursor to SARS-CoV-2 breached the canine intestine, then this would have "resulted in rapid evolution of the virus" to lose CpG sites and become better equipped to infect humans, he wrote in the paper.

covid19scenario-282-25.sentence: Beyond the low CpG levels, the paper did not note other genetic similarities between SARS-CoV-2 and the dog coronavirus, but suggested that the canine gut might provide the right environment for such viruses to evolve.

covid19scenario-282-27.sentence: Some research suggests that ZAP mRNA, which contains instructions to build the protein, appears in both the dog lung and colon but that higher concentrations accumulate in the lungs, Xia said.

covid19scenario-282-28.sentence: It may be that a glut of ZAP in the lungs guards the organ from coronaviruses, while the lower concentrations of ZAP in the colon leave the gut open to severe infection, though there are reasons to be cautious in coming to this conclusion, Xia said.

covid19scenario-282-29.sentence: But does this hypothesis make sense?

covid19scenario-282-30.sentence: "I think the data do not support these conclusions," Pleuni Pennings, an assistant professor of ecology and evolution at San Francisco State University, who was not involved in the study, told Live Science in an email.

covid19scenario-282-31.sentence: Pennings, whose research group has examined the CpG levels of many viruses, pointed out several weaknesses in the study's logic.

covid19scenario-282-33.sentence: In a 2018 study published in the journal PLOS Genetics , Pennings surveyed CpG levels in the HIV virus and investigated how the pathogen evolves within individual people.

covid19scenario-282-34.sentence: She then led a similar study of several other viruses — including Dengue fever virus, influenza , and hepatitis B and C — to learn how often these bugs lose or gain CpG sites through mutations.

covid19scenario-282-35.sentence: Her group found that, in general, mutations that add CpG sites tend to be found in viral samples taken from people less often than mutations that remove CpG sites from the genome.

covid19scenario-282-36.sentence: CpG-creating mutations may be costly to viruses in that they alert the body to infection, so over time, evolutionary forces minimize their appearance, Pennings said.

covid19scenario-282-37.sentence: That said, many viruses still carry CpG sites, so the mutations may carry some benefit "even if it comes with a slight cost," she added.

covid19scenario-282-38.sentence: So SARS-CoV-2 is not unusual in that way.

covid19scenario-282-39.sentence: "There are many viruses with lower [CpG] values than SARS-CoV-2," Pennings said.

covid19scenario-282-40.sentence: "When you look at all viruses, the [CpG] value is not strange at all," she said.

covid19scenario-282-41.sentence: Xia did find that SARS-CoV-2 contains fewer CpG sites than other animal-borne coronaviruses, and assuming that finding is correct, then it raises the question of why that came to be, she added.

covid19scenario-282-42.sentence: But even if there is an evolutionary reason to explain why SARS-CoV-2 lost CpG sites, that evolutionary reason may not give the virus a special advantage for infecting humans, Pennings said.

covid19scenario-282-43.sentence: In his paper, Xia noted that studies have "shown an association between decreased CpG in viral RNA genomes and increased virulence," meaning low-CpG viruses appear associated with more severe infection.

covid19scenario-282-44.sentence: However, although evolution favors mutations that delete CpG sites, and there's a general trend tying fewer CpG sites to more severe infection, "it doesn’t mean that viruses with low numbers of CpG sites are necessarily more virulent," Pennings said.

covid19scenario-282-45.sentence: For example, the BK virus contains very few CpG sites and resides in the kidneys of an estimated 60% to 80% of adults , but typically only triggers symptoms in immunosuppressed people, she noted.

covid19scenario-282-46.sentence: (The virus was named the initials of the first person it was isolated from.)

covid19scenario-282-47.sentence: If the CpG levels present in SARS-CoV-2 are somehow related to disease severity, "then this would provide an efficient way for vaccine development," Xia said.

covid19scenario-282-48.sentence: In this hypothetical scenario, scientists could eliminate CpG sites from the coronavirus genome in a lab dish, thereby weakening the bug to the point that it could safely be incorporated into a vaccine.

covid19scenario-282-49.sentence: But as of yet, no correlation has been drawn between CpG and the relative severity of SARS-CoV-2 infections.

covid19scenario-282-50.sentence: Several pangolin coronaviruses included in Xia's study also contained few CpG sites, on par with SARS-CoV-2 and the bat virus RaTG13.

covid19scenario-282-51.sentence: Given other genetic differences between human and pangolin coronaviruses, however, the ancestor shared between this low-CpG pangolin coronavirus and SARS-CoV-2 would likely have existed over 130 years ago, Xia said.

covid19scenario-282-52.sentence: "We expect a SARS-CoV-2 progenitor to be much more recent," he said.

covid19scenario-282-53.sentence: But did dogs serve as an intermittent host for the coronavirus?

covid19scenario-282-54.sentence: At this point, there's little evidence to suggest so.

segment-1.sentence: Tom Bartlett

segment-4.sentence: Wash Your Hands—but Beware the Electric Hand Dryer

segment-5.sentence: "Electric towels" were supposed to prevent the spread of contagious disease.

segment-6.sentence: What if they've been doing the opposite?

segment-7.sentence: Save this story for later.

segment-8.sentence: Photograph: Getty Images

segment-9.sentence: The spread of Covid-19 has turned us into a nation of hand-washing obsessives, citizens who vigorously interlace our fingers and circle-scrub our thumbs with an exacting, anxiety-fueled intensity.

segment-10.sentence: But it’s not over when you flip off the faucet: Drying your hands matters too, because damp skin provides a hospitable environment for microorganisms and, as a result, might increase the likelihood that you’ll pass on pathogens.

segment-11.sentence: So now, as we confront what could be a society-altering disease outbreak, it seems worth taking a hard look at the widely reviled yet seemingly ubiquitous electric hand dryer.

segment-12.sentence: Are they as hygienic as paper towels, as their manufacturers claim?

segment-13.sentence: The earliest pitches for hand dryers played up their supposed ability when it comes to "preventing the spread of contagious disease," as a 1924 newspaper ad for the Airdry Electric Towel put it.

segment-14.sentence: More recently, Dyson, whose Airblade hand dryer promises to "scrape water from hands like a windshield wiper," has bragged that its HEPA air filter captures particles as tiny as .3 microns in diameter, much like the N95 face masks that are now selling for AirPod Pro–equivalent prices on Amazon.

segment-15.sentence: But the quality of the intake filter doesn’t address whether blowing air at high speeds is a smart idea given that it may be sending droplets and particles from your just-washed hands flying rapidly every which way.

segment-16.sentence: When you dig into the science on hand dryers, you’ll come across reason to be concerned.

segment-17.sentence: A study published in 1989 found that gentler, old-style hand dryers blew bacteria over a three-foot radius and onto the user’s clothes, which considering the era was probably an acid-washed jean jacket.

segment-18.sentence: A 2018 study produced even more troubling results, finding that "potential pathogens and spores" could be "dispersed throughout buildings and deposited on hands by hand dryers."

segment-19.sentence: It tested conventional hot-air models with and without filters and determined that the filters "most likely reduce the number of potentially pathogenic bacteria with the potential to colonize hands but do not eliminate the risk entirely."

segment-20.sentence: A 2015 study found that super-aggro hand-dryers like the ones made by Dyson, which use higher-speed jets of air at room temperature, "produced significantly greater aerosolization of virus on the hands" than the traditional kind.

segment-21.sentence: Paper towels, meanwhile, were found to cause about the same amount of viral spread as hot-air models.

segment-22.sentence: A 2012 analysis of 12 studies over four decades published in

segment-23.sentence: Mayo Clinic Proceedings

segment-24.sentence: concluded that "[f]rom a hygiene viewpoint, paper towels are superior to electric air dryers" and that they should be used in "locations in which hygiene is paramount, such as hospitals and clinics."

segment-25.sentence: Though it could be argued that hygiene should be paramount in the restroom of, say, your neighborhood Panera Bread, too.

segment-26.sentence: The analysis did find that dryers like Dyson’s "led to much less bacterial transfer than hot air dryers."

segment-27.sentence: So does that tell us anything about whether hand dryers could spread a virus like the one that causes Covid-19?

segment-28.sentence: I called Peter Setlow, a biochemist at the University of Connecticut and one of the authors of that 2018 study.

segment-29.sentence: Setlow is a "spore guy" not an infectious disease expert, but he nonetheless came away from that research with a deep and abiding distrust of hand dryers regardless of the model.

segment-30.sentence: "Sorry, hand-dryer industry," he told me.

segment-31.sentence: "My personal opinion is that they shouldn’t be used."

segment-32.sentence: There’s been understandable blowback from the hand-dryer industry, which questions the methodology of some of this research and notes that certain studies pegging hand dryers as disease vectors—including the one cited above, from 2015—were carried out by researchers who had worked as consultants for paper-towel manufacturers.

segment-33.sentence: This is true in some, though not all, cases.

segment-34.sentence: Dyson got in on the game by funding a study, published last April, that found—surprise!

segment-35.sentence: —hands dried with the company’s own Airblade harbored fewer bacteria than those dried with paper towels.

segment-36.sentence: There’s reason to be skeptical of last year’s paper.

segment-37.sentence: In the study, subjects "slowly" moved their hands in and out of the machine for a full minute, something no normal human is ever going to do.

segment-38.sentence: Besides, Dyson says elsewhere that the model dries hands satisfactorily in a mere 12 seconds, so which is it?

segment-39.sentence: More importantly, that study only looked at the bacteria left behind on hands post-drying, not whether particles might have been blown onto your clothes.

segment-40.sentence: It’s not just a matter of public health: There are fortunes at stake in the science war between the paper-towel and hand-dryer industries.

segment-41.sentence: Multifold paper towels, the kind commonly used in bathrooms, are a several-billion-dollar-a-year behemoth, and one recent estimate of the global market for hand dryers puts the number at a shade under $800 million, and growing.

segment-42.sentence: This is big money and obviously no company wants their products to be viewed as more likely to make people sick.

segment-43.sentence: Dyson has made the case that, while other brands of hand dryers might spread disease, its products are perfectly safe even in hospitals.

segment-44.sentence: Karen Holeyman, lead research scientist and microbiologist at Dyson, also notes via email that "Dyson Airblade™ hand dryers are proven hygienic," and referred to its HEPA air filter.

segment-45.sentence: Yet it’s hard to read the scientific papers without concluding that, well, paper is the way to go.

segment-46.sentence: If the science seems to lean in that direction, though, why have electric dryers continued to claim more and more tiled territory?

segment-47.sentence: For starters, they do have undeniable upsides.

segment-48.sentence: Unlike paper towels, hand dryers don’t create waste and they’re drastically cheaper over time.

segment-49.sentence: The annual cost for paper towels in a public restroom can easily top a thousand dollars, while the electricity required to run a hand dryer costs about a fifth of that, according to one estimate.

segment-50.sentence: But focusing on paper towel prices seems a little ridiculous when epidemiologists are calculating death rates.

segment-51.sentence: We’re at a moment when hand-washing must be taken very seriously.

segment-52.sentence: The same is true for hand-drying.

segment-53.sentence: Electric hand dryers appear to be a modern, more responsible solution to an everyday problem—but one that may not live up to its billing.

segment-57.sentence: found that high-speed air dryers "led to much less bacterial transfer than hot air dryers," and that the 2018 study referenced tested conventional hot-air dryers; and to remove any implication that drying hands on pants may be more hygienic than using a hand dryer.

segment-60.sentence: The 2015 study referenced was funded by the paper towel industry and tellingly did not employ methodology which represents real-world use and instead used unwashed hands covered in unrealistically high levels of virus contamination.

segment-0.sentence: What does the COVID-19 summer surge mean for your cats and dogs?

segment-1.sentence: An employee takes a cat’s temperature at a cat café in Bangkok.

segment-2.sentence: Science’s COVID-19 reporting is supported by the Pulitzer Center and the Heising-Simons Foundation.

segment-3.sentence: Last month, the first U.S. dog to definitively test positive for COVID-19 died in New York City.

segment-4.sentence: The canine—a German shepherd named Buddy—likely had lymphoma, but the case served as a reminder that pets, too, are at risk.

segment-5.sentence: Now, COVID-19 cases are surging in some areas of the United States, including in places that had largely escaped the virus in the spring, and some countries around the world are grappling with renewed outbreaks.

segment-6.sentence: People are also wondering and worrying about their pets.

segment-7.sentence: Scientists are, too.

segment-8.sentence: It remains unclear, for example, how often cats and dogs become infected with the virus, what their symptoms are, and how likely they are to pass it along to other animals, including us.

segment-9.sentence: Yet veterinarians are hard on the case, and a handful of studies are starting to provide some answers.

segment-10.sentence: Experts have some concrete advice based on what we know so far.

segment-11.sentence: We’re a much bigger risk to our pets than they are to us.

segment-12.sentence: Federal health agencies and veterinary experts have said since the beginning of the pandemic that pets are unlikely to pose a significant risk to people.

segment-13.sentence: Hard evidence from controlled studies for this assertion was lacking—and still is—but everything scientists have seen so far suggests cats and dogs are highly unlikely to pass SARS-CoV-2 to humans.

segment-14.sentence: "There’s a lot greater risk of going to the grocery store than hanging out with your own animal," says Scott Weese, a veterinarian at the University of Guelph’s Ontario Veterinary College who specializes in emerging infectious diseases and who has dissected nearly every study on COVID-19 and pets on his blog.

segment-15.sentence: Indeed, pets are much more likely to get the virus from humans than the other way around.

segment-16.sentence: "Almost all pets that have tested positive have been in contact with infected humans," says Jane Sykes, chief veterinary medical officer at the University of California, Davis, and a founder of the International Society for Companion Animal Infectious Diseases, which is providing COVID-19 information to both pet owners and veterinarians.

segment-17.sentence: A genetic study of the viral sequences in the first two dogs known to have COVID-19 indicates they caught it from their owners.

segment-18.sentence: Even tigers and lions infected at New York City’s Bronx Zoo in April appear to have contracted the virus from humans.

segment-19.sentence: But some researchers caution that this finding may be due in part to limited testing: Most of the pets that have been evaluated got the tests because they lived with humans who had already tested positive.

segment-20.sentence: "It’s a stacked deck," says Shelley Rankin, a microbiologist at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, whose lab is part of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network.

segment-21.sentence: Still, most researchers think pets pose little risk to people—and to other pets as well.

segment-22.sentence: A few studies have shown that cats can transmit SARS-CoV-2 to other cats, but all were conducted in an artificial laboratory setting.

segment-23.sentence: And, like many COVID-19 studies in humans, most studies are preprints that have yet to be published in peer-reviewed journals.

segment-24.sentence: What’s more, Sykes notes there have been multiple reports of households where one pet tested positive and others didn’t. "Everything we’ve learned so far suggests that it’s unlikely that pets are a significant source of transmission," she says.

segment-25.sentence: COVID-19 symptoms in pets are likely mild to nonexistent.

segment-26.sentence: Because pet testing remains rare, it’s unclear how many cats and dogs have been infected with SARS-CoV-2.

segment-27.sentence: A serological preprint published last month indicated that 3% to 4% of cats and dogs in Italy had been exposed to the virus at the height of the pandemic there—comparable to the rate among people.

segment-28.sentence: A girl and her dog don masks in Regensburg, Germany.

segment-29.sentence: But even if the numbers are really that high, there hasn’t been a concomitant uptick in symptoms.

segment-30.sentence: The Seattle-based Trupanion, which provides health insurance for more than half a million dogs and cats in North America and Australia, says it has not seen an increase in respiratory claims—or any other type of health claim—since the pandemic began.

segment-31.sentence: "No big trends are jumping out," says Mary Rothlisberger, the company’s vice president of analytics, even when she looked at pandemic hot spots.

segment-32.sentence: Two recent studies have also shown that cats, at least, are unlikely to exhibit symptoms.

segment-33.sentence: "My gut sense is that [the disease is] much more minor than we’re seeing in people," Sykes says.

segment-34.sentence: That could mean pets are silent transmitters of the virus, as some scientists have suggested, but so far there’s no direct evidence for this.

segment-35.sentence: It probably doesn’t make sense to get your pet tested.

segment-36.sentence: Several pet tests are available, but they aren’t widely used because the priority has been on human testing.

segment-37.sentence: Agencies like the United States Department of Agriculture have cautioned against routine testing of cats and dogs.

segment-38.sentence: Even if your pet does test positive, Weese says, "What are you going to do with the results?"

segment-39.sentence: If your dog or cat has COVID-19, it’s probably because you do too, he says.

segment-40.sentence: "It doesn’t change anything for the pet or the family."

segment-41.sentence: And because there aren’t any drugs for the disease, he says, "We wouldn’t prescribe anything" for the pet.

segment-42.sentence: Safety precautions for pets haven’t changed.
