covid19scenario-119-0.sentence: Trail of Deceit: The Most Popular COVID-19 Myths and How They Emerged

covid19scenario-119-1.sentence: by John Gregory and Kendrick McDonald

covid19scenario-119-2.sentence: Editor’s Note: This report was updated in June 2020 to add additional COVID-19 myths that have become prominent online.

covid19scenario-119-3.sentence: As COVID-19 has spread across the globe, NewsGuard’s team of journalists has been tracking, rating, and flagging websites spreading information about the disease in the Coronavirus Misinformation Tracking Center.

covid19scenario-119-4.sentence: The tracker lists a growing number of websites that have published false claims about COVID-19, from false cures and phony treatments to conspiracy theories about the disease’s origins.

covid19scenario-119-5.sentence: Many of the sites in the tracking center publish the same hoaxes and myths as misinformation spreads virally from one domain to another and through social media posts that amplify false articles.

covid19scenario-119-6.sentence: Here, we document and debunk the top 10 COVID-19 myths that have spread across these sites—and trace how each myth emerged and began to spread across the internet.

covid19scenario-119-7.sentence: Click each myth below to see its entry.

covid19scenario-119-8.sentence: Or scroll down to browse through the full list.

covid19scenario-119-9.sentence: MYTH: “The COVID-19 virus was stolen out of a Canadian lab by Chinese spies.”

covid19scenario-119-11.sentence: PolitiFact, FactCheck.org, and the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. all concluded that there is no evidence that the COVID-19 virus was stolen by Chinese spies from a Canadian lab.

covid19scenario-119-12.sentence: The evidence provided for the claim was that two Chinese scientists were escorted from the lab in July 2019.

covid19scenario-119-13.sentence: The CBC did, in fact, report that two Chinese scientists were escorted from the lab that month.

covid19scenario-119-14.sentence: However, the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) told the CBC that they were asked to leave due to an investigation of what it described as a “policy breach” and “administrative matter,” and that the matter was not connected to the COVID-19 virus outbreak.

covid19scenario-119-15.sentence: “This is misinformation and there is no factual basis for claims being made on social media,” PHAC spokesperson Eric Morrissette told the CBC in January 2020.

covid19scenario-119-17.sentence: As NewsGuard’s Washington correspondent Gabby Deutch documented in Wired, the earliest example of this claim was a January 26, 2020 article on GreatGameIndia.com titled “Coronavirus Bioweapon–How China Stole Coronavirus From Canada And Weaponized It.” The article was then republished, word-for-word, on Red-rated misinformation site ZeroHedge.com, then one of the top 900 sites in the U.S., whose version was subsequently reposted on RedStateWatcher.com, an anonymously-run conservative site that is among the top 140 U.S. news sites as measured by engagement.

covid19scenario-119-18.sentence: MYTH: “The COVID-19 virus contains ‘HIV-like insertions,’ suggesting it was engineered.”

covid19scenario-119-20.sentence: This claim was attributed to research posted on the website BioRxiv.org, where users can submit scientific studies before they have been peer-reviewed and published.

covid19scenario-119-21.sentence: According to a February 2020 article on the fact-checking website HealthFeedback.org, the study’s finding that there is a similarity between the new strain of coronavirus and HIV “was detected using extremely short protein sequences, a practice that often gives rise to false positive results,” and the authors failed to note that the same sequences are found in many other organisms.

covid19scenario-119-22.sentence: The authors of the study withdrew it from BioRxiv.org two days after it first appeared on the website.

covid19scenario-119-24.sentence: The preprint study on BioRxiv.org was first promoted by Harvard University epidemiologist and health economist Eric Feigl-Ding in a series of tweets on Jan. 31, 2020, though he did note the study had not been peer-reviewed.

covid19scenario-119-25.sentence: Ding’s tweets and the preprint study were then cited in a ZeroHedge.com article posted that same day, which was in turn republished in full on InfoWars.com, a Red-rated far-right website that falsely asserted that the mass shooting Sandy Hook Elementary was a hoax, among other false claims.

covid19scenario-119-26.sentence: MYTH: “The COVID-19 pandemic was predicted in a simulation.”

covid19scenario-119-28.sentence: The Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security and the Gates Foundation did host a pandemic preparedness exercise called Event 201 in October 2019.

covid19scenario-119-29.sentence: However the scenario used in the exercise involved a fictional coronavirus with different characteristics than the COVID-19 virus.

covid19scenario-119-30.sentence: For example, in this simulation, the virus originated on pig farms in Brazil, not in China.

covid19scenario-119-32.sentence: This earliest example of this claim was Jan. 22, 2020 post on Reddit’s conspiracy subreddit channel, referencing October 2019 news articles about the simulation along with more recent articles about the outbreak in China.

covid19scenario-119-33.sentence: It was then more widely circulated in a Jan. 23 article from InfoWars.

covid19scenario-119-34.sentence: MYTH: “A group funded by Bill Gates patented the COVID-19 virus.”

covid19scenario-119-36.sentence: While it is true that the U.K.-based Pirbright Institute has accepted funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the patent referenced in these claims covers a separate strain of coronavirus that only affects chickens, not humans.

covid19scenario-119-37.sentence: “Pirbright does not currently work with human coronaviruses,” the institute said in a January 2020 post on its website responding to the patent conspiracy theory.

covid19scenario-119-39.sentence: Fact-checking websites FactCheck.org and Snopes pointed to a Jan. 21, 2020 tweet from Jordan Sather, a U.S. conspiracy theorist with 140,000 Twitter followers and 218,000 subscribers to his “Destroying the Illusion” YouTube channel, as the earliest example of this claim.

covid19scenario-119-40.sentence: InfoWars then repeated it in the Jan. 23 article about the simulation co-hosted by the Gates Foundation described above.

covid19scenario-119-41.sentence: MYTH: “The COVID-19 virus is a manmade bioweapon.”

covid19scenario-119-43.sentence: Scientific evidence points to the virus originating in bats.

covid19scenario-119-44.sentence: A study published in the journal Nature in February 2020 found the new virus’s genome is “96 percent identical” to a bat coronavirus.

covid19scenario-119-45.sentence: A March 2020 study published in the journal Nature Medicine concluded that the virus “is not a laboratory construct or a purposefully manipulated virus.”

covid19scenario-119-47.sentence: Similar conspiracy theories have been promoted by misinformation websites during earlier disease outbreaks.

covid19scenario-119-48.sentence: For example, NaturalNews.com, a Red-rated network of site promoting both medical and political conspiracies, previously labeled the Ebola virus as a “bioweapon” during the 2014 Ebola outbreak in Africa.

covid19scenario-119-49.sentence: The earliest mention NewsGuard could find of the COVID-19 virus being called a “bioweapon” was a Jan. 23, 2020 video from U.S. conspiracy theorist David Zublick, titled “Breaking: Coronavirus Is Bioweapon For Population Control.” Zublick has 160,000 subscribers on YouTube.

covid19scenario-119-50.sentence: MYTH: “5G cell phone technology is linked to the coronavirus outbreak.”

covid19scenario-119-52.sentence: There is no evidence that the health effects of the COVID-19 virus are related to 5G, according to articles from Reuters and FullFact.org.

covid19scenario-119-53.sentence: In an April 2020 article from the BBC, Dr. Simon Clarke, a microbiology professor at the University of Reading, described claims that 5G either transmits the virus, or suppresses the immune system, thus making people more vulnerable to it, as “complete rubbish.” A March 2020 report from the International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection found no evidence that 5G networks posed a risk to human health.

covid19scenario-119-55.sentence: The earliest mention NewsGuard could find tying 5G to the new coronavirus was a Jan. 20, 2020 article on the Red-rated, anonymously-run French conspiracy theory blog Les Moutons Enragés, according to data First Draft News shared with NewsGuard.

covid19scenario-119-56.sentence: The claims then spread across Facebook Groups and YouTube channels already steeped in misleading 5G claims (such as asserting that it can cause cancer) with a new angle highlighting the novel coronavirus.

covid19scenario-119-57.sentence: They were then amplified on social media by celebrities such as actor Woody Harrelson and boxer Amir Khan.

covid19scenario-119-58.sentence: Some in the U.K. eventually attacked 5G telephone poles, prompting the Department for Digital, Culture, Media, and Sport to call on platforms to take action against the spread of these conspiracies.

covid19scenario-119-61.sentence: Colloidal silver is a liquid substance containing silver particles.

covid19scenario-119-62.sentence: According to the U.S. National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health, “scientific evidence doesn’t support the use of colloidal silver dietary supplements for any disease or condition.” Using colloidal silver can cause a condition called argyria, a permanent bluish-gray discoloration of the skins, nails, and gums.

covid19scenario-119-63.sentence: In a February 2020 article by The Associated Press, NCCIH director Helene Langevin said, “There are no complementary products, such as colloidal silver or herbal remedies, that have been proven effective in preventing or treating this disease (COVID-19), and colloidal silver can have serious side effects.”

covid19scenario-119-65.sentence: Despite the lack of evidence supporting its use, colloidal silver has been promoted as a cure for all kinds of ailments, from bacterial and viral infections to cancer, since the late 19th century.

covid19scenario-119-66.sentence: Existing sellers of colloidal silver began promoting it as a treatment for COVID-19, most prominently on a Feb. 12, 2020 broadcast of televangelist Jim Bakker’s TV show.

covid19scenario-119-67.sentence: On March 6, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and Federal Trade Commission warned Bakker to stop representing his silver products as a treatment for COVID-19 on his show and website.

covid19scenario-119-68.sentence: MYTH: “Miracle Mineral Solution can cure COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-119-70.sentence: Miracle Mineral Solution, or MMS, is chlorine dioxide, a powerful bleaching agent that has been promoted as a cure-all for everything from cancer to autism.

covid19scenario-119-71.sentence: There is no reliable evidence supporting its use for COVID-19 or any other disease, and ingesting it can cause serious side effects such as severe vomiting and acute liver failure, according to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

covid19scenario-119-73.sentence: The earliest mention of the theory that MMS could treat the new coronavirus strain was a January 25, 2020 tweet from Jordan Sather, the U.S. conspiracy theorist described above as originating the Bill Gates patent conspiracy.

covid19scenario-119-74.sentence: It was later promoted in a January 27, 2020 article posted on the website of Jim Humble, a former Scientologist and gold prospector who claimed to have discovered MMS in 1996.

covid19scenario-119-77.sentence: The World Health Organization has stated, “Garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties.

covid19scenario-119-78.sentence: However, there is no evidence from the 2020 outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the new strain of coronavirus.”

covid19scenario-119-80.sentence: The earliest example of this claim was a Jan. 31, 2020 post from an anonymous Twitter account based in the Philippines, sharing a recipe claiming the virus “can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic water,” according to a February 2020 article from FactCheck.org.

covid19scenario-119-81.sentence: MYTH: “High doses of vitamin C have been proven to be an effective treatment for COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-119-83.sentence: While a clinical trial is underway in China to test whether a high-dose vitamin C regimen is effective against the new strain of coronavirus, the claim that it is a proven treatment for COVID-19 is not supported by scientific evidence.

covid19scenario-119-84.sentence: Vitamin C has some marginal benefits for the common cold, such as reducing the duration of symptoms if it is taken before catching the cold, but those benefits can be achieved with a diet that includes 200 milligrams of vitamin C, according to Harvard Health Publishing.

covid19scenario-119-85.sentence: The daily dosage being tested in the Chinese trial is 60 times higher.

covid19scenario-119-87.sentence: The claim originated in a Jan. 26, 2020 press release titled “Vitamin C Protects Against Coronavirus,” from the International Society for Orthomolecular Medicine, which promotes large doses of nutritional supplements.

covid19scenario-119-88.sentence: The article was then republished in full the next day on HealthImpactNews.com, a Red-rated network of health sites with 450,000 Facebook followers that has promoted false health claims such as the debunked link between vaccines and autism.

covid19scenario-119-89.sentence: MYTH: “Lemon and hot water can cure COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-119-91.sentence: This myth relies on the false claim that what you eat or drink creates an alkaline environment in your body, making it less acidic by raising its pH level.

covid19scenario-119-92.sentence: In reality, drinking lemon juice (or anything else) cannot change your body’s pH level.

covid19scenario-119-93.sentence: Similar alkaline diet remedies have been falsely promoted as cancer cures, prompting Cancer Research UK to call them “biological nonsense” in a March 2014 article.

covid19scenario-119-95.sentence: This claim, according to a March 2020 article from PolitiFact.com, has its origins in a video shared on Facebook Messenger by Marian Gorban the owner of MrHealthyChannel, an alternative health channel on YouTube with more than 22,000 subscribers.

covid19scenario-119-96.sentence: This claim was first published by the Italian website ViralMagazine.it and received more than 70,000 interactions on Facebook, including more than 40,000 shares, according to data from social media metrics company CrowdTangle.

covid19scenario-119-97.sentence: The false claim was also published on the site FanMagazine.it, which is connected to the Facebook Pages ღஐღ Semplicemente Charlie ღஐღ and Ti amo, però ღஐღ Semplicemente Charlie ღஐღ, which have more than 2 million followers and more than 600,000 followers, respectively.

covid19scenario-119-98.sentence: MYTH: “The Italian Government is preventing migrants from being tested for COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-119-100.sentence: The Italian Government has never forbidden the testing of migrants for the COVID-19 virus.

covid19scenario-119-101.sentence: As stated by the director of the provincial health authority of Ragusa Angelo Aliquò in February 2020, “Ministerial guidelines say that only those who come from areas at risk and have symptoms need to be tested.” According to NewSicilia.it, three migrants with symptoms who arrived in Italy on the Ocean Viking ship were tested for COVID-19 in February 2020, and the tests came back negative.

covid19scenario-119-103.sentence: This claim appears to have first been published by the Red-rated Italian website VoxNews.info on Feb. 27, 2020, misquoting an interview of Aliquò by Il Primato Nazionale, a site connected to the neo-fascist movement CasaPound.

covid19scenario-119-104.sentence: The next day, the Red-rated ViralMagazine.it published an almost identical article — adding more fabricated quotes attributed to Aliquò — which received more than 80,000 Facebook interactions, more than a third of which were shares, according to CrowdTangle data.

covid19scenario-119-105.sentence: MYTH: “Bill Gates plans to use COVID-19 to implement a mandatory vaccine program with microchips to surveil people.”

covid19scenario-119-107.sentence: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates and his charitable foundation have long supported vaccine initiatives.

covid19scenario-119-108.sentence: However, there is no vaccine — for COVID-19 or otherwise — with a microchip or other surveillance feature.

covid19scenario-119-109.sentence: In December 2019, researchers at MIT, who had received funding from the Gates Foundation, published a paper about technology they developed that can keep a vaccination record on a patient’s skin with an ink-like injection that could be read by smartphone.

covid19scenario-119-110.sentence: The technology does not have the capacity to track patients’ movements, Kevin McHugh, a Rice University bioengineering professor who worked on the study while at MIT, told FactCheck.org.

covid19scenario-119-111.sentence: The Gates Foundation told FactCheck.org that the research is unrelated to COVID-19.

covid19scenario-119-112.sentence: Some versions of this conspiracy theory also assert that the purpose of the “tracking” vaccine is to control or reduce the world population, which is also false.

covid19scenario-119-114.sentence: According to FactCheck.org and BuzzFeed News, conspiracy theorists have distorted comments that Gates made during a March 18 Reddit forum.

covid19scenario-119-115.sentence: Gates discussed “digital certificates,” a technology used to transmit encrypted information online, as part of a solution to expand COVID-19 testing.

covid19scenario-119-116.sentence: However, conspiracy theorists claim that Gates was referring instead to the MIT research into skin-based vaccination records — which is not related to the “digital certificates” Gates was describing.

covid19scenario-119-117.sentence: The website BioHackInfo.com published a story containing the false claims on March 19, 2020, the day after Gates’ Reddit forum, using the term “microchip,” which did not appear in either Gates’ statements or the research.

covid19scenario-119-118.sentence: FactCheck.org and BuzzFeed News reported that the conspiracy theory was subsequently amplified by a YouTube video from the Jacksonville, Florida-based Law of Liberty Baptist Church, which received 1.9 million views as of publication.

covid19scenario-119-119.sentence: MYTH: “Getting a flu shot increases your risk of getting COVID-19.”

covid19scenario-119-121.sentence: There is no evidence that the flu vaccine either increases or decreases the risk of being infected with the COVID-19 virus.

covid19scenario-119-122.sentence: Studies cited to back this false claim, such as one published in the journal Vaccine in January 2020, did not mention the COVID-19 virus, having used data collected years before the virus emerged.

covid19scenario-119-123.sentence: While some studies — including the research published in Vaccine — have found an association between the flu shot and non-influenza respiratory illnesses, such as the common cold, over the course of a single flu season, that association was not found in a larger study that included data from multiple seasons.

covid19scenario-119-124.sentence: According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, “the preponderance of evidence suggests that this is not a common or regular occurrence and that influenza vaccination does not, in fact, make people more susceptible to other respiratory infections.”

covid19scenario-119-126.sentence: DisabledVeterans.org, a news site that calls itself a “watchdog” of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, first promoted the claim in a March 11, 2020 article that cited the January 2020 Vaccine study.

covid19scenario-119-127.sentence: The same study was cited in an April 16, 2020 article by Collective Evolution, a NewsGuard Red-rated conspiracy theory website that has more than 5 million followers on Facebook.

covid19scenario-119-128.sentence: MYTH: “Wearing a face mask can cause hypercapnia, a condition of too much carbon dioxide”

covid19scenario-119-130.sentence: Hypercapnia is caused by having much carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, such as can be caused by underwater diving.

covid19scenario-119-131.sentence: Health care workers who regularly wear face masks for long periods of time do not develop this condition.

covid19scenario-119-132.sentence: According to health fact-checking website HealthFeedback.org, even surgical and N95 masks are porous enough to allow gas molecules such as carbon dioxide to pass through, while limiting exposure to the respiratory droplets that could spread the COVID-19 virus.

covid19scenario-119-134.sentence: The earliest example of this claim was an April 6, 2020 post from a Facebook user in Bangkok, Thailand, cited in a May 2020 article from Agence France-Presse.

covid19scenario-119-135.sentence: English language posts promoting the same claim began circulating in Thailand and South Africa that same month, AFP reported.

covid19scenario-119-136.sentence: MYTH: “Wearing a face mask will push the COVID-19 virus into your brain”

covid19scenario-119-138.sentence: There is no evidence that wearing a mask will cause the COVID-19 virus to enter the brain.

covid19scenario-119-139.sentence: “Breathing out the virus is not going to appreciably change the amount that is there,” Sarah Stanley, an infectious diseases professor at the University of California, Berkeley, told The Associated Press in a May 2020 fact-checking article.

covid19scenario-119-140.sentence: “Therefore, there should be no reason why wearing a mask would increase your chance of infection in the brain.”

covid19scenario-119-142.sentence: A May 11, 2020 article on NewsGuard Red-rated anti-technology website Technocracy.news from Dr. Russell Blaylock, a retired neurosurgeon, was the earliest example of this claim identified by NewsGuard.

covid19scenario-119-143.sentence: Blaylock has previously promoted the debunked link between vaccines and autism in a health newsletter he edits for conservative news site Newsmax.com.

covid19scenario-119-144.sentence: PJ Media, a Red-rated site that is among the top 70 news sites in the U.S. as measured by engagement, repeated Blaylock’s false face mask claims in a May 14 article.

covid19scenario-119-145.sentence: While PJ Media later corrected other information in the article, its correction notice did not address the false claim about face masks pushing the COVID-19 virus into the brain.

covid19scenario-119-146.sentence: MYTH: “George Soros owns a lab in Wuhan where the coronavirus was created”

covid19scenario-119-148.sentence: In the past, George Soros has indeed invested in WuXi, a pharmaceutical biotech company with a branch in Wuhan, the Chinese city where the pandemic started, as PolitiFact reported in March.

covid19scenario-119-149.sentence: However, he does not own the company, and there is no evidence connecting the company – or Soros – to the outbreak.

covid19scenario-119-151.sentence: NewsGuard found evidence of rumors connecting Soros and this lab circulating on Twitter in late January.

covid19scenario-119-152.sentence: On February 24, it gained more attention when NewsGuard Red-rated Swiss German-language website Kla.tv published a video making that connection again.

covid19scenario-119-153.sentence: Then, as Politifact reported, the hoax appeared on Facebook on March 16.

covid19scenario-119-154.sentence: On April 1, French far-right website Ns2017.Wordpress.com promoted the claim, and another French Red-rated site called Lanceurdalerte.info shared it again three days later.

covid19scenario-119-155.sentence: MYTH: “The French Pasteur Institute patented the virus”

covid19scenario-119-157.sentence: The Pasteur Institute, a French research foundation, did not invent or patent the COVID-19 virus.

covid19scenario-119-158.sentence: The institute explains on its website that in 2004, it patented a strategy to create a vaccine for another strain of the SARS coronavirus, which is not the virus responsible for the Covid-19 disease.

covid19scenario-119-160.sentence: As French media Le Monde and Sciences et Avenir have reported, this hoax started with a since-deleted video published on Facebook on March 17.

covid19scenario-119-161.sentence: On March 18, NewsGuard French Red-rated website Ns2017.wordpress.com promoted the claim on its website.

covid19scenario-119-162.sentence: MYTH: “The French government authorized euthanasia in the middle of the crisis”

covid19scenario-119-164.sentence: In March 2020, the French government issued a decree that allowed doctors to temporarily use anti-epileptic drug Rivotril to alleviate pain for end-of-life patients in severe respiratory distress.

covid19scenario-119-165.sentence: However, the decree did not authorize euthanasia or physician-assisted death.

covid19scenario-119-166.sentence: There is no evidence that any patient in France was euthanized under these circumstances, and euthanasia is illegal in the country.

covid19scenario-119-168.sentence: First circulated on social media, this false claim was shared on April 7 on NewsGuard Red-rated anti-Islam website RiposteLaique.com.

covid19scenario-119-169.sentence: A day later, it was promoted by French far-right website NS2017.wordpress.com.

covid19scenario-119-170.sentence: On April 16, Red-rated French website BVoltaire.fr published an interview with a French medical doctor named Joëlle de Monredon claiming that the government’s move was “euthanasia and eugenics.” This interview was republished on April 18 by Contre-Info.com, a NewsGuard Red-rated website owned by a nonprofit connected with the Catholic nationalist organization Renouveau Français.

covid19scenario-119-171.sentence: MYTH: In Europe, “Contact tracing apps were automatically installed on people’s smartphones without their consent”

covid19scenario-119-173.sentence: As countries started lifting lockdowns, Google and Apple developed a tool for governments to build their own contact-tracing apps to curb the spread of the virus.

covid19scenario-119-174.sentence: In their latest updates, smartphones from the two brands included this exposure notification system.

covid19scenario-119-175.sentence: Some countries, like Italy, used this feature to build their national app, but others, like France, chose not to.

covid19scenario-119-176.sentence: In countries where governments decided to use it, citizens still had to download the app first, and to activate the feature before it did anything.

covid19scenario-119-178.sentence: In Italy, NewsGuard Red-rated site ByoBlu.com claimed on May 26 that the Google feature had been automatically installed and activated on people’s phones.

covid19scenario-119-179.sentence: In France, the Red-rated website LumiereSurGaia.com, a hub of coronavirus hoaxes and false information about topics such as UFOs and the environment, published on May 29 an article claiming that the French government had secretly installed its app on people’s phones, and encouraged users to uninstall it.

covid19scenario-119-180.sentence: (At that time, the French government app had not even been released).

covid19scenario-119-181.sentence: The false claim was then reposted on May 31 by Red-rated site ReseauInternational.net and, on June 1, by WikiStrike.com.

covid19scenario-119-182.sentence: These three websites are among the most popular misinformation sites in France.

covid19scenario-119-183.sentence: MYTH: “The COVID-19 virus was engineered in a laboratory at the University of North Carolina”

covid19scenario-119-185.sentence: This variation on the false claim that the COVID-19 virus is manmade relies on misrepresenting a study published in the journal Nature Medicine in 2015.

covid19scenario-119-186.sentence: The research found that bat coronaviruses were capable of directly infecting humans, but it did not involve the same strain of coronavirus that causes COVID-19.

covid19scenario-119-187.sentence: The study authors included researchers from UNC as well as the Wuhan Institute of Virology in China.

covid19scenario-119-188.sentence: A March 2020 editor’s note on the original study addressed the conspiracy theory.

covid19scenario-119-189.sentence: “We are aware that this article is being used as the basis for unverified theories that the novel coronavirus causing COVID-19 was engineered,” the note said.

covid19scenario-119-190.sentence: “There is no evidence that this is true; scientists believe that an animal is the most likely source of the coronavirus.”

covid19scenario-119-192.sentence: The earliest mention of this false claim found by NewsGuard was a story from ShadOlsonShow.com in late February.

covid19scenario-119-193.sentence: Radio host Olson reported on his site that he was “First to reveal the links to the ‘gain of function’ coronavirus study by Dr. Ralph Baric at the University of North Carolina.” The claim received further attention when it was spread in a series of March 3, 2020 tweets from an account using the name Greg Rubini, which has 129,000 followers.

covid19scenario-119-194.sentence: According to a June 2020 article from BuzzFeed News, the Twitter account is run by an Italian man named Gregorio Palusa, a sound engineer and marketer.

covid19scenario-119-195.sentence: Palusa has no proven expertise in national security or intelligence, but conservative cable news network One America News brought this myth further into the mainstream by citing his tweets under the Greg Rubini pseudonym in a March 14 report, describing him as “a citizen investigator and monitored source amongst a certain set in the D.C. intelligence community,” according to liberal nonprofit Media Matters.

covid19scenario-119-197.sentence: Anthony Fauci will personally profit from a COVID-19 vaccine”

covid19scenario-119-199.sentence: There is no evidence that Fauci, director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), has personal financial investments in vaccines being developed for COVID-19.

covid19scenario-119-200.sentence: Fauci’s agency is working with pharmaceutical company Moderna on a potential vaccine — one of 141 that are currently in development, according to the World Health Organization — but PolitiFact found no record of a business relationship between Fauci and Moderna in an April 2020 search of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission’s database.

covid19scenario-119-202.sentence: PolitiFact reported that the false accusation against Fauci was made in an April 12, 2020 post on an anti-vaccine Facebook page called I Am Awake, which has 13,000 likes on the platform.

covid19scenario-119-203.sentence: A similar claim was made by anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., on an April 20 podcast hosted on TruePundit.com, a NewsGuard Red-rated website that ranks among the top 850 U.S. news sites as measured by engagement.

covid19scenario-119-204.sentence: Correction: An earlier version of this page incorrectly credited a 2019 study to researchers at Rice University and MIT.

covid19scenario-119-205.sentence: While the lead author of the study, Kevin McHugh, worked at Rice University when the study was published, he conducted the research during his time at MIT.

covid19scenario-127-0.sentence: A frenzy of speculation has arisen around the idea that the novel coronavirus responsible for the global COVID-19 pandemic might originally have escaped from a laboratory in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

covid19scenario-127-1.sentence: While there is so far no evidence being offered to support this suggestion, the fact that the mere possibility is being reported in mainstream media outlets like the Washington Post and Yahoo News might seem to give credence to earlier conspiracy theories about the virus being engineered in a biowarfare laboratory and deliberately released into the human population.

covid19scenario-127-3.sentence: Whether the virus first infected humans at the infamous Wuhan “wet market” or somehow took a more complicated route via a so far unidentified Chinese laboratory, the ultimate source of the novel coronavirus is still the same: wild populations of bats.

covid19scenario-127-5.sentence: None of the current speculation changes the one fact that is established beyond reasonable doubt — SARS-CoV-2 is a zoonotic virus, meaning it came from an animal and jumped into the human population.

covid19scenario-127-6.sentence: It appears that the Wuhan Institute of Virology is currently under suspicion because its scientists were studying bat coronaviruses in order to evaluate the possibility of the emergence of just such a pandemic as is currently underway.

covid19scenario-127-7.sentence: Indeed, it is thanks to their work that we know that SARS-CoV-2 is 96 percent “identical at the whole-genome level to a bat coronavirus” (to quote from a Feb. 3 Nature paper co-authored by the institute’s scientists) and that its most likely original host is the horseshoe bat.

covid19scenario-127-8.sentence: An investigation by the United States military into the origins of the virus, while noting the high degree of “speculation and rumor” around the issue, concurred that “the weight of evidence seems to indicate ‘natural.

covid19scenario-127-10.sentence: That the virus has natural origins is also apparent from its molecular structure.

covid19scenario-127-11.sentence: Scientists writing in Nature Medicine journal on March 17 made clear that “all notable SARS-CoV-2 features” were also observed “in related coronaviruses in nature” and that therefore “we do not believe that any type of laboratory-based scenario is plausible.”

covid19scenario-127-12.sentence: As Josie Golding, epidemics lead at the UK-based Wellcome Trust, pointed out: The findings “are crucially important to bring an evidence-based view to the rumors that have been circulating about the origins of the virus.”

covid19scenario-127-13.sentence: In the Nature Medicine paper, the scientists reach the definitive conclusion that SARS-CoV-2 is “the product of natural evolution,” Golding added, “ending any speculation about deliberate genetic engineering.”

covid19scenario-127-15.sentence: Would that it were so simple.

covid19scenario-127-16.sentence: All the news reports thus far rely on anonymous sources within the Trump Administration and the intelligence community — and the former have a strong interest in hyping Chinese responsibility in order to divert the spotlight from Trump’s own chaotic, slow and ill-informed response to the pandemic.

covid19scenario-127-17.sentence: A New York Times investigation published on April 11 looked in particular at the role of Matthew Pottinger, a former Wall Street Journal correspondent who is a noted China hawk and now deputy national security adviser in the Trump Administration.

covid19scenario-127-18.sentence: As the NYT reported, Pottinger and colleagues urged the CIA and other agencies to search for evidence that might “bolster his theory” that the “virus may have originated in one of the laboratories in Wuhan studying deadly pathogens” — even though “they didn’t have any evidence” to support such a contention.

covid19scenario-127-19.sentence: The Times report also reveals that “Mr.

covid19scenario-127-20.sentence: Pottinger and others — including aides to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo — pressed for government statements to use the term ‘Wuhan Virus’” in order to help seal the impression of direct Chinese responsibility.

covid19scenario-127-21.sentence: This “Wuhan Virus” insult infuriated Beijing, leading one Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson to spin his own retaliatory conspiracy theory about the origins of COVID-19 — that it was brought to China by the US military.

covid19scenario-127-22.sentence: The spat has continued with Trump’s latest move to defund the World Health Organization, ostensibly because it has been too sympathetic to the Chinese leadership, but again, more likely in reality aimed to deflect attention from his own missteps.

covid19scenario-127-24.sentence: Despite these competing geopolitical conspiracy theories, the most likely explanation about the origins of COVID-19 remains the original one: that the virus first spread into the human population of Wuhan from an animal at the city’s notorious “wet market.”

covid19scenario-127-25.sentence: Indeed the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market had reportedly sold chickens, pheasants, bats, hedgehogs, marmots, tiger frogs and snakes, as well as organs from rabbits and other animals, at some point over the previous months.

covid19scenario-127-26.sentence: Wildlife markets in China, as elsewhere in Asia, are notorious for keeping endangered and wild animals in close-confined unsanitary conditions that provide an ideal breeding grounds for germs and an easy route for viruses circulating in wild animals to infect humans via urine, feces or blood as they are butchered.

covid19scenario-127-27.sentence: While bats are consumed in China and may have been sold in the Wuhan wet market, it seems unlikely that SARS-CoV-2 jumped directly to people from wild bats.

covid19scenario-127-28.sentence: An “intermediate host” was probably involved in the virus’s evolution into a form more adapted to humans.

covid19scenario-127-29.sentence: This was also the case for previous coronavirus epidemics: the earlier SARS and MERS epidemics, respectively, had civet cats and camels as intermediate hosts.

covid19scenario-127-30.sentence: Currently pangolin — a scaly mammal endangered in the wild but often sold in Chinese markets — is the leading contender.

covid19scenario-127-31.sentence: This has led to calls from over a hundred conservation charities to close wildlife markets and stop bushmeat consumption throughout the world, and to do so permanently — both to protect animals from hunting, poaching and other exploitation and to reduce the potential for the next pandemic.

covid19scenario-127-32.sentence: After all, it is not only coronaviruses that have zoonotic origins.

covid19scenario-127-33.sentence: Ebola is likely to have infected humans from gorillas butchered in the forests of central Africa, while HIV is thought to have crossed into humans from chimpanzees, again probably when they were slaughtered for meat.

covid19scenario-127-34.sentence: Protecting endangered wildlife could therefore not only support biodiversity goals, but help humanity avoid the next global pandemic.

covid19scenario-127-35.sentence: With tens of thousands already dead and trillions of dollars wiped off the global economy thanks to COVID-19, the impacts of pandemics are surely too disastrous to allow conspiracy theories to derail a proper evidence-based global response.

segment-5.sentence: While more than 1,500 hospitalized patients with COVID-19 were chosen at random to receive hydroxychloroquine, more than 3,000 received usual care.

segment-0.sentence: Facebook Messenger video falsely claims hot lemon juice can kill the coronavirus

segment-1.sentence: A video being passed around on Facebook Messenger claims that curing the novel coronavirus is as easy as drinking hot lemon juice.

segment-2.sentence: The video, which a reader sent us on March 23, shows a series of stock images and videos with text underneath.

segment-3.sentence: A man with a British accent narrates.

segment-4.sentence: "Use as much natural vitamin C as possible to strengthen the immune system," he says during the nearly 2-minute video.

segment-5.sentence: "Slices of lemon in a cup of hot water can save your life.

segment-6.sentence: The hot lemon can kill the proliferation of this virus in our bodies!"

segment-7.sentence: The narrator identifies himself as "Jiao Shenme Minzi from China, a researcher at the Faculty of Medical Science, Zanjan University."

segment-8.sentence: He goes on to say that "warm lemons can have the same beneficial effects as medicines" and their juice "destroys the virus and cures the flu."

segment-9.sentence: As evidence, the narrator credits a "Professor Chen Horin, CEO of the Beijing Military Hospital."

segment-10.sentence: (Screenshot from Facebook Messenger)

segment-11.sentence: We’ve fact-checked several chain messages about the coronavirus, as well as bogus cures, on apps like iMessage, Snapchat and WhatsApp.

segment-12.sentence: So we looked into this one, too.

segment-13.sentence: There is no evidence that drinking hot lemon juice kills COVID-19.

segment-14.sentence: Health officials have debunked the hoax, and a similar version has been shared in India and Italy.

segment-15.sentence: There are a couple of things wrong with the video right off the bat.

segment-16.sentence: First, the narrator claims to be based in China.

segment-17.sentence: But Zanjan University is in Iran.

segment-18.sentence: We found no evidence that the university has anyone on its medical faculty named Jiao Shenme Minzi, at least not as of September 2017, when its webpage says it was last updated.

segment-19.sentence: In fact, "Jiao Shenme Minzi" is one letter off from "jiao shenme mingzi," a popular phonetic pronunciation of a phrase used in Chinese when asking someone for their name.

segment-20.sentence: Second, there is no evidence that vitamin C is effective against COVID-19.

segment-21.sentence: We rated a similar claim False in February.

segment-22.sentence: Third, we could find no trace of a researcher named Chen Horin.

segment-23.sentence: The name has been used for similar hoaxes in the past.

segment-24.sentence: The Messenger video comes from Marian Gorban, the owner of MrHealthyChannel, an alternative health channel on YouTube with more than 21,000 subscribers.

segment-25.sentence: One of his most popular videos claims you can lose weight quickly by drinking ginger syrup.

segment-26.sentence: RELATED:

segment-27.sentence: Stop sharing myths about preventing the coronavirus.

segment-28.sentence: Here are 4 real ways to protect yourself

segment-29.sentence: Gorban, whose Facebook profile says he lives in Romania, also claims to be an expert in search engine optimization.

segment-30.sentence: We reached out to him for a comment, but we haven’t heard back.

segment-31.sentence: On its website, the World Health Organization says that, while it recommends eating plenty of fruits and vegetables to stay healthy, there is no scientific evidence that lemon treats or prevents COVID-19 infection.

segment-32.sentence: To prevent coronavirus infection, officials advise people to regularly wash their hands, avoid touching their face, disinfect surfaces in their homes daily and avoid people who are sick.

segment-33.sentence: As of now, there is no specific treatment for COVID-19.

segment-34.sentence: But according to the Mayo Clinic, patients can alleviate symptoms — including cough, shortness of breath and fever — with cough medicine, pain and fever relievers, rest, and fluids.

segment-36.sentence: We rate it False.

segment-0.sentence: No evidence that vitamin D prevents coronavirus, say experts

segment-1.sentence: No evidence exists to support taking vitamin D supplements to prevent Covid-19, UK public health experts have found.

segment-2.sentence: A rapid review of evidence for claims that the so-called sunshine vitamin could reduce the risk of coronavirus was launched amid concerns about the disproportionate number of black, Asian and minority ethnic people contracting and dying from the disease.

segment-3.sentence: Higher levels of melanin in the skin lead to less absorption of vitamin D from sunlight.

segment-4.sentence: However, on Monday, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) said that, having examined five studies, it had not found evidence to support any benefit from vitamin D with respect to Covid-19.

segment-5.sentence: "While there are health benefits associated with vitamin D, our rapid evidence summary did not identify sufficient evidence to support the use of vitamin D supplements for the treatment or prevention of Covid-19," said Paul Chrisp, the director of the centre for guidelines at Nice.

segment-6.sentence: "We know that the research on this subject is ongoing, and Nice is continuing to monitor new published evidence."

segment-7.sentence: At the same time, the Scientific Advisory Committee on Nutrition (SACN) reached similar conclusions, stating that the evidence did not support recommending vitamin D supplementation to prevent acute respiratory tract infections.

segment-8.sentence: However, both Nice and the SACN advised that people should continue to follow official guidance, which was updated in April, advising people to consider taking 10 micrograms of vitamin D a day to maintain bone and muscle health, amid concerns people were not getting enough sunlight during lockdown.

segment-9.sentence: Prior to April, the advice was for people with little exposure to sunlight and/or with dark skin to take 10 micrograms all year round and for others to consider doing so in autumn and winter.

segment-10.sentence: Nice said the five studies it had examined all had very low quality of evidence, noting that none had adjusted for confounding factors, such as body mass index, higher socioeconomic deprivation and poorer self-reported health.

segment-11.sentence: The SACN said that one of the most widely supported studies to support the hypothesis that vitamin D reduces the risk of acute respiratory tract infections was one led by Prof Adrian Martineau in 2017.

segment-12.sentence: But Martineau, a professor of respiratory infection and immunity at Queen Mary University of London, has himself described the evidence on vitamin D as "mixed" and the SACN said randomised controlled trials published since 2017 had not supported its conclusions.

segment-13.sentence: The committee said it would keep the topic "under urgent review" and consider updating its assessment if new evidence emerged from randomised controlled trials.

covid19scenario-39-0.sentence: Clear Up Confusion About Elderberry in COVID-19 Patients

covid19scenario-39-1.sentence: Growing concerns about the potential for cytokine storm syndrome in coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) patients has raised questions about the safety of elderberry.

covid19scenario-39-2.sentence: Cytokine storm syndrome – a severe overproduction of immune cells that can lead to life-threatening lung inflammation – may be a complication of COVID-19 in some patients.

covid19scenario-39-3.sentence: This has raised questions about the safety of elderberry, since elderberry may have a pro-cytokine effect.

covid19scenario-39-4.sentence: A very small study that used blood from healthy donors shows that elderberry extract increases the production of inflammatory cytokines in vitro.

covid19scenario-39-6.sentence: Other research suggests that elderberry might actually have an anti-cytokine effect.

covid19scenario-39-7.sentence: Furthermore, there is NO evidence that elderberry induces cytokine storm syndrome in humans.

covid19scenario-39-8.sentence: Tell your patients that there’s no strong evidence that elderberry causes cytokine storm syndrome.

covid19scenario-39-9.sentence: While this is reassuring, it’s also important to remind patients that there is NO evidence that elderberry can help treat or prevent COVID-19.

covid19scenario-39-10.sentence: Although elderberry is commonly taken for colds and the flu, and there’s some evidence it might help for these conditions, elderberry has NOT been evaluated for treating or preventing COVID-19.

covid19scenario-39-11.sentence: Overall, there is no strong evidence that elderberry can cause cytokine storm syndrome, but there’s also no good evidence that it can improve symptoms or prevent COVID-19.

covid19scenario-39-12.sentence: Continue reminding patients that the best way to prevent COVID-19 is through proper hand hygiene, using disinfectant sprays or wipes to clean surfaces, etc.

segment-8.sentence: The new guideline came from analyzing data from four randomized international trials with 7,000 patients hospitalized for COVID-19.

covid19scenario-103-1.sentence: (WWLP) – The COVID-19 outbreak is a global pandemic.

covid19scenario-103-4.sentence: There are many myths about COVID-19 that have been circulating through social media — here are some of the most common ones, from the World Health Organization.

covid19scenario-103-5.sentence: Myth #1: Cold weather kills the novel coronavirus

covid19scenario-103-6.sentence: Truth: The CDC and the WHO have said this from the start: the most effective way to protect yourself from COVID-19 is with frequent handwashing with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer with at least 60 percent alcohol.

covid19scenario-103-7.sentence: The WHO says there is “no reason to believe cold weather can kill the new coronavirus,” or other diseases, for that matter.

covid19scenario-103-8.sentence: Myth #2: COVID-19 cannot be transmitted in hotter, more humid climates

covid19scenario-103-9.sentence: Truth: Protective measures, like proper handwashing and social distancing, need to be taken no matter where you live.

covid19scenario-103-10.sentence: COVID-19 can be transmitted anywhere, regardless of how hot or humid the air is.

covid19scenario-103-11.sentence: Myth #3: Taking a hot bath prevents you from getting COVID-19

covid19scenario-103-12.sentence: Truth: This myth has been stemming from the false idea that cold and hot temperatures can kill the virus.

covid19scenario-103-13.sentence: Just like the cold weather and hot and humid climate myths, this is not true.

covid19scenario-103-14.sentence: Your body temperature stays relatively stable even when you take an extremely hot bath.

covid19scenario-103-15.sentence: This just leaves you with a risk of a burn.

covid19scenario-103-16.sentence: Still, the best way to prevent getting COVID-19 is to wash your hands often.

covid19scenario-103-17.sentence: This prevents viruses on your hands from infecting you when you touch your face.

covid19scenario-103-18.sentence: Myth #4: Coronavirus can be transmitted through mosquito bites

covid19scenario-103-19.sentence: Truth: As temperatures continue to warm as we dive into spring, mosquitoes will become more common again in Western Massachusetts.

covid19scenario-103-20.sentence: That typically brings a risk of Eastern Equine Encephalitis (EEE) and West Nile Virus, but the increasing population of mosquitoes does not create another channel in which you can get COVID-19.

covid19scenario-103-21.sentence: From the WHO, “there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that the new coronavirus could be transmitted by mosquitoes.” This is because the new coronavirus is spread primarily through droplets when someone with the coronavirus sneezes or coughs.

covid19scenario-103-22.sentence: This is why social distancing and frequent hand washing is so important.

covid19scenario-103-23.sentence: Myth #5: Hand dryers are effective in killing the new coronavirus

covid19scenario-103-24.sentence: Truth: The heat from a hand dryer alone is not enough to kill the new coronavirus.

covid19scenario-103-25.sentence: However, in combination with washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, this method is very effective.

covid19scenario-103-26.sentence: You can also dry your hands after using paper towels, or instead use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.

covid19scenario-103-27.sentence: Myth #6: UV lamps kill the new coronavirus

covid19scenario-103-28.sentence: Truth: It’s too soon to tell whether UV light is an effective way to kill the new coronavirus, and the World Health Organization does not suggest its use.

covid19scenario-103-29.sentence: It should especially not be used on hands or your body as it can cause irritation.

covid19scenario-103-30.sentence: UV light has been known to kill the flu virus, however.

covid19scenario-103-31.sentence: Myth #7: Thermal scanners can detect everyone who is infected with coronavirus

covid19scenario-103-32.sentence: Truth: Thermal scanners, like thermometers, can detect people who have a higher-than-normal body temperature due to infection from COVID-19.

covid19scenario-103-33.sentence: But not everyone who is infected with the coronavirus has a fever yet.

covid19scenario-103-34.sentence: According to the WHO, “it takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and develop a fever.”

covid19scenario-103-36.sentence: Myth #8: Spraying alcohol and chlorine all over yourself kills the coronavirus

covid19scenario-103-37.sentence: Truth: This will not cure you of COVID-19 if it has already entered your body.

covid19scenario-103-38.sentence: Spraying alcohol and chlorine all over your body can be harmful if it gets into your eyes or mouth.

covid19scenario-103-39.sentence: The World Health Organization says they both can be used to disinfect surfaces, however.

covid19scenario-103-40.sentence: Myth #9: Getting a pneumonia vaccine protects against COVID-19

covid19scenario-103-41.sentence: Truth: The WHO says, “vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and Haemophilus influenza type B vaccine, do not provide protection against the new coronavirus.” COVID-19 is a respiratory infection, yes, but it requires its own vaccine, which is in the testing phase right now.

covid19scenario-103-42.sentence: Myth #10: Rinsing your nose, and gargling, with saline solution helps prevent COVID-19 infection

covid19scenario-103-44.sentence: But this does not apply to COVID-19, and other respiratory infections.

covid19scenario-103-45.sentence: The same applies to gargling a saline solution.

covid19scenario-103-46.sentence: Myth #11: Eating garlic helps prevent COVID-19 infection

covid19scenario-103-47.sentence: Truth: There is no scientific evidence that eating garlic prevents you from being infected with the novel coronavirus.

covid19scenario-103-48.sentence: However, according to the National Institutes of Health, it does have some antimicrobial properties.

covid19scenario-103-49.sentence: Myth #12: The coronavirus only affects older people, and not younger people

covid19scenario-103-51.sentence: The best ways are frequent hand washing, the use of hand sanitizer, and social distancing.

covid19scenario-103-56.sentence: This myth may have stemmed from the fact some people who are hospitalized for coronavirus have received antibiotics, but that’s because bacterial “co-infections” are possible with COVID-19, according to the WHO.
